Authors: Schouleur A., Sapin J., Kluyskens V., Labrique F., Dehez B.
Title: Study and control of a magnetic bearing for flywheel energy storage system
Source title: POWERENG 2007 - International Conference on Power Engineering - Energy and Electrical Drives Proceedings
Affiliations: Université Catholique de Louvain, Center for Research in Mechatronics (CEREM), Place du Levant 2, B-1348 Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Schouleur, A., Université Catholique de Louvain, Center for Research in Mechatronics (CEREM), Place du Levant 2, B-1348 Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Sapin, J., Université Catholique de Louvain, Center for Research in Mechatronics (CEREM), Place du Levant 2, B-1348 Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Kluyskens, V., Université Catholique de Louvain, Center for Research in Mechatronics (CEREM), Place du Levant 2, B-1348 Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Labrique, F., Université Catholique de Louvain, Center for Research in Mechatronics (CEREM), Place du Levant 2, B-1348 Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium; Dehez, B., Université Catholique de Louvain, Center for Research in Mechatronics (CEREM), Place du Levant 2, B-1348 Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium
Abstract: The purpose of this study is to develop a suspension system for a low-cost flywheel energy storage system. This suspension system is composed of two identical magnetic bearings mounted at the end of the flywheel. Due to a specific design of these magnetic bearings, it has the particularity to have only one active axis (sustentation). The others (centering) are passively stable. The control of the suspension is therefore limited to one axis. After a short description of the system, this paper presents the achievement of the control and all the elements needed to achieve it, within the scope of energy storage, therefore leading to a minimal energy consumption in the bearings. © 2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Flywheel energy storage system; Minimal energy; Specific design; Suspension system; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Flywheel propulsion; Flywheels; Magnetic bearings; Magnetic storage; Wheels; Suspensions (components)

Authors: Rangel C.M., Silva R.A., Pinto A.M.F.R.
Title: Fuel cells and on-demand hydrogen production: Didactic demonstration prototype
Source title: POWERENG 2007 - International Conference on Power Engineering - Energy and Electrical Drives Proceedings
Affiliations: Instituto Nacional de Engenharia, Tecnologia e Inovação, DMTP, Electrochemistry of Materials Unit, Paço do Lumiar, 22, 1649-038 Lisboa, Portugal; Departamento de Engenharia Quimica, Faculdade de Engenharia, Universidade do Porto, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Rangel, C.M., Instituto Nacional de Engenharia, Tecnologia e Inovação, DMTP, Electrochemistry of Materials Unit, Paço do Lumiar, 22, 1649-038 Lisboa, Portugal, Departamento de Engenharia Quimica, Faculdade de Engenharia, Universidade do Porto, Portugal; Silva, R.A., Instituto Nacional de Engenharia, Tecnologia e Inovação, DMTP, Electrochemistry of Materials Unit, Paço do Lumiar, 22, 1649-038 Lisboa, Portugal, Departamento de Engenharia Quimica, Faculdade de Engenharia, Universidade do Porto, Portugal; Pinto, A.M.F.R., Instituto Nacional de Engenharia, Tecnologia e Inovação, DMTP, Electrochemistry of Materials Unit, Paço do Lumiar, 22, 1649-038 Lisboa, Portugal, Departamento de Engenharia Quimica, Faculdade de Engenharia, Universidade do Porto, Portugal
Abstract: Hydrogen is presently the most promising alternative to fossil fuels as an energy carrier. A demonstration prototype, for didactic purposes, is presented featuring a polymer electrolyte fuel cell (PEM) coupled to a reactor designed for simultaneous on-demand hydrogen production and storage. The operating principles are illustrated in a simple but comprehensive manner with the aid of an attached booklet emphasizing advantages and limitations to performance on the basis of the electrochemical and physical knowledge of the system. The cell generates electricity combining hydrogen and air in an electrochemical direct process, using a modular device, which is characterized by high efficiency in the conversion and low level of emissions and noise. Emphasis is given to the modularity of the cell and the role of the different components that makes the energy conversion possible, from chemical to electrical and from electrical to mechanical, driving a small motor associated to a bus-like shaped mobile platform. The cell is designed for an air breathing cathode. On-demand hydrogen using chemical hydrides is the option taken for production as well as storage of the fuel, based on the high volumetric and gravimetric efficiency exhibited. Data for comparison with other storage methods are provided in order to encourage a debate on the different storage systems and applications. The demonstration is intended for students at High School and University levels. © 2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Air breathing cathode; Chemical hydride; Energy carriers; High school; Low level; Mobile platform; Modular device; On-demand hydrogen; Operating principles; Polymer electrolyte fuel cells; Storage systems; University levels; Demonstrations; Energy conversion; Fossil fuels; Fuel cells; Fuel storage; Hydrogen; Hydrogen storage; Hydrogen production

Authors: Sousa D.M., Costa Branco P.J., Dente J.A.
Title: Electric bicycle supplied by an electronic converter using distinct forms of energy storage
Source title: POWERENG 2007 - International Conference on Power Engineering - Energy and Electrical Drives Proceedings
Affiliations: DEEC AC-Energia/CAUTL, Institute Superior Técnico, TU Lisbon, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1049-001 Lisboa, Portugal; DEEC AC-Energia, Institute Superior Técnico, TU Lisbon, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1049-001 Lisboa, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Sousa, D.M., DEEC AC-Energia/CAUTL, Institute Superior Técnico, TU Lisbon, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1049-001 Lisboa, Portugal; Costa Branco, P.J., DEEC AC-Energia, Institute Superior Técnico, TU Lisbon, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1049-001 Lisboa, Portugal; Dente, J.A., DEEC AC-Energia, Institute Superior Técnico, TU Lisbon, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1049-001 Lisboa, Portugal
Abstract: This work implements an electronic converter to supply an electric vehicle powered by two distinct power supplies, a battery and supercapacitors. A solution for the implementation of the electronic converter in the electric vehicle (in this case a bicycle) is developed. The control system of the electronic converter is built regarding the vehicle's optimal functioning and to increase its autonomy. Based on the implemented system, experimental results are shown and the advantages and disadvantages of this solution are analyzed. © 2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric bicycles; Electronic converters; Power supply; Super capacitor; Electric power systems; Electric vehicles; Electric drives

Title: Storage electrical energy assessment in real time of lead-acid batteries
Source title: POWERENG 2007 - International Conference on Power Engineering - Energy and Electrical Drives Proceedings
Affiliations: Escola Superior de Tecnologia de Setúbal, IPS, LabSEI, CAUTL, Portugal; Escola Superior de Tecnologia de Setúbal, IPS, CESET, INESC, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Fernão Pires, V., Escola Superior de Tecnologia de Setúbal, IPS, LabSEI, CAUTL, Portugal; Dias, O.P., Escola Superior de Tecnologia de Setúbal, IPS, CESET, INESC, Portugal
Abstract: This paper describes the development of a battery charger system for the autonomy of lead-acid batteries assessment in real time. In the monitoring system it is implemented an algorithm that models the dynamic behavior of the battery under different charge and discharge profiles. This will allow evaluating in real time, the available electrical energy storage in the battery. For the implementation of the proposed monitoring system the most important parameters that influence the autonomy of the battery have been identified. These parameters are: the electrical current, the voltage, the temperature and how the batteries are used in their charges and discharges regimes (historic of the battery). It was also developed the power supply and their system control which is used to assure that the electrical charge current of the batteries stays inside of the values recommended by the manufacturer. The ac/dc power converter is based on a single-phase power factor corrector buck topology. Extensive tests were made on the system for different charge and discharge profiles. This shows the right operation of the monitoring system as well as the accuracy of the proposed model for the batteries autonomy assessment that have showed a margin of error less than 6%. © 2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Battery chargers; Buck topology; Charge and discharge; Dynamic behaviors; Electrical charges; Electrical current; Electrical energy; Margin of error; Monitoring system; Power supply; Real time; Single-phase power; System control; DC-DC converters; Electric power factor; Electric power systems; Lead acid batteries; Mathematical models; Rating; Monitoring

Authors: Watanabe E.H., Aredes M., Barbosa P.G., Santos G., Lima F.K.D.A.A., Dias R.F.D.S.
Title: Flexible AC transmission systems
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, COPPE/Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, South America, Brazil; Electrical Engineering Department, Polytechnic School and COPPE/ Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, South America, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Watanabe, E.H., Electrical Engineering Department, COPPE/Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, South America, Brazil; Aredes, M., Electrical Engineering Department, Polytechnic School and COPPE/ Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, South America, Brazil; Barbosa, P.G., Electrical Engineering Department, COPPE/Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, South America, Brazil; Santos, G., Electrical Engineering Department, COPPE/Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, South America, Brazil; Lima, F.K.D.A.A., Electrical Engineering Department, COPPE/Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, South America, Brazil; Dias, R.F.D.S., Electrical Engineering Department, COPPE/Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, South America, Brazil
Abstract: This chapter presents the basic operation principles of flexible AC transmission systems (FACTS) devices. The chapter provides a brief introduction on the concept and its origin, the text then focuses on the ideal behavior of each basic shunt and series FACTS device. Guidelines on the synthesis of the first generation of these devices, based on thyristors, are presented, followed by the newer generations of FACTS devices based on self-commutated semiconductor switches. The switching characteristics of thyristors - controlled turn-on and natural turn-off - are appropriate for using in line-commutated converters, like in conventional HVDC transmission systems with a current source in the DC side. In this latter application, the technology for series connection of thyristors is very important due to the high-voltage characteristics of the transmission voltage. Self-commutated switches are adequate for use in converters where turn-off capability is necessary. Thyristor-based FACTS devices use line or natural commutation together with large energy storage elements (capacitors or reactors). On the other hand, devices based on self-commutating switches like GTOs, IGCTs, or IGBTs uses gate-controlled commutation. In general, it is said that the first generation of FACTS devices is based on conventional line commutated thyristors and the subsequent generations are based on gate-controlled devices. The most important FACTS devices based on thyristors and self-commutating devices are presented. © 2007 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Vollmer M.K., Weilenmann M., Steinbacher M., Reimann S., Buchmann B., Bach C., Hill M., Fischer A., Bond S.W.
Title: Anthropogenic emissions of molecular hydrogen (H2) to the atmosphere: From a fossil fuel to an H2 energy economy
Authors with affiliations: Vollmer, M.K.; Weilenmann, M.; Steinbacher, M.; Reimann, S.; Buchmann, B.; Bach, C.; Hill, M.; Fischer, A.; Bond, S.W.
Abstract: A future hydrogen-based (H2) energy economy is likely to change our atmosphere - hopefully to a cleaner one. Concerns are raised related to the budget of atmospheric H2which may change with unknown consequences for the chemistry of the atmosphere. We analyse current anthropogenic H 2 emissions, particularly from the traffic sector, and assess future emissions on regional and global scales. These today fossil-fuel based H 2 emissions need to be balanced against the emissions of a "leaky" H2 economy to better understand future atmospheric H2 changes. For hydrogen vehicles, diffusive leakage of gaseous H2 during storage and propulsion, in both parking and running mode, is a significant loss, and therefore its quantification is crucial for the overall loss estimates. We have developed a method to estimate overall system emissions of H2. The method is applicable for any climate-controlled test cells with chassis dynamometers.

Authors: Bujedo L.A., Rodríguez J., Martínez P.J.
Title: Study of the optimum working temperature for a real solar cooling absorption facility in valladolid
Affiliations: Fundacion CARTIF, Parque Tecnologico Boecillo, Pac 205, Boecillo 47151, Spain; Universidad Miguel Hernandez, Avda. De la Universidad s/n, Elche 03202, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Bujedo, L.A., Fundacion CARTIF, Parque Tecnologico Boecillo, Pac 205, Boecillo 47151, Spain; Rodríguez, J., Fundacion CARTIF, Parque Tecnologico Boecillo, Pac 205, Boecillo 47151, Spain; Martínez, P.J., Universidad Miguel Hernandez, Avda. De la Universidad s/n, Elche 03202, Spain
Abstract: In this work, a comparison of the energy produced from a solar absorption facility based on different activation temperatures and parameters of collectors has been made. Thermal chillers improve their efficiency when the temperature of the focus that is feeding them is greater while the collectors are working in bad yields when the medium temperature inside them grows. This makes so important to know the optimum operational temperature for each solar system. With the use of a simulation program, TRNSYS 16, the solar cooling absorption facility situated in CARTIF Foundatiońs building placed in the continental climate of Valladolid (Spain), has been modeled. In the system configuration exists cold and heat storage tanks to make the cooling offer a little independent of the demand. Varying the parameters of the existing collectors that can be found in the market and the temperatures needed to drive the chiller, a complete revision of the possibilities has been done. Climatological data proceeding from TMY archives has been used to simulate from June to September making an estimation of the energy produced with differential controls and constant flow mass pumps. Copyright © (2007) by the International Solar Energy Society.
Index Keywords: Activation temperatures; Climatological data; Continental climate; Differential control; Medium temperature; Operational temperature; System configurations; Working temperatures; Collector efficiency; Cooling systems; Digital storage; Solar energy; Absorption cooling

Authors: Sarasüa J.I., Fraile-Ardanuy J., Pérez J.I., Wilhelmi J.R., Sánchez J.A.
Title: Control of a run of river small hydro power plant
Source title: POWERENG 2007 - International Conference on Power Engineering - Energy and Electrical Drives Proceedings
Affiliations: Departamento de Ingeniería Civil: Hidráulica y Energética, ETSI Caminos, Canales y Puertos, Technical University of Madrid (UPM), Spain
Authors with affiliations: Sarasüa, J.I., Departamento de Ingeniería Civil: Hidráulica y Energética, ETSI Caminos, Canales y Puertos, Technical University of Madrid (UPM), Spain; Fraile-Ardanuy, J., Departamento de Ingeniería Civil: Hidráulica y Energética, ETSI Caminos, Canales y Puertos, Technical University of Madrid (UPM), Spain; Pérez, J.I., Departamento de Ingeniería Civil: Hidráulica y Energética, ETSI Caminos, Canales y Puertos, Technical University of Madrid (UPM), Spain; Wilhelmi, J.R., Departamento de Ingeniería Civil: Hidráulica y Energética, ETSI Caminos, Canales y Puertos, Technical University of Madrid (UPM), Spain; Sánchez, J.A., Departamento de Ingeniería Civil: Hidráulica y Energética, ETSI Caminos, Canales y Puertos, Technical University of Madrid (UPM), Spain
Abstract: Nowadays, new small hydro power plants are being built all over the world. In most cases, these power plants lack significant storage capacity; therefore the more adequate control strategy is to keep constant the water level at the intake basin to capture the maximum amount of energy from the river flow. In this paper, the control of a diversion run of river hydro plant is considered. A practical criterion for tuning the gains of the PI controller is proposed. The influence of turbine operating point on controller gains is analyzed. Finally, the results are applied to a model of a typical hydropower plant to verify that the tuning of the PI controller allows a stable and suitable control of the power plant. © 2007 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Level control; Root locus design method; Run of river hydro plant control
Index Keywords: Control strategies; Controller gain; Hydro plants; Hydropower plants; Operating points; PI Controller; River flow; Root locus design method; Run of river hydro plant control; Small hydro power plants; Storage capacity; Hydroelectric power; Hydroelectric power plants; Level control; River control; River diversion; Root loci; Small power plants; Tuning; Water levels; Controllers

Title: The dielectric spectrum of flexible polyelectrolyte solutions
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, National Taiwan University, Taipei 106, Taiwan; Department of Physics, Center of Theoretical Physics, National Taiwan University, Taipei 106, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lu, C.-Y.D., Department of Chemistry, National Taiwan University, Taipei 106, Taiwan, Department of Physics, Center of Theoretical Physics, National Taiwan University, Taipei 106, Taiwan
Abstract: The simplest version of the double-layer polarization theory for the flexible polyelectrolyte solution is formulated where the thin-double-layer limit is taken. The double-layer region of the polyelectrolyte contains the excess fluxes of charge and salt where the off-diagonal Onsager coefficient couples the charge- and the neutral-salt dynamics. The dynamic charge and the salt distributions are solved for the weakly charged polyelectrolyte. We calculate the free-energy storage and loss under the applied AC electric field to obtain the dielectric function, which depends on the chain configuration through the chain structure factor. A simple mean-field structure factor for the flexible chains is used to calculate the dielectric spectrum for the full range of the polyelectrolyte concentration. © Europhysics Letters Association.

Authors: De Vera N.P., Rimando B.L., Rimando L.A., Kalaw M.E.
Title: Testing of a cold thermal storage classroom air conditioning system equipped with occupancy sensors
Source title: Proceedings - 9th Asia Pacific Conference on the Built Environment 2007: "Sustainable HVAC and R Technology"
Affiliations: 1Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, De La Salle University-Manila, 1004, Manila, Philippines
Authors with affiliations: De Vera, N.P., 1Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, De La Salle University-Manila, 1004, Manila, Philippines; Rimando, B.L., 1Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, De La Salle University-Manila, 1004, Manila, Philippines; Rimando, L.A., 1Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, De La Salle University-Manila, 1004, Manila, Philippines; Kalaw, M.E., 1Mechanical Engineering Department, College of Engineering, De La Salle University-Manila, 1004, Manila, Philippines
Abstract: A Kolin window type air conditioner model KAG-19ME installed in a classroom was equipped with a cold water thermal storage system controlled via occupancy sensors. The cold thermal storage system consisted of a 150 liter water tank with three partitions connected by weirs, one for the returning warm water, one for the cold water settling, and one for the cold water used for the releasing phase. The water is cooled, in the charging period, in the evaporator during periods when the air conditioning load is low. The cold water is used, during the releasing phase, to supercool the liquid from the condenser prior to throttling to the evaporator. The flow of water in and out of the storage tank is controlled by two pumps which is in turn controlled through occupancy sensor input. Two heat exchangers were used, one to supercool the refrigerant after the condenser, and the other to cool the water that will be stored inside the cold storage tank.Initial tests show an increase in the coefficient of performance of the air conditioning system, however, energy consumption is not mitigated because of additional consumption by the pumps.
Author Keywords: Cold thermal storage; Occupancy sensors
Index Keywords: Air conditioning load; Airconditioning systems; Coefficient of Performance; Cold thermal storage; Cold waters; Energy consumption; Occupancy sensors; Sensor inputs; Storage tank; Thermal storage system; Two-pump; Warm water; Window type air conditioner; Cold storage; Condensers (liquefiers); Energy utilization; Evaporators; Heat convection; Heat storage; Pumps; School buildings; Sensors; Supercooling; Sustainable development; Teaching; Water tanks; Air conditioning

Title: Proceedings - 9th Asia Pacific Conference on the Built Environment 2007: "Sustainable HVAC and R Technology"
Source title: Proceedings - 9th Asia Pacific Conference on the Built Environment 2007: "Sustainable HVAC and R Technology"
Abstract: The proceedings contain 25 papers. The topics discussed include: cooling system in ethanol plant with starch base feedstock; stabilizing chilled water distribution; frictional performance of wavy fin-and-tube heat exchangers - data with larger diameter tube and deep tube row; heat and mass transfer modeling of two stage indirect-direct evaporative air coolers; refrigerant selection for sustainable future; modular air-conditioning system in an underground mass rapid transit station; variable speed tri-rotor screw compressor: raising the bar for variable speed performance; testing of a cold thermal storage classroom air conditioning system equipped with occupancy sensors; a numerical study of the effect of the evaporating temperature on energy usage in a tube-ice making tower; achieving acceptable indoor air quality with unitary air conditioning units in hot and humid climates; and investigation and improvement of indoor air quality in selected grade school classrooms in Metro Manila.

Title: Optimistic future for short-sea shipping
Abstract: Norway has desires of strengthening short-sea shipping, and this was presented in the so-called Soria Moria Declaration. Egil Rensvik of Marintek analyzed the situation at Verftskonferansen 2006. Mr. Rensvik showed that although coastal shipping has traditionally played an important part in Norwegian transport, given the lack of railways, the long-term tendency has been for trucks to take over the transport of goods. Mr. Rensvik pointed out that there are various ways in which the short-sea shipping sector can improve its competitiveness. One is by developing new vessel concepts, e.g., module-based for lower construction costs and to provide a more effective transport platform. There are energy savings to be made through improved hulls and propulsion. An important factor would be to see the ship as part of a total transport infrastructure. Not least, using natural gas as a fuel would help to increase the use of natural gas ashore. The coastal gas infrastructure would comprise LNG reception terminals and storage at strategic locations along the coastline fed by small LNG ships, probably < 10,000 cu m. This would fuel the intermodal transport chain and would also be used in power generation.

Title: Terrorists set to feel the Force
Abstract: Famous for its industrial processes using flow knowhow, including CFD, its hydrodynamic and aerodynamic expertise, with as many as 30-40 ship tests/yr in its sophisticated towing tank, Force Technology has also long prided itself on its simulation capabilities, built on its strong hydrodynamic and aerodynamic expertise. Less exotic, perhaps, but just as significant, was work done to simulate tug operations as they interact with LNG carrier and floating production and storage offshore vessel mooring, as the offshore energy market continues to expand. Here, force was working on behalf of Wijsmuller, model testing tug operations to establish its future tug size and number requirements. As tugs come in close to large ships, they interact with them as they follow in their wake.

Title: Water resources and renewable energy development in Asia: Asia 2006 Symposium Report
Source title: International Journal on Hydropower and Dams
Abstract: A two-day symposium held in Bangkok on November 30 and December 1, 2006, focused on major water resources development programs presently underway and planned throughout Asia. The opening session by Alison Bartle, Director of Aqua-Media International, detailed about the activities in the field of water resources development such as hydropower. The plenary session covered topics of socio-economic development, water resources and food security, and storage and role of dams. Parallel sessions covered topics such as sustainability: sedimentation management, environmental aspects and case studies, and large construction sites: managing efficiency and safety. power systems- technology innovation and synergy covered topics such as tidal, in-stream and low head hydropower and synergy between energy sources: operation, planning and experience.

The topics discussed include: secure web applications via automatic partitioning; tolerating Byzantine faults in transaction processing systems using commit barrier scheduling; low-overhead Byzantine fault-tolerant storage; MUVI: automatically inferring multi-variable access correlations and detecting related semantic and concurrency bug; attested append-only memory: making adversaries stick to their word; staged deployment in mirage, an integrated software upgrade testing and distribution system; integrating concurrency control and energy management in device drivers; VirtualPower: coordinated power management in virtualized enterprise systems; improving file system reliability with I/O shepherding; generalized file system dependencies; information flow control for standard OS abstractions; and secure virtual architecture: a safe execution environment for commodity operating systems.

Authors: Martins J.F., Joyce A., Rangel C., Sotomayor J., Rui C., Pires A., Carvalheiro J., Silva R.A., Viana S.
Title: RenH2 - Stand-alone energy system supported by totally renewable hydrogen production
Source title: POWERENG 2007 - International Conference on Power Engineering - Energy and Electrical Drives Proceedings
Affiliations: INETI, DER, Paço do Lumiar 22, 1649-038 Lisboa, Portugal; LABSEI, ESTS/IPS, Campus do IPS, Estefannilha, 2914-508 Setúbal, Portugal; INETI, Electroqimica de Materials, DMTP, Paço do Lumiar 22, 1649-038 Lisboa, Portugal; ESTT, IPT, Quinta do Contador, Estrada da Serra, 2300-313 Tomar, Portugal; REQUIMTE, CQFB, Dpto. Quimica, FCT/UNL, Quinta da Torre, 2829-516 Caparica, Portugal; Rui, C., CEEL, IST, UTL, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1049-001 Lisboa, Portugal; Pires, A., LABSEI, ESTS/IPS, Campus do IPS, Estefannilha, 2914-508 Setúbal, Portugal; Carvalheiro, J., ESTT, IPT, Quinta do Contador, Estrada da Serra, 2300-313 Tomar, Portugal; Silva, R.A., INETI, Electroqimica de Materials, DMTP, Paço do Lumiar 22, 1649-038 Lisboa, Portugal; Viana, S., INETI, DER, Paço do Lumiar 22, 1649-038 Lisboa, Portugal
Abstract: This paper describes a Stand-Alone Energy System Supported by Totally Renewable Hydrogen Production. The system was conceived for off-grid operation and is composed by solar panels, a wind turbine, a fuel-cell, an electrolyzer, hydrogen tanks and power electronics converters. The basic control strategy for the overall system considers the pressurized hydrogen gas storage as the energy buffer. The basic logic is that the exceeding renewable energy (solar and wind) is used to accumulate hydrogen, while the fuel cell uses this hydrogen to produce electrical energy when there is insufficient solar/wind energy. © 2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Basic logic; Control strategies; Electrical energy; Electrolyzers; Energy systems; Hydrogen tank; Off-grids; Power electronics converters; Pressurized hydrogen; Renewable energies; Renewable hydrogen production; Solar panels; Buffer storage; Electrolytic cells; Fuel cells; Hydrogen; Hydrogen storage; Power electronics; Solar energy; Solar power generation; Hydrogen production

Title: Status of the ALBA project
Source title: NATO Security through Science Series B: Physics and Biophysics
Affiliations: CELLS, PO Box 68, 08193 Bellaterra, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Bordas, J., CELLS, PO Box 68, 08193 Bellaterra, Spain
Abstract: ALBA is a 3GeV third generation Synchrotron Radiation (SR) Facility currently under construction in Cerdanyola del Vall's, Barcelona, Spain. The Storage Ring is to deliver as high as possible photon flux densities on the samples. To this end the Storage Ring has been designed to have an electron beam emittance of ca. 4.5 nm.rad and, in spite of a relatively small perimeter, a significant number of straight sections in which to house Insertion Devices (IDs). The injector complex consists of a 100 MeV LINAC and a small emittance (ca. 9 nm.rad), full energy, 3 GeV, Booster. It is intended to operate the accelerator complex in a top-up mode from the very beginning of its operation. The project started in earnest in 2004 and its completion with seven beam-lines (BLs) in its initial phase, is expected by 2009, so that routine user operation can start in 2010. © 2007 Springer.
Author Keywords: accelerator; brightness; insertion device; synchrotron radiation

Title: Knowledge representation for subassembly designing using CBR methodology
Source title: Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Advanced Research in Virtual and Rapid Prototyping: Virtual and Rapid Manufacturing Advanced Research Virtual and Rapid Prototyping
Affiliations: Tallinn University of Technology, Tallinn, Estonia
Authors with affiliations: Nekrassov, G.I., Tallinn University of Technology, Tallinn, Estonia; Portjanski, L.A., Tallinn University of Technology, Tallinn, Estonia
Abstract: The aim is to develop an integrated design space for CAD of technological equipments for SMEs. The model of the design environment is represented as a two-level hierarchical decision-making system. The proposed environment provides support for creating and manipulating 3D models of technological equipment and their components, calculating functional and structural properties and the evaluation criteria, and for determining the rules to control the design process for optimising the portfolio of interdependent projects of technological equipments. As examples the design of work-holder is considered. The computer aided work-holder design system is created on Case Based Reasoning, in which the attributes of the workpiece and structure of workholder as case index code are designed for the retrieve of the similar cases, and the structure and hierarchical relation of case library are stored. The structure of case storage (database and knowledge base) for general work-holders selected as an object for mining and sampling of the developed software are worked out. © 2008 Taylor & Francis Group.
Index Keywords: 3-d models; Case libraries; Case-based reasonings; Cbr; Decision-making systems; Design environments; Design process; Design systems; Evaluation criterion; Hierarchical relations; Integrated designs; Knowledge base; Similar case; Work pieces; Case based reasoning; Concurrent engineering; Electric energy storage; Industrial research; Job analysis; Knowledge based systems; Knowledge representation; Rapid prototyping; Three dimensional; Structural design

Title: Monte Carlo simulation of the adsorption of methane and tetrafluorocarbon on single walled carbon nanotubes
Affiliations: Department of Physical Chemistry, Collage of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Ghadarghadr, Y., Department of Physical Chemistry, Collage of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran; Hashemianzadeh, S.M., Department of Physical Chemistry, Collage of Chemistry, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: Alternative fuels must be substantially non-petroleum, provide energy security and environmental benefits, and substitute for conventional fuels such as gasoline and diesel. Natural gas, which consists mainly of methane, fits this definition and is widely available in many countries. One of the strategic goals of the modern automobile manufacturing industry is to replace gasoline and diesel with alternative fuels such as natural gas. In this report, we elucidate the desired characteristics of an optimal adsorbent for gas storage. The U.S. Department of Energy has outlined several requirements that adsorbents must fulfill for natural gas to become economically viable, with a key criterion being the amount adsorbed at 35 bar. We explore the adsorption characteristics of methane on an armchair carbon nanotube and contrast it with the characteristics of CF4. In this research work, adsorptions of pure methane and tetraflouro carbon on (7, 7) armchair carbon nanotubes (CNTs) were studied. Lennard-Jones potential was used for the gas-gas and gas-carbon nanotube interactions. Potential parameters for the carbon-gas and carbon-carbon interactions were obtained from the Lorentz-Berthelot combining rules. Virial equation of state was used to study the pure gas molecules. The work was carried out at a variety of temperatures and pressures. © 2007 American Institute of Physics.
Author Keywords: Methane; Monte Carlo simulation; Single walled carbon nanotube; Teteraflourocarbon

Title: SOSP'07 - Proceedings of 21st ACM SIGOPS Symposium on Operating Systems Principles

Abstract: The proceedings contain 25 papers. The topics discussed include: protection and communication abstractions for web browsers in MashupOS; secure web applications via automatic partitioning; tolerating byzantine faults in transaction processing systems using commit barrier scheduling; low-overhead byzantine fault-tolerant storage; MUVI: automatically inferring multi-variable access correlations and detecting related semantic and concurrency bugs; Sinfonia: a new paradigm for building scalable distributed systems; attested append-only memory: making adversaries stick to their word; staged deployment in mirage, an integrated software upgrade testing and distribution system; integrating concurrency control and energy management in device drivers; improving file system reliability with I/O shepherding; and information flow control for standard OS abstractions.

Title: CO 2 capture for sequestration
Affiliations: Shell Global Solutions International B.V., Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Li, K.J., Shell Global Solutions International B.V., Netherlands; Protopapas, G., Shell Global Solutions International B.V., Netherlands
Abstract: Environmental concerns have led to increased interest in processes that aim to capture CO 2. The produced CO 2 stream can be stored in depleted oil fields or aquifers. Post-combustion carbon capture is an attractive option, since this technology can easily be implemented in existing facilities without significant modifications. However, as CO 2 capture is an energy intensive process, there is a significant efficiency penalty with the addition of the capture plant. This effect can be minimised with appropriate integration between the power plant and the CO 2 capture plants. A study by Shell on the potential benefits of various integration options on the overall efficiency of a Combined Cycle Gas Turbine (CCGT) power plant and a post-combustion CO 2 capture plant system was conducted to determine the optimum integration configuration between plants. The CCGT power plant considered consists of 2 Gas Turbine's (GT) and 1 Steam Turbine (ST) with a design capacity of approximately 800MWe at a net electrical Lower Heating Value (LHV) efficiency of approximately 58%. Addition of an amine based CO 2 capture plant, including drying and compression, and designed to produce high purity CO 2 at a pressure level suitable for aquifer storage, led to a net electrical LHV efficiency reduction to approximately 45%. A number of integration options as well as their combinations were simulated using a steady state, thermodynamic cycle modeling software tool for the power plant and an in-house developed spreadsheet tool for the capture plant. The best performance achieved resulted in an overall efficiency of approximately 50%. Technology, which is readily available in the market at the time of the study, was considered throughout the evaluation. Copyright 2007, International Petroleum Technology Conference.
Index Keywords: Aquifer storage; Carbon capture; Combined cycle gas turbine; Design capacity; Environmental concerns; High purity; In-process; Lower heating value; Modeling softwares; Number of integrations; Overall efficiency; Plant systems; Post-combustion; Potential benefits; Pressure level; Spreadsheet tools; Steady state; Thermodynamic cycle; Amines; Aquifers; Combustion; Gas turbines; Hydrogeology; Marine engines; Oil fields; Petroleum engineering; Steam power plants; Technology; Thermodynamic properties; Turbomachinery; Energy efficiency

Authors: Bortkevich S., Boldyrev A., Kostrov S., Wooden W.
Title: Creation of multicomponent fuels without use of thermal-catalvtic methods
Affiliations: RusGasOil, LLC; SPE, BEPA, LLC
Authors with affiliations: Bortkevich, S., RusGasOil, LLC; Boldyrev, A., RusGasOil, LLC; Kostrov, S., SPE, BEPA, LLC; Wooden, W., SPE, BEPA, LLC
Abstract: This paper presents a new method and technology to create different types of fuels from water-fuel emulsions and multi-component mixtures as two potential solutions to the fuel-energy problem. The technology consists of specialized hydrodynamic devises that convert crude oils which can have high water cuts into homogeneous high-octane gasoline or diesel whilst not greatly degrading the octane number. The new method does not require thermal treatment and/or catalysts. As the process reaches 94-98% of product output, mazut or any other analogous heavy fuel is added prior to the sprayer/injector. The add-mixed fuels can consist of: gas/oil plus water; diesel plus water; mazut and waste products of chemical processing plus water; liquid fuel plus coal dust plus water, for just some possibilities. The specialized hydrodynamic devices can (i) create various emulsions, dispersions and suspensions; (ii) atomize liquids and include saturation with flammable/non-flammable gases (iii) resolve problems with enhancement of thermo-mass-transfer processes in multi-component, multiphase substances, and (iv) resolve the problem with utilization of heavy hydrocarbon fraction sediments in fuel storage tanks by means of mixing them with the tank fuel in required proportions. The paper provides the results of lab experiments and pilot implementations. Copyright 2007, International Petroleum Technology Conference.

Title: Reducing CO 2 emissions by making cheaper CO 2 capture technologies available
Affiliations: Shell Global Solutions International B.V., Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Klaver, T., Shell Global Solutions International B.V., Netherlands
Abstract: The Royal Dutch Shell Group (Shell) 1 was one of the first energy companies to acknowledge the threat of climate change - to call for action by governments; our industry and energy users; and to take action ourselves. Shell's strategy: to expand our alternative energies portfolio, while investing in advanced CO2 solutions in order to improve our ability to manage emissions from our hydrocarbon business. Measures to manage future emissions will include developing new technologies to capture and store CO 2 underground. The pursuit of Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) technologies allows Shell to play an important and leading role towards addressing the need for an increasing worldwide demand for energy, while at the same time dealing with the need to reduce global emissions. Authors: Lindblom A., Larsson A., Bernhoff H., Leijon M.
Title: 45 GW pulsed-power generator
Affiliations: Division for Electricity, Uppsala University, Box 534, SE-751 21, Uppsala, Sweden; Swedish Defence Research Agency (FOI), SE-147 25, Tumba, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Lindblom, A., Division for Electricity, Uppsala University, Box 534, SE-751 21, Uppsala, Sweden; Larsson, A., Division for Electricity, Uppsala University, Box 534, SE-751 21, Uppsala, Sweden, Swedish Defence Research Agency (FOI), SE-147 25, Tumba, Sweden; Bernhoff, H., Division for Electricity, Uppsala University, Box 534, SE-751 21, Uppsala, Sweden; Leijon, M., Division for Electricity, Uppsala University, Box 534, SE-751 21, Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: The construction of a 45 GW pulsed-power generator with an impedance of 2 Ωis presented. The generator can deliver a rectangular pulse of 300 kV with duration of 200 ns across a matched load. The generator is designed to be able to deliver a voltage of 500 kV into a 10Ω unmatched load with an electric power of 25 GW. The primary energy storage of the generator consists of a 50 kV, 20 kJ capacitor bank. The 50 kV is discharged into a 1:12 transformer that charges a pulse-forming line to 600 kV. When charged, the pulse-forming line is discharged into the load via a spark gap. The transformer is of the type transmission-line-like where the highvoltage and low-voltage windings consists of high-voltage cables that are interleaved wounded. The pulse-forming line consists of 8x40 m long 110-kV coaxial cables, where both ends are connected to the load. Each cable is grounded at 20 m and connected in parallel. The cables have a characteristic impedance of 31Ω and the parallel set-up makes the pulse-forming line impedance 2 ΩThe total length, height and width of the pulse generator are 4 m, 2 m and 1.2 m respectively. © 2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Capacitor bank; Characteristic impedance; Electric power; High voltage cable; High-voltages; Low-voltage; Matched load; Primary energies; Pulse-forming lines; Pulsed-power generators; Rectangular pulse; Spark-gaps; Total length; Transmission-line; Capacitors; Electric cables; Plasmas; Signal generators; Transformer windings; Pulse generators

Authors: Smith P.D., Qu C., Hong K.
Title: On models of pulse power storage and forming lines
Affiliations: Department of Mathematics, Macquarie University, NSW, Australia; Defence Science and Technology Organisation, Edinburgh, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Smith, P.D., Department of Mathematics, Macquarie University, NSW, Australia; Qu, C., Department of Mathematics, Macquarie University, NSW, Australia; Hong, K., Defence Science and Technology Organisation, Edinburgh, Australia
Abstract: The design of nanosecond high-current generators is usually one of three schemes: a high voltage microsec- ond pulse voltage generator and pulse forming line; a relatively low-voltage pulse voltage generator and inductive energy storage in vacuum; or the switch- ing of energy into a load with the help of a plasma- erosion opening switch. The use of an inductive stor- age (IS) of energy with an electro-explosive opening switch (EEOS) allows charging of a pulse forming line in about 100 ns; this ensures insulation of high electri- cal strength and reduces overall dimensions and weight of the line. Optimisation of various designs that include an EEOS is usually performed by examining a large number of experimental data for RLC circuit models. We consider a theoretical RLC-circuit model of a particular device, the magnetic-flux compression gen- erator (MCG). The energy conversion in the IS circuit occurs in two stages. Initially, the energy is stored in the inductance, with a partial loss for fuse heating; this stage is simultaneously one of heating and of accumu- lation of magnetic energy. At the second stage, the fuse resistance is determined mainly by the density of expanding metal and grows by a few orders of magni- tude in a short time (explosion stage), when the mag- netic field energy of increasing power is released into the fast-rising resistance of the fuse. We discuss the MCG detonation procedure, how the energy efficiency varies with respect to inductance and the EEOS pa- rameters, and how the energy is released to the load. ©2007 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Circuit models; Experimental data; Field energy; Flux compression; High voltage; High-current generator; In-vacuum; Inductive energy storage; Low-voltage pulse; Magnetic energies; Opening switch; Optimisations; Pulse forming lines; Pulse power; Pulse voltage; RLC circuit; Two stage; Circuit theory; Energy conversion; Energy efficiency; Explosives; Heating; High energy forming; Inductance; Microwave generation; Plasmas; Pulse generators

Abstract: Parameters of high power microwave compressors having a single storage cavity are presented for different frequency bands. Their resonant cavities operated with electrical field strength values close to critical ones which allowed par ex. to reach the output pulse power about 2 MW in Q-band and about 200 MW in S-band. Ways to go beyond these power values were considered. They were using asymmetrical TE-mode in a circular cavities, energy extraction through a multiport output element, the waveguide hybrid in this report, and series compression with resonant transfer of the energy stored in the first stage cavity. ©2007 IEEE.

Authors: Olga L., Giraldo V., Eduardo Arévalo S.
Title: Inhibiting factors for communication and information technologies usage - five colombian smes study
Source title: ICEIS 2007 - 9th International Conference on Enterprise Information Systems, Proceedings
Affiliations: Systems and Computing Engineering, Los Andes University, Calle 19 No 1-37 Este, Bogotá, Colombia
Authors with affiliations: Olga, L., Systems and Computing Engineering, Los Andes University, Calle 19 No 1-37 Este, Bogotá, Colombia; Giraldo, V., Systems and Computing Engineering, Los Andes University, Calle 19 No 1-37 Este, Bogotá, Colombia; Eduardo Arévalo, S., Systems and Computing Engineering, Los Andes University, Calle 19 No 1-37 Este, Bogotá, Colombia
Abstract: Small-to-Medium sized enterprises, SMEs, are the main development engine of economy, particularly in countries in development, as is the case in Colombia. SMEs must use information and communication technologies, ICT, as strategic tools to find their place in the global market; nevertheless, this is not a common situation for Colombian SME. In this work we present the results of a project that attempts to find factors inhibiting five Colombian SMEs toward strategic usage of ICT. Through this study we have looked at the structure and strategy of those enterprises, their value chains, ICT support to value chain activities - how and where they exploit ICT-, managerial attitude toward technology, and appropriation of ICT into business, looking for inhibiting factors. Results show that the most common inhibiting factors are: poor organizational planning; inability to identit' strategic use of ICT or no ICT leadership; no funding for ICT projects; lack of ICT expertise and lack of proper ICT usage by final users; and lack of technical support. Even though findings are not conclusive they show an existing trend, and highlight the main ICT inhibitor factors-IF- to be surpassed to attain local sustainable industries.

Abstract: In this article a set of processes which are considered to be of high-priority when initiating the implementation of a Software Process Improvement -SPI- project in Very Small Software Enterprises -VSEs-, is presented. The objective is to present the VSEs with a strategy to deal with the first processes that must be considered when they undertake an SPI project. The processes proposed in this article are fundamentally based on the analysis and contrast of several pieces of research carried out by the COMPETISOFT project. The fundamental principle of the proposal is that process improvement must be connected with the other software process management responsibilities.

Abstract: For enterprises to be able to use information technologies and communications with guarantees, it is necessary to have an adequate security management system and tools which allow them to manage it. In addition, security management system must have highly reduced costs for its implementation and maintenance in small and medium-sized enterprises (from here on refered to as SMEs) to be feasible. In this paper, we will show the tool we have developed using our model for the development, implementation and maintenance of a security management system, adapted to the needs and resources of a SME. Furthermore, we will state how this tool lets enterprises with limited resources manage their security system very efficiently. This approach is being directly applied to real cases, thus obtaining a constant improvement in its application.

Title: An intelligent information system for enabling product mass customization
Source title: ICEIS 2007 - 9th International Conference on Enterprise Information Systems, Proceedings

Abstract: We propose to develop an intelligent design decision-support system to enable mass customization through product configuration using intelligent computational approaches. The system supports customer-driven product development throughout the product's life cycle and enables rapid assessment and changes of product design in response to changes in customer requirements. The overall system consists of four subsystems: customer requirement analysis subsystem, product configuration subsystem, product lifecycle cost estimation subsystem and product data management subsystem. Various challenging issues for developing the system are investigated, and a number of methodologies and techniques to resolve the issues are presented. The proposed system will allow SMEs to effectively compete with larger companies who command superior resources.

Abstract: The maturity and security management systems are essential in order to guarantee the continuity and stability of the companies in the current market situation. However, this requires that enterprises know in every moment their security maturity level and to what extend their information security system must evolve. In small and medium-sized enterprises, the application of security standards has an additional problem, which is the fact that they do not have enough resources to carry out an appropriate management. This security management system must have highly reduced costs for its implementation and maintenance in small and medium-sized enterprises (from here on refered to as SMEs) to be feasible. In this paper, we will put forward our proposal of a maturity model for security management in SMEs and we will briefly analyse other models that exist in the market. This approach is being directly applied to real cases, thus obtaining a constant improvement in its application.

Title: Multiobjective optimization of water supply system operation using Genetic Algorithms
Source title: Proceedings of the Combined International Conference of Computing and Control for the Water Industry, CCWI2007 and Sustainable Urban Water Management, SUWM2007
Affiliations: ECOSERVIÇOS - Management of Ecological Systems, Lisbon, Portugal; Instituto Superior Técnico, Technical University of Lisbon (TULisbon), Lisbon, Portugal

Abstract: The current paper focuses on the analysis and optimization of operating strategies of water supply systems taking into consideration different points of view related to the technical-hydraulic and water quality performance of the system. An integrated software tool has been developed composed of three main modules: a hydraulic simulator, a performance assessment tool and an optimization module based on Genetic Algorithms (GA). The developed tool has been applied to a real life case study: a water conveyance system - "Póvoa-Vila do Conde" system - integrated in the Multimunicipal Water Supply System of "Baixo Cávado" and Ave. Results have shown that the implementation of optimal pumping schemes allows the reduction of operation and maintenance direct costs associated with pumping energy between 6 to 8% as well as the increase of hydraulic reliability of the system, maximizing available water volume in storage tanks. ©2007 Taylor & Francis Group.

Authors: Flower D.J.M., Mitchell V.G., Codner G.P.
Title: The potential of water demand management strategies to reduce the greenhouse gas emissions associated with urban water systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Combined International Conference of Computing and Control for the Water Industry, CCWI2007 and Sustainable Urban Water Management, SUWM2007
Affiliations: Institute for Sustainable Water Resources Ewater CRC, Department of Civil Engineering, Monash University, Melbourne, VIC, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Flower, D.J.M., Institute for Sustainable Water Resources Ewater CRC, Department of Civil Engineering, Monash University, Melbourne, VIC, Australia; Mitchell, V.G., Institute for Sustainable Water Resources Ewater CRC, Department of Civil Engineering, Monash University, Melbourne, VIC, Australia; Codner, G.P., Institute for Sustainable Water Resources Ewater CRC, Department of Civil Engineering, Monash University, Melbourne, VIC, Australia
Abstract: Urban water systems contribute to climate change both directly through the fugitive greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions associated with water storage reservoirs and wastewater treatment processes, and indirectly through significant energy and materials consumption. This paper presents the findings of an investigation of the capacity of water demand management strategies to reduce the GHG emissions associated with operating a case study urban water system in Melbourne, Australia. It was found that a combination of structural and non-structural demand management strategies had the capacity to reduce household water consumption by up to 65% and the associated GHG emissions by up to 63%. These findings led to the conclusion that water utilities should implement carefully targeted water demand management strategies not only to delay the need for additional water resources, but also to rapidly reduce: (a) their own GHG emissions and, more importantly, (b) those usually attributed to consumers. © 2007 Taylor & Francis Group.

Title: Fast multi-level image vector quantization
Source title: ICSPC 2007 Proceedings - 2007 IEEE International Conference on Signal Processing and Communications
Affiliations: College of Science, University of Baghdad, Baghdad, Iraq
Authors with affiliations: George, L.A., College of Science, University of Baghdad, Baghdad, Iraq; Al-Abudi, B.Q., College of Science, University of Baghdad, Baghdad, Iraq
Abstract: In this research work, a measure based on moment features is proposed to index the reproduction vectors of any VQ codebook. The rotation and reflection invariant feature of the proposed indexing measure was utilized to get further reduction in the vectors searching time. The quad tree coding scheme was adopted to partition the compressed images into blocks. The overall error caused by using the closest reproduction vector for representing each image block was utilized to decide whether the tested image block needs to be further partitioned or not. To improve the compression performance the coded blocks have been remapped such that their DC energy was set zero, and their AC energy is normalized (i.e., set equal to 1). The test results indicated that the proposed coding scheme leads to an encouraging compression results, and the required encoding time was greatly reduced without causing significant decrease in the image quality. © 2007 IEEE.

Authors: Johnston J.H., Grindrod J.E., Dodds M., Schimitschek K.
Title: The use and performance of a nano-structured calcium silicate phase change material for thermal buffering in food packaging
Affiliations: School of Chemical and Physical Sciences, Victoria University of Wellington, PO Box 600, Wellington, New Zealand; AgResearch Limited, Agriculture and Science Centre, Gerald Street, Lincoln, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Johnston, J.H., School of Chemical and Physical Sciences, Victoria University of Wellington, PO Box 600, Wellington, New Zealand; Grindrod, J.E., School of Chemical and Physical Sciences, Victoria University of Wellington, PO Box 600, Wellington, New Zealand; Dodds, M., AgResearch Limited, Agriculture and Science Centre, Gerald Street, Lincoln, New Zealand; Schimitschek, K., School of Chemical and Physical Sciences, Victoria University of Wellington, PO Box 600, Wellington, New Zealand
Abstract: This paper presents the characteristics and use of a new nano-structured calcium silicate - phase change composite material to provide effective thermal buffering to paperboard packages during the transport and temporary storage of chilled perishable food from the supplier to the market. Nano-structured calcium silicate (NCS) is a proprietary new material comprising nano-size platelets stacked together in a unique open framework structure forming discrete particles of about 1-5 microns in size. The material has a high pore volume with a consequent high liquid absorbency of up to about 500-600 g oil. 100g -1 silicate (ASTM Oil Absorption test D281), and a high surface area of up to about 500 m2 g-1. Phase change materials (PCMs) absorb and release heat energy (latent heat) associated with the liquid-solid transition at their melting point. Alkanes (paraffin waxes) which have good latent heat properties (-160-190 J g-1) are often used, as they are non-toxic and the operating temperature (melting point) can be tuned by altering the hydrocarbon chain length. The major practical problem of containing the liquid phase on melting has been overcome here by incorporating the alkane PCM into the highly porous NCS matrix to a level of about 300 wt% of NCS (1 kg of composite comprises 250 g NCS and 750 g PCM). The resulting composite NCS-300PCM remains a powdery solid above the alkane melting point and can be readily incorporated into packaging materials to provide heat buffering properties of about 110 J g-1 of composite. The NCS-300PCM composite utilising Rubitherm RT6 alkane with a melting point of about 8°C was incorporated into a 10 mm paperboard liner and also into bubble-wrap liners placed on the inside walls of a fluted paperboard container to provide effective thermal buffering capacity for the contents of the container around this temperature. A rectangular container with dimensions 270 mm long × 200 mm wide x 180 mm high was constructed from 4 mm C-fluted paperboard and lined with six bubble wrap "Post-It" bags containing a total of 400 g NCS-300PCM composite spread thinly and evenly in the six bags. The NCS-300PCM composite provided effective thermal buffering capacity by maintaining the temperature inside the container at 10°C for some 5 hours after the outside temperature had increased to about 23°C The temperature/time profile on the inside wall of the NCS-300PCM liners for the empty container, was the same when the container was filled with 2 kg of asparagus, which served as a model for perishable food. This demonstrated the effectiveness of the NCS-300PCM composite in providing thermal buffering to such food produce. The extent of thermal buffering appears to be sufficient to ensure the temperature of perishable foodstuffs inside such a container remains below about 10°C during transport and temporary storage en route from the supplier to the market, thereby enabling the freshness to be maintained. Hence the use of NCS-300PCM composite phase change materials contained in bubble wrap liners is a simple way to impart effective thermal buffering capacity to a fluted paperboard container or other type of package, to ensure the contents of the container are buffered at a requisite temperature for a desirable period of time.

Title: Moderator neutron pulse-shape study for the NxGENS long-pulse spallation source
Source title: 8th International Topical Meeting on Nuclear Applications and Utilization of Accelerators, ACCAPP'07
Affiliations: Nuclear Engineering Program, The Ohio State University, 201 W. 19th Ave., Columbus, OH 43210; Los Alamos Neutron Science Center, MS H813, Los Alamos, NM 87545
Authors with affiliations: Willis, C., Nuclear Engineering Program, The Ohio State University, 201 W. 19th Ave., Columbus, OH 43210; Muhrer, G., Los Alamos Neutron Science Center, MS H813, Los Alamos, NM 87545
Abstract: We present results of MCNPX modeling of the neutron pulse time structure delivered by moderators under investigation for the proposed NxGENS long-pulse spoliation neutron source at the Los Alamos Neutron Science Center. As envisioned at the time of this work, low-energy neutrons would be produced for the NxGENS flight path by a single "backscattering" moderator of either water or liquid hydrogen in proximity to a tungsten-reflected tungsten target bombarded by 800 MeV protons. Specifically, our results here pertain to a 9.2 cm thick water moderator, and a 5.2 cm thick liquid hydrogen moderator with ortho:para ratio of 1:1. It was found that the Ikeda-Carpenter model accurately represents the storage of neutrons in these moderators, but that there are inaccuracies in the time region dominated by slowingdown. We suspect that inhomogeneity of the moderators, their limited size, and neutronic coupling of the moderators to their surroundings may be responsible for the observed disparities with this model.
Index Keywords: Flight paths; In homogeneities; Liquid hydrogens; Mev protons; Neutron pulses; Neutronic; Spallation sources; Spoliation neutrons; Time regions; Atoms; Cryogenic liquids; Hydrogen; Liquefied gases; Neutron sources; Neutrons; Tungsten; Moderators

Title: Evaluation of ionic liquids as heat transfer materials in thermal storage systems
Source title: Materials Science and Technology Conference and Exhibition, MS and T'07 - "Exploring Structure, Processing, and Applications Across Multiple Materials Systems"
Affiliations: Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL; Center for Green Manufacturing, Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, M., Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL; Reddy, R.G., Center for Green Manufacturing, Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, AL
Abstract: Ionic liquids have emerged as novel thermal storage and heat transfer fluids. They have several advantages over conventional molten salts and thermal oils such as negligible vapor pressure, wider liquid temperature range, and higher chemical stability. In this work, a series of ionic liquids such as [Cnmim][Cl], [Cnmim][Tf2N] and [C nmim][BF4] were synthesized and characterized using differential thermal analysis (DTA) and differential scanning calorimeter (DSC). Properties such as thermal stabilities, specific heat capacities and thermal storage densities were measured and calculated. After comparing these properties, it is found that thermal stability of ionic liquids with different anions was in the order of [Tf2N]- >[BF 4]- >[Cl]- within the studied temperature range. The calculated sensible thermal storage densities for the studied ionic liquid sample were greater than 160 MJ/m3 at 100°C. Special consideration is given to the thermodynamic properties changes of ionic liquid samples and their phase transformation enthalpies. Their possible application in latent heat storage systems to meet the requirements of high energy density is also discussed. It is concluded that ionic liquids are promising liquid thermal storage media and heat transfer fluids, although the present understanding of their thermoeconomic and thermohydrodynamics is insufficient to accommodate the needs of modern thermal storage design, which requires maximization in latent heat storage systems (LHS) and their minimization of convection in sensible heat storage systems (SHS). Title: Tensile response of titanium at reasonably high strain rates and temperatures
Source title: Materials Science and Technology Conference and Exhibition, MS and T'07 - "Exploring Structure, Processing, and Applications Across Multiple Materials Systems"
Affiliations: University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Quinlan, M.F., University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland; Phelan, P., University of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland
Abstract: The tensile behaviour of titanium is characterized for dynamic loading at moderately high strain rates (200 - 800/s) and temperatures (20C - 600C). This experimental work was carried out using energy stored in a flywheel to rapidly deform a tensile specimen. Specimen strain was measured across the specimen gauge length using two laser measurement systems. Load was measured using an in house built load cell that was dynamically calibrated in situ using strain rate insensitive aluminium alloys. Flywheel rotational velocity and specimen temperature were monitored using a magnetic pick-up and a probe thermocouple respectively. All machine control functions, including automatic data acquisition, were achieved using a P.C. based data acquisition system. Results presented here show the effect of temperature and strain rate on the ultimate tensile strength of titanium. They will also show the change in elongation of the specimens caused by an increase in strain rate. Conclusions that will be drawn from this research will be the effect of strain rate and temperature on the flow stress of the material. Copyright © 2007 MS&T'07®.

Authors: Borland M., Decker G., Nassiri A., Sun Y.-E., White M.
Title: Potential and challenges of upgrading the Advanced Photon Source to an Energy Recovery Linac
Source title: 8th International Topical Meeting on Nuclear Applications and Utilization of Accelerators, ACCAPP'07
Affiliations: Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439
Authors with affiliations: Borland, M., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439; Decker, G., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439; Nassiri, A., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439; Sun, Y.-E., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439; White, M., Argonne National Laboratory, 9700 South Cass Avenue, Argonne, IL 60439
Abstract: The Advanced Photon Source (APS) is a thirdgeneration synchrotron radiation source operating at 7 GeV that has been in operation for over 10 years. In that time, the emittance has been improved from 8 nm to the present value of 3.1 nm, which is close to the practical minimum. Recently, APS undertook an intensive exploration of potential upgrades, including options for a replacement storage ring or Energy Recovery Linac (ERL) injector. Our conclusion was that only the ERL would provide a dramatically new capability. This paper discusses the potential performance available from an ERL upgrade to the APS and reviews the challenges of delivering this performance.

Title: Interface engineering in the high-k dielectrics gate stacks
Source title: Materials Science and Technology Conference and Exhibition, MS and T'07 - "Exploring Structure, Processing, and Applications Across Multiple Materials Systems"
Affiliations: Institute of Material and Research Engineering, 3 Research Link, Singapore 117602, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Wang, S.J., Institute of Material and Research Engineering, 3 Research Link, Singapore 117602, Singapore
Abstract: The continual downscaling of semiconductor devices into the "nano" era requires not only the replacement of silicon dioxide (SiO2) gate dielectric by high dielectric constant (high-K) materials, but also that of polycrystalline Si (poly-Si) gate electrodes by metal gates. In order to integrate the metal gate material and the high-k dielectric with current semiconductor technology, it is essential to understand and control two interfaces at the atomic scale: the interface between metal gate and high-k dielectric and the interface between high-k dielectric and Si. Band alignments at the interfaces are the most important parameters for semiconductor interfaces. The transport properties in heterojunctions devices are controlled by the electronic band profiles at the interfaces, namely the valence and conduction band offsets. In this report, we will discuss the interface-related issues with high-k gate stacks and investigate how the atomicinterface structures affect the properties of metal gate/high-k dielectric/Si gate stacks, and how the macroscopic properties (e.g., band alignments) are related to the electronic structures at small length scale (e.g., interface bonding). Copyright © 2007 MS&T07®.

Title: Nanotechnology - Challenges and opportunities for the future
Affiliations: Ceramic and Composites Material Center, Rutgers University, New Jersey
Authors with affiliations: Haber, R.A., Ceramic and Composites Material Center, Rutgers University, New Jersey
Abstract: Nanotechnology encompasses a broad range of materials and processes on a sub-micron scale. Nanotechnology materials have been in use for many years. However, recent developments in synthesis by high temperature chemistry have yielded new material structures. These new material exhibit new and unexpected properties and behaviors. Adaptation of these structures is the key to taking advantage of these materials. Current nanotechnology applications cover areas of rheological control (aerogels), composite structures (grapheme sheets) and surface modification (transparent hydrophobic coatings). Future uses of nano-materials are envisioned in information storage in the gigabyte range, antibacterial and anti-fungal agents with surface active components, detoxification of contaminated clothing, fuel cells, catalyst with specific structures, energy storage of exceptionally high density such as hydrogen storage, and medical applications such as targeted drug delivery vehicles for tumors and viruses. The growth of nano-materials in many products is indicated to have impacts as significant as antibiotics, printed circuits and manmade polymer.

Title: Conversion of wet booths into dry booths
Affiliations: Herding Filtration, LLC
Authors with affiliations: Vanoplinus, C., Herding Filtration, LLC
Abstract: Trends in the entire industry segment, from the application process to the production of process materials, all commonly have to deal with filtration issues. With environmental issues as well as dealing with permits. worker exposure, waste and containment. Herding reviewed a number of case histories where Herding's unique media has been used to solve a multitude of these issues by either retrofitting clients existing plants or integrating the media into new booth and collection designs to address the issues. The porcelain industry, like other processing industries have also been challenged to reduce the large costs associated with energy and chemical or water usage. Trending towards the use of improved dry filtration solutions rather than expensive scrubber and wet booth technology, Herding's media can handle a wide range of collected streams at various load levels, and still fulfill an industry best clean exhaust emission result between 0.00004 and 0.0004 grains/cubic foot.

Abstract: Text Categorization is an important information processing task. This paper presents a neural approach to a text classifier based on the Learning Vector Quantization (LVQ) algorithm. We focus on multilabel multiclass text categorization. Experiments were carried out using the High Energy Physics (HEP) text collection. The HEP collection is an highly unbalanced collection. The results obtained are very promising and show that our neural approach based on the LVQ algorithm behaves robustly over different parameters.

Abstract: For enterprises to be able to use information technologies and communications with guarantees, it is necessary to have an adequate security management system. However, this requires that enterprises know in every moment their security maturity level and to what extend their information security system must evolve. Moreover, this security management system must have very reduced costs for its implementation and maintenance in small and mediumsize enterprises (from now on, SMEs) to be feasible. In this paper, we will put forward our proposal of a maturity model for security management in SMEs and we will briefly analyse other models that exist in the market. This approach is being directly applied to real cases, thus obtaining an improvement in its application.

Title: Drilling and blasting for underground space
Source title: Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy Publication Series
Affiliations: Coffey Mining Pty. Ltd., PO Box 2301, Newstead, QLD 4006
Authors with affiliations: Pesch, R., Coffey Mining Pty. Ltd., PO Box 2301, Newstead, QLD 4006; Robertson, A., Coffey Mining Pty. Ltd., PO Box 2301, Newstead, QLD 4006
Abstract: Australia has been slow in adopting the use of underground space as a part of our urban planning process. Australia has one of the highest levels of tunnel advance per capita per annum in the world, yet the use of underground space in our cities appears difficult for our planners and politicians to comprehend, not withstanding the general availability of good quality rock and contractor expertise in Australia. However, the lack of space in our urban areas is being highlighted as our major cities expand outwards and people and businesses gravitate towards city centres. Typical potential underground space uses include car parking, self-storage and archiving facilities, water storage, underground quarrying, small industrial facilities and another layer of traffic (electric and fuel cell) and services network. Historically, blasting in high density population areas has resulted in blast vibrations and blast overpressures exceeding the limits, which in some case have been set extremely low in terms of peak particle velocity (PPV). This makes conventional blasting difficult, often requiring low charge weights per delay and associated small blast sizes and slow advance rates. However, the introduction of new technologies, such as computer aided drilling, electronic delays and low-energy explosives has made this task considerably easier. Although more expensive than conventional blasting, excavation by blasting using these products and technologies in relatively good quality ground is believed, in most cases, to be less than the cost of mechanical excavation. In this paper, the authors look at innovative trends in underground quarrying, underground commercial space and tunnelling and put forward their concept of future excavation demand, future product requirements and technical specifications to the drill and blast community.

Affiliations: Dept. of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Pennsylvania; Arkema, Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Zestar-Postrk, J., Dept. of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Pennsylvania; O'Dwyer, S., Dept. of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Pennsylvania; Fioktistov, S., Dept. of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Pennsylvania; Churchill, S.W., Dept. of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Pennsylvania; Wismer, J., Arkema, Inc.
Abstract: Hydrogen may serve as a fuel in the sense of storage and transport but it is not a primary source of energy in that it does not occur naturally and must be generated by the electrolysis of water. A discussion on the production of pure hydrogen and pure CO2 from coal char covers the advantages and disadvantages of hydrogen as a fuel; concerns on the transportation an storage of hydrogen; use of hydrogen as a chemical agent or intermediate in chemical and petroleum processing; and the market for hydrogen as an automotive fuel. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the 2007 AIChE Annual Meeting (Salt Lake City, UT 11/4-9/2007).

Affiliations: Chemical Engineering Department, Middle East Technical University, Ankara 06531, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Uner, D., Chemical Engineering Department, Middle East Technical University, Ankara 06531, Turkey; Ergun, O., Chemical Engineering Department, Middle East Technical University, Ankara 06531, Turkey; Karslioglu, O., Chemical Engineering Department, Middle East Technical University, Ankara 06531, Turkey; Oymak, M.M., Chemical Engineering Department, Middle East Technical University, Ankara 06531, Turkey
Abstract: Solar energy driven reduction of CO2 in the gas phase is a natural phenomenon known as photosynthesis. As with many other natural processes, the simple process building blocks are combined in perfect complexity yielding marvelous outcomes. Photosynthesis translated into the photocatalytic processes are reviewed. The state of the art of the "storage of the solar energy in chemical bonds" around the world are presented. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the AIChE Annual Meeting (Salt Lake, UT 11/4-9/2007).

Authors: Irfansyah A.N., Lehmann T., Nooshabadi S.
Title: Energy optimization for current-mode signaling in high-speed on-chip interconnects
Source title: 2007 International Conference on Intelligent and Advanced Systems, ICIAS 2007
Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW 2052, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Irfansyah, A.N., School of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW 2052, Australia; Lehmann, T., School of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW 2052, Australia; Nooshabadi, S., School of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW 2052, Australia
Abstract: This paper studies the energy-optimization design methodology for current-mode (CM) signaling in high-speed on-chip interconnects, using the modified clamped bit-line sense amplifier circuit (MCBLSA) as a case study. Optimization for the CM circuits for on-chip interconnects requires a completely different treatment than the voltagemode circuits, due to the problems such as different effective driver resistance and termination resistance modeling. The methodology will be validated using SPICE simulations. It is shown that when dealing with receiver termination sizing, the optimal size is determined by the required voltage swing at the receiver end to guarantee valid operation under the effect of crosstalk noise. However, sizing the driver and receiver transistors should be done simultaneously as their resistive values which affect the performance are dependent on each other. ©2007 IEEE.
