Box 4400, FIN-02015 TKK, Finland; Zevenhoven, R., Heat Engineering Laboratory, Åbo Akademi University, Piispankatu 8, FIN-20500 Turku, Finland
Abstract: Abundant resources of magnesium silicates make an interesting prospect for long-term storage of CO2 by mineral carbonation. Several carbonation processes proposed in literature for CO2 storage employ extraction of silicate minerals using a liquid solvent. In this study, the dissolution of natural serpentinite in respective solutions of acids, bases and ammonium salts has been investigated. Experiments performed at room temperature showed that H2SO4 was most efficient at extracting magnesium from serpentinite, followed by HCl, HNO3, HCOOH and CH3COOH. Experiments for determining the dissolution kinetics was performed at temperatures of 30, 50 and 70 °C in 2 M solutions of H2SO4, HCl, and HNO3. At 70 °C temperatures all magnesium was extracted from serpentinite in each of the three acid solutions tested during 1-2 h. Also a large part of iron in serpentinite was extracted, while very little silicon dissolved (< 4%). The dissolution rate seemed to be limited by product layer diffusion for serpentinite particles with a size distribution of 74-125 μm. The apparent activation energies were 68 kJ mol- 1 for dissolution in H2SO4, 70 kJ mol- 1 for dissolution in HCl, and 74 kJ mol- 1 for dissolution in HNO3. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Extraction; Kinetics; Leaching; Mineral carbonation; Serpentine; Serpentinite
Index Keywords: Carbonation; Dissolution; Extraction; Kinetics; Leaching; Magnesium compounds; Mineral resources; Organic acids; Size distribution; Solvents; Magnesium silicates; Mineral carbonation; Serpentinite; Serpentine

Title: Transportation - Quick takes: Millennium gas pipeline project under way
Abstract: Millennium Pipeline Co LLC has started construction of its 182-mi, 30-in. natural gas pipeline across the Southern Tier and lower Hudson Valley areas of New York. The pipeline is expected to start service on 11/1/2008. It will serve markets along its route and will provide essential service to the New York City markets via its pipeline connections. Phase 1 will transport 500 million cu ft/day of gas from the Dawn, Ontario, trading hub and several supply and storage basins. It includes the upgrade of a 186-mi Corning-Ramapo, NY, pipeline section on Millennium, which will replace an existing line of Columbia Gas Transmission Corp, and an 83-mi extension of the 24-in. Empire system from a point near Rochester to Corning, NY. The Millennium Pipeline is owned by affiliates of NiSource Inc, KeySpan Corp, and DTE Energy.

Title: Transportation - Quick takes: Expansions planned for China's Zhoushan oil port
Abstract: China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) has approved an oil port and storage expansion project at Zhoushan port, Ningbo, in eastern China's Zhejiang province. According to NDRC, Zhejiang Jianqiao Energy Development Co Ltd will invest 325 million yuan to build the facility, which will include a 50,000-ton-capacity berth for oil products, a 5000-ton-capacity berth, and storage for 290,000 cu m. The port currently has a throughput capacity of 4 million ton/yr.

Authors: Zhaunerchyk V., Al-Khalili A., Thomas R.D., Geppert W.D., Bednarska V., Petrignani A., Ehlerding A., Hamberg M., Larsson M., Rosen S., Van Der Zande W.J.
Title: Rotational state effects in the dissociative recombination of H2+
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Albanova University Centre, Stockholm University, S106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Institute for Molecules and Materials, Radboud University Nijmegen, P.O. Box 9010, NL-6500 GL Nijmegen, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Zhaunerchyk, V., Department of Physics, Albanova University Centre, Stockholm University, S106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Al-Khalili, A., Department of Physics, Albanova University Centre, Stockholm University, S106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Thomas, R.D., Department of Physics, Albanova University Centre, Stockholm University, S106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Geppert, W.D., Department of Physics, Albanova University Centre, Stockholm University, S106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Bednarska, V., Institute for Molecules and Materials, Radboud University Nijmegen, P.O. Box 9010, NL-6500 GL Nijmegen, Netherlands; Petrignani, A., Institute for Molecules and Materials, Radboud University Nijmegen, P.O. Box 9010, NL-6500 GL Nijmegen, Netherlands; Ehlerding, A., Department of Physics, Albanova University Centre, Stockholm University, S106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Hamberg, M., Department of Physics, Albanova University Centre, Stockholm University, S106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Larsson, M., Department of Physics, Albanova University Centre, Stockholm University, S106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Rosen, S., Department of Physics, Albanova University Centre, Stockholm University, S106 91 Stockholm, Sweden; Van Der Zande, W.J., Institute for Molecules and Materials, Radboud University Nijmegen, P.O. Box 9010, NL-6500 GL Nijmegen, Netherlands
Abstract: We have studied the dissociative recombination (DR) of molecular hydrogen ions with slow electrons over a range of collision energies from 0 to 400 meV. By employing a pulsed expansion source for rotational cooling and by exploiting superelastic collisions with near-0-eV electrons in a heavy ion storage ring for vibrational cooling, we observe a highly structured DR cross section, comparable to that reported for HD+. Using para-hydrogen-enriched ion beams, we identify for the first time features in the DR cross sections attributed to ν=0, J=even molecules (para-H2) and ν=0, J=odd (ortho-H2) molecules, separately. Indications are given that para levels have different DR rate coefficients from ortho levels for the first four vibrational levels at near-0-eV collisions. © 2007 The American Physical Society.
Index Keywords: Electrons; Heavy ions; Hydrogen; Ion beams; Vibrational spectra; Collision energies; Pulsed expansion source; Rotational cooling; Superelastic collisions; Molecular dynamics

Title: More oil firms join Statoil's Mongstad carbon test center
Authors with affiliations: Dittrick, P.
Abstract: In planning a carbon capture and storage (CCS) test center at a combined heat and power station (CHP) being constructed at Statoil's 200,000b/cd Mongstad refinery, Hydro ASA, DONG Energy, Royal Dutch Shell PLC agreed to cooperate with Statoil ASA. The center will be run by a technology company consisting of a partnership of Statoil, the Norwegian government and the newly announced partners. The CHP station, expected to supply 280Mw of electricity and 250Mw of heat, the refinery will use some of the heat and electricity with the surplus electricity probably to be sold to Norwegian oil and gas operations. The center will be capable of testing more than one type of CO2 capture technology. The test center was developed to test and qualify carbon capture technology to help reduce costs and risks associated with large-scale carbon capture.
Index Keywords: Carbon; Costs; Petroleum industry; Petroleum refineries; Risk management; Societies and institutions; carbon dioxide; carbon sequestration; oil industry; Eurasia; Europe; Northern Europe; Norway; Scandinavia; Chandipura virus

Title: Government: FERC uses new penalty authority on gas companies
Abstract: Columbia Gulf Transmission paid the federal government a $2 million fine for refusing to allow Tennessee Gas Pipeline to build an interconnection at the Blue Water Project in Louisiana. The two companies own and operate Blue Water jointly. It is a major processing, storage, and transportation hub. Columbia is owned by NiSource, Tennessee by El Paso. Although it touted the fine as the third meted out to a natural gas company in 2007 under the FERC's new fine authority granted it in the 2005 Energy Policy Act, the $2 million total was far less than what FERC could have assessed. The 2005 law allows FERC to issue fines of $1 million/day. Columbia defied a direct FERC order for about 7 mo, or about 200 days. FERC used its new penalty authority to fine Bangor Gas $1 million and followed with a fine of $4.5 million to Calpine. In the Calpine case, the fine was part of a consent order agreed to by Calpine Energy Services LP (CES), which is in bankruptcy. The Commission found that CES violated Commission requirements when the company failed to hold title to 156.5 bcf of gas that CES transported on eight natural gas pipelines. CES' violations of the "shipper-must-have-title" requirement numbered in the thousands and varied in type, including the misuse of capacity held by Calpine affiliates to serve other affiliates, and improper movement of gas to storage and delivery of gas to other pipelines and markets.

Title: Government: Senate approves energy bill
Abstract: US Senator Dick Lugar praised the Senate 65-27 passage of an energy bill that focuses on new sources of energy and conservation to reduce US dependence on foreign oil. The bill includes major provisions initiated by Lugar, including incentives for flexible fuel cars, requirements for greater use of ethanol mixed with petroleum fuels and numerous provisions to promote energy efficiency. The legislation would increase auto fuel efficiency standards for the first time in > 20 yr. It includes a provision mandating automakers to produce flexible-fuel vehicles, which are able to run on E85 ethanol or regular gasoline. The bill includes a renewable fuel standard similar to the Biofuels Security Act, sponsored by Lugar and Senator Tom Harkin. Provisions include expanding loan guarantees for renewable fuel facilities, studies to improve flex fuel vehicles and ship biofuels by pipeline, and an assessment of CO2 storage capacity.

Title: LFSS: Using an extra RAM buffer for improving flash storage system performance
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, National Chiao Tung University, 1001 Ta-Hsueh Road, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering, National Cheng-Kung University, No. 1, Ta-Hsueh Road, Tainan, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Li, C.-H., Department of Computer Science, National Chiao Tung University, 1001 Ta-Hsueh Road, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Chang, D.-W., Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering, National Cheng-Kung University, No. 1, Ta-Hsueh Road, Tainan, Taiwan
Abstract: Erasing flash memory blocks is a time-consuming and energy-wasting operation. Moreover, the number of erase times is also limited. In this paper, we propose using ah extra RAM buffer as the extension of the flash memory to reduce the number of erase operations, and to prolong the flash lifetime. Based on the extra RAM buffer, we design and implement a flash storage system, called Log Flash Storage System (LFSS), which incorporates two techniques. One is a novel data clustering method, which allows the hot data usually be updated in the RAM buffer, reducing the chances of updating and erasing flash blocks. The other is a new data layout approach for the flash memory so as to reduce the system mount time. We implemented the LFSS as a Linux kernel module. According to the performance results, LFSS can eliminate 40%-90% of the erase operations when a 4Mbyte RAM buffer is used. In addition, it can also ensure even wearing.
Author Keywords: And even wearing; Cleaning clustering; Erase operations; Flash memory
Index Keywords: Buffer storage; Clustering algorithms; Data processing; Random access storage; Cleaning clustering; Erase operation; Log flash storage system; Flash memory

Title: Modeling and control of advanced propulsion systems
Source title: Oil and Gas Science and Technology
Affiliations: ETH Zurich, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Guzzella, L., ETH Zurich, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland
Abstract: Propulsion systems of modern road vehicles include several subsystems for energy conversion and storage. Such complex systems cannot be optimized for performance, fuel economy, and cost using "trial-and-error" approaches. Systematic optimizations must be performed using mathematical models that approximate the system's behavior on the appropriate precision level. This survey paper describes some of the most useful general ideas in this field and shows three examples of their application. Copyright © 2007, Institut français du pétrole.
Index Keywords: Energy conversion; Energy storage; Fuel economy; Mathematical models; Optimization; Advanced propulsion system; Land vehicle propulsion; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Fuel economy; Land vehicle propulsion; Mathematical models; Optimization; control system; energy use; engine; model; optimization; performance assessment; precision

Title: The offshore lifecycle
Affiliations: Sevan Marine and Rolf Gibbels of Dassault Systemes
Authors with affiliations: Smedal, T.E., Sevan Marine and Rolf Gibbels of Dassault Systemes
Abstract: Product lifecycle management (PLM) solutions, aided the design and construction of an innovative floating production, storage and offlanding (FPSO) vessel, from a conventional ship shaped design. The FPSO market landed the contract for a multinational oil platform project, to be manufactured by a Chinese shipyard for a Brazilian customer. The offshore industry opted for retrofitted oil tankers as storage and production facilities, but a shortage of tankers available for retrofitting brought a change in the FPSO market. The integration of the open architecture upon which PLM technology enables real time validation of the FPSO design against analysis requirements and construction processes, reduced revisions in energy market and ensured significant time gains for the company. The projects involve subcontractors using CAD systems, seamless collaboration and data exchange facilities, both within the PLM solution and CAD systems.

Title: DOE study confirms IGCC as the lowest cost coal-power alternative
Authors with affiliations: Jaeger, H.
Abstract: FutureGen, which is the strength of an international government and industry collaboration for advanced IGCC technology development, is going to announce the selection of gasification, gas turbine technology, and suppliers for a commercial scale 275MW demo plant to be built in Texas or Illinois around 2012. The main purpose of FutureGen is to increase IGCC plant output by reducing the construction and operating costs. The plan of the FutureGen is to design the plant for 90% carbon capture and permanent disposal of carbon dioxide by injection for enhanced oil recovery or for storage in geological formations. The investment costs for CO2 capture range from almost $600 per kW for the GE Energy plant to around $ 700 per kW for E-gas and shell. FutureGen is also running the research and development programs to improve the technology.

Authors: Konovalov I.N., Panchenko A.N., Tarasenko V.F., Tel'minov E.A.
Title: Wide-aperture electric-discharge nitrogen laser
Affiliations: Institute of High Current Electronics, Siberian Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, prosp. Akademicheskii 2/3, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Konovalov, I.N., Institute of High Current Electronics, Siberian Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, prosp. Akademicheskii 2/3, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation; Panchenko, A.N., Institute of High Current Electronics, Siberian Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, prosp. Akademicheskii 2/3, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation; Tarasenko, V.F., Institute of High Current Electronics, Siberian Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, prosp. Akademicheskii 2/3, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation; Tel'minov, E.A., Institute of High Current Electronics, Siberian Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, prosp. Akademicheskii 2/3, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The parameters of a wide-aperture nitrogen laser pumped by a generator with the inductive energy storage and a SOS diode opening switch or a generator with the capacitive energy storage are studied. The gas preionisation was performed by soft X-rays. The size of the active volume of the laser was 10 × 6 × 100 cm. The output energy and power obtained at the 337.1-nm C 3∏u - B 3∏g transition are maximal for electric-discharge nitrogen lasers. The output energy in the second positive system of nitrogen in the N2 - SF6 mixture achieved 110 mJ for a peak power of 6 MW. Due to an increase in voltage across the laser gap in nitrogen mixtures with NF3, the generation of ∼ 35-mJ, 100-ns pulses was obtained in the quasi-stationary stage of the discharge. ©2007 Kvantovaya Elektronika and Turpion Ltd.
Author Keywords: Inductive and capacitive energy storages; Maximum output energy and power; N2 - SF6 and N2 - NF3 mixtures; UV nitrogen laser
Index Keywords: Electric discharges; Electric energy storage; Electric generators; Electric potential; Nitrogen; Capacitive energy storages; Maximum output energy; UV nitrogen lasers; Pumping (laser)

Authors: Koshelev K.N., Banine V.E., Salashchenko N.N.
Title: Research and development in short-wave radiation sources for new-generation lithography
Affiliations: Institute of Spectroscopy, RAS, Troitsk, Moscow Region, Russian Federation; ASML, Veldhoven, Netherlands; Institute for the Physics of Microstructures, RAS, Nizhny Novgorod, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Koshelev, K.N., Institute of Spectroscopy, RAS, Troitsk, Moscow Region, Russian Federation; Banine, V.E., ASML, Veldhoven, Netherlands; Salashchenko, N.N., Institute for the Physics of Microstructures, RAS, Nizhny Novgorod, Russian Federation
Abstract: A short-wave radiation sources have been studied for a new-generation lithography, extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography. It is conventional to characterize the source by the electric energy-to-useful radiation conversion efficiency (CE). The effective size of the emitting volume should not exceed 1 mm 3 and the source operating frequency is about 10 kHz. The laser produced plasma as an EUV source offers several advantages over discharge plasmas, which include higher CE, higher radiation collection efficiency, and simpler system of optics protection from the destructive effect of corpuscular radiation. Research into axially symmetric discharges, such as vacuum sparks shows that soft X-ray and VUV radiation is excited in plasmas with currents exceeding 10 kA at the moment the sausage type instability develops in the discharge column. The plasma outflow from a pinch is accompanied by plasma compression, heating, and passage to progressively higher ionization stages.
Index Keywords: Corpuscular radiation; New-generation lithography; Plasma compression; Short-wave radiation; VUV radiation; Conversion efficiency; Electric energy storage; Extreme ultraviolet lithography; Ionization; Plasmas; Radiation; X rays; Lithography

Authors: Avdin V.V., Lymar A.A., Batist A.V., Nikitin E.A., Belkanova M.Yu., Potemkin V.A.
Title: Structure formation in heavy metal oxyhydrates at low rates of gel formation
Affiliations: South Urals State University, Chelyabinsk, Russian Federation; Chemical Faculty, Chelyabinsk State University, Chelyabinsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Avdin, V.V., South Urals State University, Chelyabinsk, Russian Federation; Lymar, A.A., South Urals State University, Chelyabinsk, Russian Federation; Batist, A.V., South Urals State University, Chelyabinsk, Russian Federation; Nikitin, E.A., South Urals State University, Chelyabinsk, Russian Federation; Belkanova, M.Yu., South Urals State University, Chelyabinsk, Russian Federation; Potemkin, V.A., Chemical Faculty, Chelyabinsk State University, Chelyabinsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: Oxyhydrate gels have a hydrophilic surface, due to which they undergo destruction and secondary polymerization in aqueous media. Prolonged storage in aqueous solution gives rise to regions with selfsimilar helical ordering in gels. Structuring of this kind is also observed when synthesis is conducted under conditions that provide low gelation rates. Electromagnetic UV and visible radiation is another means to change the gel structure; it makes the oligomer species pass into the excited state, due to which one of the directions of structuring becomes dominant. This work summarizes the results of computer simulation of gel agglomerates. For oxyhydrate systems, helical ordering was found to be one of the local energy minima. The units of a macrohelix can lie at various angles relative to one another, and they can change, after absorption of energy, the helix pitch and the order of elements in the helix. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
Author Keywords: Effects of UV and visible radiation; Heavy metal oxyhydrates; Helical ordering; Low rate of gel formation; Structure formation processes

Title: ZAP receives orders for 50,000 recharge-it-AII batteries
Authors with affiliations: Larkin, J.
Abstract: ZAP, alternative energy and transportation pioneer, has received orders for over 50,000 units of its Recharge-It-All line of rechargeable lithium battery storage devices. ZAP's Recharge-It-All line is a unique rechargeable battery system that can provide a portable power source for almost any kind of mobile electronic device, such as cell phones and laptops. Recharge-It-All can automatically sense and deliver the appropriate voltage for a range of power settings. ZAP launched the Recharge-It-All line at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, the world's largest mobile electronics and technology trade fair. ZAP's Recharge-It-All comes in several sizes depending the requirements, from the RX4-C Universal Battery Charger for $29.99 to power and recharge smaller electronics devices like cell phones and digital cameras. The Company has launched an advanced portable energy technology that manages power for mobile electronics from cell phones to laptops.
Index Keywords: Charging (batteries); Industrial economics; Industrial management; Laptop computers; Lithium batteries; Mobile phones; Battery Charger; Mobile electronics; Contracts

Title: Regenerative braking boosts GREEN credentials
Authors with affiliations: Ford, R.
Abstract: The railway operators in the UK are using regenerative braking systems such as traction motors to save energy and reduce maintenance costs of the break wheel wear. The regenerative braking includes the return of current to the overhead lines and the braking is dependent on the ability of other trains on the same route to accept the current. The DC electrical systems receptivity is improved by providing energy storage at substations with capacitors. The protective systems are linked to adjacent substations known as inter-tripping, to detect an earth fault in the supply. The regenerative braking returns electric power to the distribution grids while AC electrification provides unlimited receptivity allowing electric braking to be the normal operational mode. Regenerative braking allows energy recovery and reduce brake wear by a proper interface between traction equipment and brakes.

Title: EU-OPEC Energy Dialogue witnesses 'significant' developments
Authors with affiliations: Haylins, J.
Abstract: In the 4th Ministerial Meeting of the EU-OPEC Energy Dialogue, which was held in Vienna on 6/21/2007, two sessions were held with several presentations. Presented during the sessions include EU's new policies concerning energy and climate change by Heinz Hilbrecht, Director for Conventional Energies at the European Commission; oil market developments in the near term by Dr. Hasan M. Qabazard, Director of its Research Division; status of the Energy Dialogue's joint activities; roundtable on carbon capture and storage by Mohamed Hamel, Head of the Secretariat's Energy Studies Department; and roundtable on energy policies by Jean-Arnold Vinois. Specific joint actions were also agreed such as a workshop on the oil refining sector, including the implications of biofuels, to take place in Brussels at the end of 2007 or early in 2008.

Title: Security of oil demand equally as important as security of supply
Abstract: Secure oil demand is as important to oil producers as secure supply is to the consumers. This was one of the issues discussed by OPEC at a joint Roundtable on Energy Policies with the European Union (EU), held in Brussels, Belgium, at the end of May 2007. Dr Hasan M. Qabazard, Director of OPEC's Research Division, also discussed other oil market issues, including the disturbing impact of uncertainties on investment; potential benefits for the industry at large of energy efficiency and conservation; the need to accommodate environmental protection in the energy profiles, such as carbon capture and storage; shortage of skilled labor; and the need to ensure that the international oil industry develops in a way that accommodates the pressing needs of sustainable development and the eradication of poverty.

Title: Storage and transportation opportunities of hydrogen
Source title: Energy Sources, Part B: Economics, Planning and Policy
Affiliations: Sila Science, Universite Mahallesi, Trabzon, Turkey; Sila Science, Universite Mahallesi, Akif Saruhan Caddesi, Mekan Sokak No: 24, Trabzon, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Demirbas, A., Sila Science, Universite Mahallesi, Trabzon, Turkey, Sila Science, Universite Mahallesi, Akif Saruhan Caddesi, Mekan Sokak No: 24, Trabzon, Turkey
Abstract: There are a few different approaches for hydrogen transportation and storage. Hydrogen can be stored as a compressed gas, as a liquid (at 20 K), and in solid state compounds. The first two methods are established technologies with several limitations, the most important being their energy intensive character. Hydrogen storage in metal hydrides is considered one of the most attractive methods. While hydrogen has many obvious advantages, there remains a problem with storage and transportation. Hydrides reduce the risk factors of gaseous or liquid hydrogen. The metal hydrides provide a safe method for fuel storage in hydrogen-powered vehicles. LiBH4 is a complex hydride which consists of 18% mass of hydrogen. Therefore, there are many reasons why hydrogen-storage materials, for example LiBH4, will be used in the future at many ranges. Hydride formation, reaction (absorption and/or chemisorption) between metal (M) and hydrogen (H2) is: M + nH2 [image omitted] MH2n+ Q.
Author Keywords: Hydrogen; Metal hydride; Storage; Transportation
Index Keywords: Chemisorption; Fuel storage; Hydrides; Hydrogen storage alloys; Transportation; Hydrogen transportation; Liquid hydrogen; Metal hydrides; Hydrogen storage

Title: The current status and future opportunities of hydroelectricity
Source title: Energy Sources, Part B: Economics, Planning and Policy
Affiliations: Civil Engineering Department, Anadolu University, Eskisehir, Turkey; Department of Civil Engineering, Faculty of Engineering and Architecture, Anadolu University, Eskisehir, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Bakis, R., Civil Engineering Department, Anadolu University, Eskisehir, Turkey, Department of Civil Engineering, Faculty of Engineering and Architecture, Anadolu University, Eskisehir, Turkey
Abstract: This study presents the status of and prospects for the current state of small hydropower technologies used to produce electricity and assesses their future prospects. The hydropower currently provides about 20% of the world's electricity supply and more than 40% of the electricity used in developing countries. Norway produces more than 99% of its electricity with hydropower. The hydropower is the leading source of renewable energy, providing more than 97% of all electricity generated by renewable sources. The chief advantage of hydro systems is elimination of the cost of fuel. Hydropower on a small-scale is in most cases "run-of-river," with no dam or water storage, and is one of the most cost-effective and environmentally benign energy technologies to be considered both for rural electrification in less developed countries and further hydro developments in Europe.
Author Keywords: Electricity market; Generation; Hydroelectricity; Hydropower; Small hydropower
Index Keywords: Electric industry; Electric loads; Electric power generation; Hydroelectric power plants; Renewable energy resources; Electricity market; Renewable energy; Small hydropower technologies; Water storage; Hydroelectric power

Authors: Bratfos H.A., Leinum B.H., Torbergsen L.E., Saugerud O.T.
Title: Challenges to the pipeline transportation of dense CO2
Affiliations: Det Norske Veritas, Hovik, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Bratfos, H.A., Det Norske Veritas, Hovik, Norway; Leinum, B.H., Det Norske Veritas, Hovik, Norway; Torbergsen, L.E., Det Norske Veritas, Hovik, Norway; Saugerud, O.T., Det Norske Veritas, Hovik, Norway
Abstract: OVER THE past decade, the prospect of climate change resulting from anthropogenic CO2 emissions to the atmosphere has become a matter of growing political and public concern. To achieve the global goals of reduction in CO2 emissions, carbon capture and storage (CCS) has been introduced as one of the most promising methods. One of the initiatives in this direction is the Norwegian government's decision to capture CO2 at the Kårstø gas power plant for permanent storage in a subsea aquifer in the North Sea. While both the capture and the storage issues have got considerable attention in the debate of how to realize CCS, the transportation has been regarded as fairly trivial. There are, however, several important technical issues to be resolved related to pipeline transport of dense CO2, and some of these are highlighted in DNV's report to the Norwegian Water Resources and Energy Directorate (NVE) as input to their feasibility study of the Karstø CCS concept. Such issues are limitation of gas humidity to avoid corrosion of C-Mn steel pipes, severity of accidental entrance of wet gas, toughness requirements to ensure fracture arrest properties under a release of dense CO2, corrosivity of reproduced CO2 from enhanced oil recovery (EOR) reservoirs, and procedures for requalification of oil and gas pipelines for transport of dense CO2.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Corrosion; Gas fuel storage; Gas pipelines; Toughness; Carbon capture and storage (CCS); Enhanced oil recovery (EOR); Requalification; Gas supply

Authors: Winkelhausen E., Jovanovic-Malinovska R., Velickova E., Kuzmanova S.
Title: Sensory and Microbiological Quality of a Baked Product Containing Xylitol as an Alternative Sweetener
Affiliations: University Ss.Cyril and Methodius, Faculty of Technology and Metallurgy, Skopje, North Macedonia; University Ss.Cyril and Methodius, Faculty of Technology and Metallurgy, Rudjer Boskovic 16, 1000 Skopje, North Macedonia
Authors with affiliations: Winkelhausen, E., University Ss.Cyril and Methodius, Faculty of Technology and Metallurgy, Skopje, North Macedonia, University Ss.Cyril and Methodius, Faculty of Technology and Metallurgy, Rudjer Boskovic 16, 1000 Skopje, North Macedonia; Jovanovic-Malinovska, R., University Ss.Cyril and Methodius, Faculty of Technology and Metallurgy, Skopje, North Macedonia; Velickova, E., University Ss.Cyril and Methodius, Faculty of Technology and Metallurgy, Skopje, North Macedonia; Kuzmanova, S., University Ss.Cyril and Methodius, Faculty of Technology and Metallurgy, Skopje, North Macedonia
Abstract: The potential application of xylitol, as low energy alternative sweetener, was investigated in baked products. Xylitol was used as sole sweetener in home made cookies, the properties of which were compared to products containing sucrose and glucose. The sensory properties were evaluated by discrimination, descriptive, and affective tests. The storage time of one and two weeks, both at 4-6C and at 20-22C did not show significant impact on the flavor and texture properties of all cookies. After being stored for 3 months at 20-22C, the samples with sucrose showed statistically significant differences in crunchiness (P 0.001) and tenderness (P 0.01). The cookies prepared with xylitol, apart from significantly reducing the aftertaste (P 0.001), did not exhibit any other significant changes. Statistically significant differences (P 0.001) were detected between the samples containing sucrose and xylitol in all texture attributes and in the cooling effect, but no difference in the sweetness was observed. The most chosen categories on the hedonic scale for the xylitol cookies were "like slightly" and "like moderately," while the extreme categories were not ascribed. Compared to the cookies with sucrose and glucose, xylitol cookies had least microbial loads at different storage and temperature regimes and were microbiologically safe with tendency to have longer shelf-life than the other products.
Author Keywords: Alternative sweetener; Baked product; Glucose; Microbiological analysis; Sensory quality; Sucrose; Xylitol
Index Keywords: Food storage; Microbiology; Sensory perception; Statistical methods; Alternative sweetener; Baked product; Microbiological analysis; Sensory quality; Xylitol; Food additives

Title: News: BP axes UK carbon project
Abstract: The Scottish Government's slowness in deciding on how to support carbon capture and storage (CCS) projects in the UK forced BP to cancel its planned hydrogen energy project at Peterhead, Scotland. Due to go into commercial operation around 2011, the project in the North Sea Miller oilfield involved using natural gas feedstock to generate some 475 Mw of electricity and capturing and storing some 1.8 million tons/yr of CO2. Injection of the CO2 into the oilfield was also expected to increase recovery of oil from the reservoir by an estimated 50-60 million bbl. The termination of the Peterhead project coincided with BP's formation of the Hydrogen Energy venture with mining group Rio Tinto. The company will focus on hydrogen-fueled power generation, using fossil fuels and CCS technology to produce electricity. The new company will take over BP's other hydrogen-fuelled power project in Carson, CA - a planned 500 Mw power project alongside BP's Carson refinery, near Los Angeles, which will capture some 4 million ton/yr of CO2 and transport it for reinjection into geological formations in southern California.

Title: Business: Analysis: Process plans unlimited
Authors with affiliations: Raleigh, P.
Abstract: A discussion covers the technologies and commercial trends behind the current wave of investment in new process facilities in the Middle East, China, and other global regions; Middle East nations' efforts to diversify into speciality chemicals, engineering polymers, etc.; Foster Wheeler Energy Ltd's focus on the upstream oil and gas, LNG, petrochemicals, refining, and pharmaceutical sectors, as well as emerging markets (carbon capture and storage); Foster Wheeler projects, e.g., the SevenPlus FEED for construction of two 8500 kton/yr NGL trains, the Browse gasfield study fro LNG development, and the Manifa Arabian Heavy Crude project, which will add 900,000 bpd of crude oil to Aramco's production; the development of the world's first industrial-scale project to generate electricity using hydrogen manufactured from natural gas to create decarbonated fuels; and other activities in the refining industry.

Title: News: Skills in short supply
Abstract: A Doosan Babcock poll of 500 senior corporate executives, energy analysts, MP and academics has found that industry skills shortages will seriously impact on the UK'S ability to implement the recommendations of the recent Energy White Paper. The findings of the Energy Pulse survey indicated that most leading energy experts (87%) believe the UK energy industry is facing a serious skills shortage, which is likely to hamper the drive to a low-carbon economy. The Energy White Paper discussed issues such as security of supply and the potential energy gap, but there is clearly an increasing unease amongst energy experts about the ability of the industry to implement all the investment required. Six out of ten (62%) Energy Pulse respondents believe clean coal with CO2 capture and storage, nuclear energy, and a balanced portfolio are likely to make the most impact to solve the UK'S energy gap. Over half (56%) said nuclear energy has a substantial part to play in meeting the shortfall.

Authors: Alekseev P.N., Alekseev N.N., Zavodov V.P., Mil'yachenko A.D.
Title: Adiabatic trapping and acceleration of the beam in the booster synchrotron of the ITEP-TWAC accelerating-storage facility
Affiliations: Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, ul. Bol'shaya Cheremushkinskaya 25, Moscow 117218, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Alekseev, P.N., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, ul. Bol'shaya Cheremushkinskaya 25, Moscow 117218, Russian Federation; Alekseev, N.N., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, ul. Bol'shaya Cheremushkinskaya 25, Moscow 117218, Russian Federation; Zavodov, V.P., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, ul. Bol'shaya Cheremushkinskaya 25, Moscow 117218, Russian Federation; Mil'yachenko, A.D., Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics, ul. Bol'shaya Cheremushkinskaya 25, Moscow 117218, Russian Federation
Abstract: A system for adiabatic trapping of injected particles into the acceleration mode was developed and used to increase the intensity of the ion beam accelerated in the booster synchrotron of the ITEP-TWAC accelerating-storage facility at the Institute for Theoretical and Experimental Physics. Using numerical simulation, the parameters of the injected beam were optimized and the conditions for the absence of particle loss upon a changeover into the acceleration mode and subsequent acceleration to the maximum energy were determined. The effect that the characteristics of a system controlling the radio frequency of the accelerating field had on the dynamics of synchrotron motion and the particle loss was investigated. During development and adjustment of a complex of equipment that provided optimal conditions for adiabatic trapping and acceleration of C4+ ions with an initial energy of 1.3 MeV/amu, the trapping efficiency was as high as 80%, being limited only by the initial distribution of the momentum spread in the injected beam. © 2007 Pleiades Publishing, Ltd.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Momentum; Synchrotrons; Adiabatic trapping; Particle loss; Synchrotron motion; Trapping efficiency; Particle beams

Authors: Barros J.R.P., Melo A.C.G., Leite Da Silva A.M.
Title: An approach to the explicit consideration of unreliability costs in transmission expansion planning
Affiliations: Hydro Electric Company of São Francisco, CHESF, Recife, Brazil; Electric Power Research Center, CEPEL, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil; Power System Unit, INESC Porto, Portugal; Institute of Electrical Engineering, Federal University of Itajubá (UNIFEI), Minas Gerais, Brazil; UNIFEI, Brazil; Rio de Janeiro State University, UERJ, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Barros, J.R.P., Hydro Electric Company of São Francisco, CHESF, Recife, Brazil; Melo, A.C.G., Electric Power Research Center, CEPEL, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Rio de Janeiro State University, UERJ, Brazil; Leite Da Silva, A.M., Power System Unit, INESC Porto, Portugal, Institute of Electrical Engineering, Federal University of Itajubá (UNIFEI), Minas Gerais, Brazil, UNIFEI, Brazil
Abstract: This paper proposes a new methodology to explicitly consider unreliability costs in a multi-stage transmission expansion planning. Starting from a reference plan, alternative expansion plans are derived based on postponement/anticipation of circuit implementations. These plans are then ranked by using an economic index of merit (EIM) and the associated Pareto-optimal set is obtained through cost/benefit (trade-off) analyses. The cost/benefit is related to the variation of investments and operational costs of each alternative transmission plan. Besides the usual operational costs (active power losses, fuels, etc.) the unreliability costs, due to random failures in the system, are also considered as operational costs. Therefore, reliability evaluations are carried out for all transmission expansion plans (TEPs) in order to compute reliability indices, such as the Expect Energy not Supplied and Loss of Load Cost (LOLC). To reduce the computational effort, pruning techniques are used to limit the number of possible TEPs. The proposed approach is applied to a configuration of the Brazilian North-eastern system, considering a planning horizon of 10 years, to identify TEPs that are more balanced in terms of investment and reliability. Copyright © 2007 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
Author Keywords: Probabilistic methods; Reliability worth; Trade-off analysis; Transmission expansion planning
Index Keywords: Costs; Failure modes; Industrial economics; Probability; Random access storage; Reliability theory; Economic index of merit (EIM); Probabilistic methods; Trade-off analysis; Transmission expansion planning; Electric power transmission

Authors: Baev V.P., Buyanov Yu.L., Veselovsky A.S.
Title: A superconducting magnetic-energy storage system as a source of high-power current pulses with constant amplitude
Affiliations: Joint Institute for High Temperatures, Russian Academy of Sciences, ul. Izhorskaya 13/19, Moscow 127412, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Baev, V.P., Joint Institute for High Temperatures, Russian Academy of Sciences, ul. Izhorskaya 13/19, Moscow 127412, Russian Federation; Buyanov, Yu.L., Joint Institute for High Temperatures, Russian Academy of Sciences, ul. Izhorskaya 13/19, Moscow 127412, Russian Federation; Veselovsky, A.S., Joint Institute for High Temperatures, Russian Academy of Sciences, ul. Izhorskaya 13/19, Moscow 127412, Russian Federation
Abstract: A facility is described that allows generation of long current pulses with a virtually constant amplitude by a superconducting inductive (magnetic) energy storage with a 5-MJ energy content. The design of this facility ensures the possibility of changing the parameters of an output current pulse by varying the inductances of the magnetic-system's sections and their electromagnet coupling. This approach allows not only the stabilization of the current pulse but also a severalfold increase in the initial current value. The electric insulation of the storage's coil can withstand a voltage higher than 200 kV, and a special system of multielectrode current leads can transfer a power of up to 250 MW at a 1.3-kA current from the cold zone (4.2 K) into the warm (300 K) zone almost without energy losses. The current can be increased to 10 kA by changing the connection of the facility's sections. The facility has been tested in six full-scale experiments and is ready for further tests as a component of electrophysical facilities of various purposes. © 2007 Pleiades Publishing, Ltd.
Index Keywords: Electric insulation; Electromagnetic coupling; Energy dissipation; Current pulses; Multielectrode current; Energy storage

Title: Phenomenology of the double-layer capacitor (Supercapacitor)
Authors with affiliations: Salem, R.R.
Abstract: The main specialties and properties of a double-layer capacitor as an electric-energy accumulator, based on the fundamental principles of electrodynamics and quantum statistics, is discussed. The electric double layer at the metal-environment is formed because the wave function of the metal electrons extend outside the visible surface and its amplitude decreases slowly. The charges at the inner and outer plates are equal and opposite in sign due to the absence of an external field. The electric energy stored in the capacitor, which is filled with a dielectric, is determined is by the molecular parameters of the environment and the intensity of the external field. The electric field intensity at the planar interface between two phases is obtained by free and bound charges. The field near the surface of capacitor is determined by the liquid in contact with the metal and temperature. The capacitance of a dipolar double layer is derived by the number of particles and their dipole moments.
Index Keywords: Electric dipole moments; Electric energy storage; Electric fields; Electrodynamics; Electrons; Wave functions; Phenomenology; Quantum statistics; Capacitors

Title: Air-cooled chiller with 'free cooling' looks to be right buy for best buy: Unit to save an estimated $18,720 a year in energy costs
Abstract: The MLC-FC 450 chiller from Motivair installed at the Best Buy store at Walden Galleria Mall, are expected to save approximately $18,720 a year, at a power cost of 8 cents per kilowatt-hour, compared with the costs associated with a standard winter chiller. Motivair free-cooling chillers can produce 50 percent free cooling at ambient temperatures approximately 10°F below design chilled-water temperatures or 100-percent free cooling at about 20°F below chilled-water supply temperatures. These chillers supply 42°F chilled glycol at a rate of 320 gpm to several variable-air-volume air handlers year-around through an integral pump and storage tank. Chillers provide effectively free cooling by eliminating winter compressor operation, saving about 85% of the power cost usually associated with mechanical cooling during the coldest periods.

Title: Uniform fatty acid mobilization from anatomically distinct fat depots in the sable (Martes zibellina)
Affiliations: Faculty of Biosciences, University of Joensuu, P.O. Box 111, 80101 Joensuu, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Nieminen, P., Faculty of Biosciences, University of Joensuu, P.O. Box 111, 80101 Joensuu, Finland; Mustonen, A.-M., Faculty of Biosciences, University of Joensuu, P.O. Box 111, 80101 Joensuu, Finland
Abstract: The mobilization of fatty acids (FA) is a selective process in humans, rodents and the few previously studied carnivores. The FA composition of and mobilization from different fat depots reflect the functions of adipose tissues, e.g. in energy storage or insulation. Sixteen farm-raised sables (Martes zibellina), a terrestrial mustelid, were assigned into a fed control group or fasted for 4 days. The FA composition of the sable was relatively similar to other previously studied mustelids. The masses of the different fat depots decreased by 28-55% during fasting. The subcutaneous (sc) and intraabdominal (iab) fats had a uniform FA composition and the sable could mobilize both sc and iab FA. 18:3n-3, 18:4n-3 and 16:1n-7 were effectively mobilized, while long-chain saturated (SFA) and monounsaturated FA (MUFA) increased in proportion. Relative mobilization (RM) correlated inversely with the FA chain length and A9-desaturation increased RM of several MUFA compared to SFA. The results reinforce the hypothesis that the terrestrial sable can utilize sc and iab fat depots as energy reserves during nutritional scarcity. The natural history of the species is an important determinant of the FA composition and RM between anatomically different fat depots. © AOCS 2007.
Author Keywords: Fasting; Fatty acids; Martes zibellina; Sable; White adipose tissue

Title: ARPA-E heads to house floor
Affiliations: Federation of Materials Societies
Authors with affiliations: Houston, B., Federation of Materials Societies
Abstract: The House Science & Technology Committee has proposed a bill to establish an Advanced Research Projects Agency Energy (ARPA-E). ARPA-E is intended to foster research in fossil energy, carbon sequestration, nuclear energy, renewable energy, energy distribution and energy efficiency. The bill would create a research, development, and demonstration program for advanced biofuel technologies, organize a basic and applied research program for energy storage solutions, and develop advanced vehicle technologies. The House has passed a Department of Defense (DoD) authorization bill calling for $503.8 billion in spending in FY 2008. The House also passed a bill sponsored by Rep. Rush Holt to establish a national database on financial assistance for the study of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).

Authors: Majdi A., Soltani A.S., Litkouhi S.
Title: Mitigation of liquefaction hazard by dynamic compaction
Affiliations: Department of Mining Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Tehran, Iran; Soils Engineering Services, Consulting Engineers, Tehran, Iran
Authors with affiliations: Majdi, A., Department of Mining Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Tehran, Iran; Soltani, A.S., Soils Engineering Services, Consulting Engineers, Tehran, Iran; Litkouhi, S., Soils Engineering Services, Consulting Engineers, Tehran, Iran
Abstract: The tendency to apply soil improvement techniques in comparison with conventional remedial methods has been widely increasing in Iran, especially over the past decade. This is because these techniques are less time-consuming and more cost-effective. The risk of liquefaction at the Caspian Sea Republics Oil Swap (CROS) project site for loose saturated sandy layers down to 13 m was revealed subsequent to completion of the geotechnical investigations. Following a detailed study, dynamic compaction was selected to be the best option, especially for the foundations of the nine oil tanks at the site. To determine the dynamic compaction pattern, including the optimum number of drops, total energy and height of drop, a detailed trial programme was carried out. This included drilling boreholes, cone penetration test and standard penetraiton test performance and trial tamping as well as heave tests. The results were quite satisfactory, and the liquefaction hazard was well mitigated. Because of the lack of time, no ageing effect was investigated.
Author Keywords: Dynamic compaction; Liquefaction

Authors: Popovic V., Doknic M., Maric N., Pekic S., Damjanovic A., Miljic D., Popovic S., Miljic N., Djurovic M., Jasovic-Gasic M., Dieguez C., Casanueva F.F.
Title: Changes in neuroendocrine and metabolic hormones induced by atypical antipsychotics in normal-weight patients with schizophrenia
Affiliations: Institute for Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolic Diseases, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Institute for Psychiatry, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, Complejo Hospitalario Universitario de Santiago, Santiago de Compostela, Spain; Department of Medicine, School of Medicine, Complejo Hospitalario Universitario de Santiago, Santiago de Compostela, Spain; Neuroendocrine Unit, Institute for Endocrinology, University Clinical Center, Dr Subotic 13, YU-11000 Belgrade, Serbia
Authors with affiliations: Popovic, V., Institute for Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolic Diseases, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia, Neuroendocrine Unit, Institute for Endocrinology, University Clinical Center, Dr Subotic 13, YU-11000 Belgrade, Serbia; Doknic, M., Institute for Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolic Diseases, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Maric, N., Institute for Psychiatry, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Pekic, S., Institute for Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolic Diseases, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Damjanovic, A., Institute for Psychiatry, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Miljic, D., Institute for Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolic Diseases, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Popovic, S., Institute for Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolic Diseases, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Miljic, N., Institute for Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolic Diseases, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Djurovic, M., Institute for Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolic Diseases, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Jasovic-Gasic, M., Institute for Psychiatry, University Clinical Center Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; Dieguez, C., Department of Physiology, School of Medicine, Complejo Hospitalario Universitario de Santiago, Santiago de Compostela, Spain; Casanueva, F.F., Department of Medicine, School of Medicine, Complejo Hospitalario Universitario de Santiago, Santiago de Compostela, Spain
Abstract: Context: Atypical antipsychotics (SGA) have the propensity to induce weight gain. Objective: The aim was to evaluateearly changes in hormones involved in neuroendocrine regulations (serum cortisol, growth hormone and prolactin) and positive energy balance (serum insulin, leptin and ghrelin) during SGA treatment in normal-weight patients with schizophrenia with the purpose of exploring the possibility to combat weight gain early through manipulation of circulating hormone levels. Design: We conducted a randomized, partly cross-sectional and partly longitudinal, prospective study. Setting and Patients: Eighteen normal-weight in-patients with schizophrenia treated with FGA (first-generation antipsychotics) were referred to the Institute of Psychiatry. Twenty age-, gender- and BMI-matched healthy subjects were investigated at the Neuroendocrine Unit, Belgrade University. Intervention: Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) was performed at baseline in all and then 13 patients were assigned to receive SGA (risperidone or clozapine) and OGTT was repeated after 1 and 3 months. Results: At baseline, patients with schizophrenia had higher peak glucose levels (p < 0.05), glucose area under the curve (AUC; p < 0.05), peak insulin levels (p < 0.05), insulin AUC values during OGTT (p < 0.01) and the calculated homeostasis model assessment (HOMA-IR) value than control subjects (p < 0.05). Patients with schizophrenia showed higher morning cortisol (p < 0.05) levels than control subjects. After 1 and 3 months of SGA therapy patients with schizophrenia gained bodyweight by 3.5 and 8.6%, respectively. Leptin levels steadily increased while cortisol levels decreased in the first month and remained so. Serum glucose, insulin and ghrelin levels on SGA were similar as at baseline. Circulating ghrelin levels decreased after OGTT during SGA which is consistent with a role for ghrelin in the initiation of meals. Conclusions: Treatment with SGA was associated with continuous weight gain, with an early increase in serum leptin levels and decrease in cortisol levels. Elevated circulating leptin was ineffective in the control of fat deposition. Similar plasma ghrelin levels and similar decrease pattern of ghrelin after OGTT compared to healthy subjects signify intact meal-promoting effects of ghrelin during SGA therapy, which at the same time renders anorexigenic pathways ineffective. This may lead to weight gain and further studies with a ghrelin antagonist may provide support for this hypothesis. Copyright © 2007 S. Karger AG.
Author Keywords: Antipsychotics; Cortisol; Ghrelin; Growth hormone; Insulin; Leptin; Weight gain

Authors: Jia X., Ekman M., Grove H., Færgestad E.M., Aass L., Hildrum K.I., Hollung K.
Title: Proteome changes in bovine longissimus thoracis muscle during the early postmortem storage period
Affiliations: Matforsk AS, Norwegian Food Research Institute, Osloveien 1, N-1430 Ås, Norway; Department of Chemistry, Biotechnology and Food Science, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, N-1432 Ås, Norway; Department of Animal and Aquacultural Sciences, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, P.O. Authors with affiliations: Jia, X., Matforsk AS, Norwegian Food Research Institute, Osloveien 1, N-1430 Ås, Norway, Department of Chemistry, Biotechnology and Food Science, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, N-1432 Ås, Norway; Ekman, M., Matforsk AS, Norwegian Food Research Institute, Osloveien 1, N-1430 Ås, Norway; Grove, H., Matforsk AS, Norwegian Food Research Institute, Osloveien 1, N-1430 Ås, Norway, Department of Chemistry, Biotechnology and Food Science, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, N-1432 Ås, Norway; Færgestad, E.M., Matforsk AS, Norwegian Food Research Institute, Osloveien 1, N-1430 Ås, Norway; Aass, L., Department of Animal and Aquacultural Sciences, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, P.O. Box 5003, N-1432 Ås, Norway; Hildrum, K.I., Matforsk AS, Norwegian Food Research Institute, Osloveien 1, N-1430 Ås, Norway; Hollung, K., Matforsk AS, Norwegian Food Research Institute, Osloveien 1, N-1430 Ås, Norway
Abstract: Postmortem changes in protein composition up to 24 h in bovine longissimus thoracis muscle were investigated by two-dimensional gel electrophoresis and MALDI-TOF MS/MS. A total of 47 spots were significantly changed the first 24 h postmortem. The 39 identified proteins can be divided into five groups: metabolic enzymes, defense and stress proteins, structural proteins, proteolytic enzymes, and unclassified proteins. The identified metabolic enzymes are all associated with ATP-generating pathways, either the glycolytic pathway or energy metabolism. In addition, several defense and stress proteins were changed in abundance in this study. These findings contribute to a better understanding of the biochemical processes during postmortem storage of meat. © 2007 American Chemical Society.

Title: News: Downstream: Clean coal project planned in Australia
Abstract: BP and Rio Tinto are beginning feasibility studies and work on plans for the potential development of a $1.5 billion coal-fired power generation project in Western Australia. This will be the first new project for Hydrogen Energy, the new company recently launched by BP and Rio Tinto, subject to regulatory approval. The project would be fully integrated with carbon capture and storage to reduce its emissions of greenhouse gases. The project's gasification facility and power station would be located in Kwinana, alongside BP's refinery and Rio Tinto's Hlsmelt facility, gasifying locally-produced coal from the Collie region to produce hydrogen and CO2. The power plant, which would be fueled by H2, would be capable of producing 500 Mw of low-carbon electricity. Subject to the successful outcome of detailed engineering and commercial studies, and providing government policy is in place to make the project commercially viable, a final investment decision to develop the project could be made in 2011, with the project coming into operation after a 3-yr construction period.

Title: Taking energy from waste without the carbon
Authors with affiliations: Butterworth, B.
Abstract: The process of extracting energy from waste harms the environment as it undergoes burning which produces carbon dioxide. Hence, it is therefore necessary to take energy from waste without burning or without releasing more greenhouse gases. Now, there is a technology that locks up the carbon which uses photosynthetic carbon capture and storage (PCCS) to produce liquid biofuels. This in turn compost wastes and use the nutrients in the compost ot grow crops. And if these crops are oil seeds, it can then produce biodiesel and bioheating oils, while if the crops use wheat or maize, the fuel can be bioethanol. The use of mechanical and biological sterilization (MBS) is prefered as it produces safe materials that can be recycled to produce energy crops. Overall, though this is not the final solution, sustainability can still be achieved through continuous practice of environmental friendly processes.
Index Keywords: biofuel; carbon dioxide; carbon sequestration; composting; energy resource; recycling; sustainability; waste management; Triticum aestivum; Zea mays

Authors: Cosemans S., Dehaene W., Catthoor F.
Title: A low-power embedded SRAM for wireless applications
Affiliations: IEEE, Belgium; ESAT-MICAS Laboratory, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; IMEC-DESICS, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Cosemans, S., IEEE, Belgium, ESAT-MICAS Laboratory, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Dehaene, W., IEEE, Belgium, ESAT-MICAS Laboratory, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Catthoor, F., IEEE, Belgium, IMEC-DESICS, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: This paper introduces a novel ultra-low-power SRAM. A large power reduction is obtained by the use of four new techniques that allow for a wider and better trade-off between area, delay and active and passive energy consumption for low-power embedded SRAMs. The design targets wireless applications that require a moderate performance at an ultra-low-power consumption. The implemented design techniques consist of a more efficient memory databus, the exploitation of the dynamic read stability of SRAM cells, a new low-swing write technique and a distributed decoder. An 8-KB 5T SRAM was fabricated in a 0.18-μm technology. The measurement results confirm the feasibility and the usefulness of the proposed techniques. A reduction of active power consumption with a factor of 2 is reported as compared to the current state of the art. The results are generalized towards a 32-KB SRAM. © 2007 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Embedded memory; Low power; SRAM
Index Keywords: Low power; Electric power utilization; Embedded systems; Fabrication; Mobile computing; Static random access storage

Title: A model for optimal sizing of photovoltaic irrigation water pumping systems
Affiliations: Faculty of Chemical Engineering and Technology, University of Zagreb, Marulicev trg 19, 10000 Zagreb, Croatia; Faculty of Civil and Architectural Engineering, University of Split, Matice Hrvatske 15, 21000 Split, Croatia
Authors with affiliations: Glasnovic, Z., Faculty of Chemical Engineering and Technology, University of Zagreb, Marulicev trg 19, 10000 Zagreb, Croatia; Margeta, J., Faculty of Civil and Architectural Engineering, University of Split, Matice Hrvatske 15, 21000 Split, Croatia
Abstract: The previous methods for optimal sizing of photovoltaic (PV) irrigation water pumping systems separately considered the demand for hydraulic energy and possibilities of its production from available solar energy with the PV pumping system. Unlike such methods, this work approaches the subject problem systematically, meaning that all relevant system elements and their characteristics have been analyzed: PV water pumping system, local climate, boreholes, soil, crops and method of irrigation; therefore, the objective function has been defined in an entirely new manner. The result of such approach is the new mathematical hybrid simulation optimization model for optimal sizing of PV irrigation water pumping systems, that uses dynamic programming for optimizing, while the constraints were defined by the simulation model. The model was tested on two areas in Croatia, and it has been established that this model successfully takes into consideration all characteristic values and their relations in the integrated system. The optimal nominal electric power of PV generator, obtained in the manner presented, are relatively smaller than when the usual method of sizing is used. The presented method for solving the problem has paved the way towards the general model for optimal sizing of all stand-alone PV systems that have some type of energy storage, as well as optimal sizing of PV power plant that functions together with the storage hydroelectric power plant. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Dynamic programming; Irrigation; Optimal sizing; Photovoltaic pumping; PV generator

Authors: Rørvik K.-A., Alne H., Gaarder M., Ruyter B., Måseide N.P., Jakobsen J.V., Berge R.K., Sigholt T., Thomassen M.S.
Title: Does the capacity for energy utilization affect the survival of post-smolt Atlantic salmon, Salmo salar L., during natural outbreaks of infectious pancreatic necrosis?
Affiliations: Department of Animal and Aquaculture Sciences, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Ås-UMB, Norway; AKVAFORSK, Institute of Aquaculture Research, Sunndalsøra, Norway; Intervet Norbio AS, Bergen, Norway; EWOS Innovation AS, Dirdal, Norway; Lipid Research Group, University of Bergen, Haukeland University Hospital, Bergen, Norway; BioMar AS, Trondheim, Norway; AKVAFORSK AS, N-1432 Ås, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Rørvik, K.-A., Department of Animal and Aquaculture Sciences, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Ås-UMB, Norway, AKVAFORSK, Institute of Aquaculture Research, Sunndalsøra, Norway, AKVAFORSK AS, N-1432 Ås, Norway; Alne, H., Department of Animal and Aquaculture Sciences, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Ås-UMB, Norway, AKVAFORSK, Institute of Aquaculture Research, Sunndalsøra, Norway; Gaarder, M., Department of Animal and Aquaculture Sciences, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Ås-UMB, Norway; Ruyter, B., AKVAFORSK, Institute of Aquaculture Research, Sunndalsøra, Norway; Måseide, N.P., Intervet Norbio AS, Bergen, Norway; Jakobsen, J.V., EWOS Innovation AS, Dirdal, Norway; Berge, R.K., Lipid Research Group, University of Bergen, Haukeland University Hospital, Bergen, Norway; Sigholt, T., BioMar AS, Trondheim, Norway; Thomassen, M.S., Department of Animal and Aquaculture Sciences, Norwegian University of Life Sciences, Ås-UMB, Norway, AKVAFORSK, Institute of Aquaculture Research, Sunndalsøra, Norway
Abstract: If osmotic stress and reduced seawater tolerance are predisposing factors for infectious pancreatic necrosis (IPN) outbreaks in farmed Atlantic salmon, increased survival by enhancing access to energy would be expected. The aim of the present study was, therefore, to increase energy access in 1-year old Atlantic salmon after sea transfer by increasing the level of dietary fat, by exchanging some of the dietary oil with more easily oxidized medium chain triacylglycerols, or by dietary supplementation of potentially energy enhancing additives such as clofibrate and tetradecylthioacetic acid (TTA). A natural outbreak of IPN occurred 8 weeks after sea transfer, and a significant dietary effect explaining 76% of the variation in mortality was observed. Relative percentage survival for the fish fed TTA in sea water was 70% when compared with the unsupplemented control, reducing mortality from 7.8 to 2.3%. Muscle fat content and plasma chloride were related to IPN mortality, suggesting that reduced hypoosmoregulatory capacity might be a predisposing factor to the onset of an IPN outbreak. Based on the observation of a threefold increase in white muscle mitochondrial fatty acid oxidizing activity by TTA, it is suggested that TTA has resulted in a re-allocation of dietary fatty acids from storage to energy producing oxidation. © 2007 The Authors.
Author Keywords: Atlantic salmon; B-oxidation; Energy; IPN; Osmoregulation; TTA

Title: Thermal conductivity enhancement in a latent heat storage system
Affiliations: Department of Solar Energy, National Research Center of Egypt, Box 31, Shoubra Garden, Postal Code 11241 Cairo, Egypt; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering at Shoubra, Zagazig University, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: Mettawee, E.-B.S., Department of Solar Energy, National Research Center of Egypt, Box 31, Shoubra Garden, Postal Code 11241 Cairo, Egypt; Assassa, G.M.R., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering at Shoubra, Zagazig University, Egypt
Abstract: Latent heat storage systems especially those employing organic materials have been reported to exhibit a rather slow thermal response. This is mainly due to the relatively low thermal conductivity of organic latent heat materials. In this study, experiments were carried out to investigate a method of enhancing the thermal conductivity of paraffin wax by embedding aluminum powder in it. The size of the aluminum powder particles was 80 μm. The tested mass fractions in the PCM-aluminum composite material were 0.1, 0.3, 0.4, and 0.5 of aluminum. The used mass fraction in the experimental work was 0.5. The experiments were conducted by using a compact PCM solar collector. In this collector, the absorber-container unit performed the function of absorbing the solar energy and storing the phase change material (PCM). The solar energy was stored in the PCM and was discharged to cold water flowing in pipes located inside the PCM. Charging and discharging processes were carried out. The propagation of the melting and freezing fronts was studied during the charging and the discharging processes. The time wise temperatures of the PCM were recorded during the processes of charging and discharging. The solar intensity was recorded for the charging process. It was found that the charging time was reduced by approximately 60% by adding aluminum powder in the wax. In the discharging process, experiments were conducted for different water flow rates of 9-20.4 kg/h. It was found that the useful heat gained increased when adding aluminum powder in the wax as compared to the case of pure paraffin wax. The heat transfer characteristics were studied. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Composite material; Latent heat; Solar energy; Storage; Thermal conductivity

Authors: Beneito R., Vilaplana J., Gisbert S.
Title: Electric toy vehicle powered by a PEMFC stack
Affiliations: Technological Institute for Toy, AIJU, 03440 Ibi, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Beneito, R., Technological Institute for Toy, AIJU, 03440 Ibi, Spain; Vilaplana, J., Technological Institute for Toy, AIJU, 03440 Ibi, Spain; Gisbert, S., Technological Institute for Toy, AIJU, 03440 Ibi, Spain
Abstract: The article describes the design and development of an electric toy vehicle powered by a fuel cell stack. The system consisted of a 150 W PEMFC stack powered by hydrogen/air, a tank of metal hydrides of AB (TiFe) alloy type with a capacity of 300 standard litres, for storing hydrogen, and an electronic power device based on electrolytic capacitors, to supply peak power demands during acceleration and start up of the vehicle. The air supply was provided by a fan preceded by a filter, and in a similar manner the stack was cooled by an air ventilation system. An electrovalve was used to supply H2 in dead-ended mode. All the components were integrated in the vehicle, and the prototype was tested in real working conditions, in a test bench and by children. © 2006 International Association for Hydrogen Energy.

Authors: Greiner C.J., KorpÅs M., Holen A.T.
Title: A Norwegian case study on the production of hydrogen from wind power
Affiliations: Department of Electric Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, 7491 Trondheim, Norway; Energy Systems Department, SINTEF Energy Research, 7465 Trondheim, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Greiner, C.J., Department of Electric Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, 7491 Trondheim, Norway; KorpÅs, M., Energy Systems Department, SINTEF Energy Research, 7465 Trondheim, Norway; Holen, A.T., Department of Electric Power Engineering, Norwegian University of Science and Technology, 7491 Trondheim, Norway
Abstract: A method for assessment of wind-hydrogen (H2) energy systems is presented. The method includes chronological simulations and economic calculations, enabling optimised component sizing and calculation of H2 cost. System components include a wind turbine, electrolyser, compressor, storage tank and power converter. A case study on a Norwegian island is presented. The commuting ferry is modelled as a H2 ferry, representing the H2 demand. The evaluation includes a grid-connected system and an isolated system with a backup power generator. Simulation results show that much larger components are needed for the isolated system. H2 cost amounted to 2.8 € / kg and 6.2 € / kg for the grid-connected and isolated system, respectively. Sensitivity analyses show that a marginal decrease in wind turbine and electrolyser cost will reduce the H2 cost substantially. Rate of return is also important due to high investment costs. The grid-connected system is by far the most economical, but the system involves frequent grid interaction. © 2006 International Association for Hydrogen Energy.
Author Keywords: Chronological simulation; Distributed generation; Electrolysis; Hydrogen economy; Modelling; Renewable energy; Wind power

Authors: Mulder G., Hetland J., Lenaers G.
Title: Towards a sustainable hydrogen economy: Hydrogen pathways and infrastructure
Affiliations: VITO, Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; SINTEF Energy Research, Kolbjorn Hejesvei 1A, N-7465 Trondheim, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Mulder, G., VITO, Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; Hetland, J., SINTEF Energy Research, Kolbjorn Hejesvei 1A, N-7465 Trondheim, Norway; Lenaers, G., VITO, Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium
Abstract: Results from the European HySociety project (2003-2005) are revealed in which political, societal and technical challenges for developing a European hydrogen economy have been addressed. The focus is placed on the assessments of hydrogen pathways and infrastructure. It will show that no chain can be selected as an obvious winner according to primary energy demand, emission and cost. In order to ensure that the pathway losses are compensated by the more efficient end-use of the H2 fuel, calculations based on well-to-tank losses and tank-to-wheel efficiencies are used. Furthermore, in order to look into the consequences of introducing hydrogen, a top-down scenario has been worked out. The message is that certainly the hydrogen distribution part for the transport application has to be improved to avoid loosing the emission gain that is obtainable, especially via carbon capture and storage of the CO2. In order to quantify the market development a bottom-up approach has been established in particular for the transport sector. © 2006 International Association for Hydrogen Energy.

Authors: López E., Isorna F., Rosa F.
Title: Optimization of a solar hydrogen storage system: Exergetic considerations
Affiliations: Instituto Nacional de Técnica Aeroespacial, Ctra. S. Juan-Matalascanas, km.34, 21130 Mazagón (Huelva), Spain
Authors with affiliations: López, E., Instituto Nacional de Técnica Aeroespacial, Ctra. S. Juan-Matalascanas, km.34, 21130 Mazagón (Huelva), Spain; Isorna, F., Instituto Nacional de Técnica Aeroespacial, Ctra. S. Juan-Matalascanas, km.34, 21130 Mazagón (Huelva), Spain; Rosa, F., Instituto Nacional de Técnica Aeroespacial, Ctra. S. Juan-Matalascanas, km.34, 21130 Mazagón (Huelva), Spain
Abstract: From production to end-users, the choice of suitable hydrogen delivery and storage systems will be essential to assure the adequate introduction and development of these facilities. This article describes the main options for hydrogen storage when produced from renewable energy, and explains different criteria to be considered in the design and building-up of stationary hydrogen storage systems, with special attention to exergy issues. An example of exergy analysis is done using data from the solar hydrogen storage facility of the Spanish Instituto Nacional de Técnica Aeroespacial (INTA). As expected, the main conclusions of this analysis show the advantage of low pressure hydrogen in comparison with other available methods to store hydrogen. Another interesting option, from the exergy efficiency point of view, is the storage of hydrogen in metal hydride systems. The last option, and the most inefficient, is the high pressure hydrogen storage. © 2006 International Association for Hydrogen Energy.

Title: Last advances in analysis of intra-beam scattering in the hadron storage rings
Source title: Nuclear Instruments and Methods in Physics Research, Section A: Accelerators, Spectrometers, Detectors and Associated Equipment
Affiliations: ITEP, B. Cheremushkinskaya 25, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Zenkevich, P., ITEP, B. Cheremushkinskaya 25, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Multiple intra-beam scattering (IBS) appears because of Coulomb scattering of charged particles on each other. In hadron storage rings, it results in re-distribution of the energy between different degrees of freedom, growth of six-dimensional emittance, development of non-Gaussian tails in distribution function and sometimes to the loss of particles. Traditional method of IBS analysis is based on "Gaussian model", which is assumed that distribution functions are Gaussian ones for all degrees of freedom. The basic theorems derived from the Gaussian model are shortly discussed. More detailed IBS analysis can be done using the Fokker-Planck equation (FPE) or equivalent tools. The FPE is written in "coordinate-momentum" space and in "invariant space" with account of the multiple IBS. Here, we consider two numerical methods of three-dimensional FPE solution developed at the last time: (1) the use of the "Langevin equations map" (LEM) and (2) the simulation of three-dimensional IBS using "the binary collision map" (BCM). The basics of both methods and examples of their application to storage rings are given. Alternative approach to the IBS analysis is named "molecular dynamics" (MD) based on the straight-forward integration of the particle trajectories taking into account the external electromagnetic fields and the Coulomb forces. Two modifications of MD are described: (1) a two-dimensional "wire model" and (2) a three-dimensional model of "periodical cells", which is fruitful in the case of small density beams, for example, the "crystalline beams". The basic problems of the molecular dynamics and results of its application to IBS analysis are shortly discussed. © 2007.
Author Keywords: Intra-beam scattering; Numerical simulations; Storage ring
Index Keywords: Charged particles; Coulomb blockade; Distribution functions; Gaussian beams; Molecular dynamics; Theorem proving; Fokker-Planck equation (FPE); Intra-beam scattering; Non-Gaussian tails; Storage rings

Authors: Mamagkakis S., Bartzas A., Pouiklis G., Atienza D., Catthoor F., Soudris D., Thanailakis A.
Title: Systematic methodology for exploration of performance - Energy trade-offs in network applications using Dynamic Data Type refinement
Affiliations: VLSI Design and Testing Center-Democritus University, Thrace, 67100 Xanthi, Greece; DACYA, UCM, 28040 Madrid, Spain; LSI, EPFL, 1015 Lausanne, Switzerland; IMEC vzw, Kapeldreef 75, 3001 Heverlee, Belgium

Abstract: Modern network applications require high performance and consume a lot of energy. Their inherent dynamic nature makes the dynamic memory subsystem a critical contributing factor to the overall energy consumption and to the execution time performance. This paper presents a novel, systematic methodology for generating performance-energy trade-offs by implementing optimal Dynamic Data Types, finely tuned and refined for network applications. Our systematic methodology is supported by a new, fully automated tool. We assess the effectiveness of the proposed approach in four representative, real-life case studies and provide significant energy savings and performance improvements compared to the original implementations. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
