Title: Laser-probing measurements and calculations of lifetimes of the 5d D 3 2 2 and 5d D 5 2 2 metastable levels in Ba II
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Stockholm University, AlbaNova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden; Service d'Astrophysique et de Spectroscopie, Université de Mons-Hainaut, 20 Place du Parc, B-7000 Mons, Belgium; Institut de Physique Nucléaire, Atomique et de Spectroscopie (IPNAS), Université de Liège, Bĝtiment B15, B-4000 Liège, Belgium; Institute of Solid State Physics, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, 72 Tzarigradsko Chaussee, BG-1784 Sofia, Bulgaria; Department of Physics, Royal Institute of Technology, AlbaNova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Gurell, J., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, AlbaNova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden; Biémont, E., Service d'Astrophysique et de Spectroscopie, Université de Mons-Hainaut, 20 Place du Parc, B-7000 Mons, Belgium, Institut de Physique Nucléaire, Atomique et de Spectroscopie (IPNAS), Université de Liège, Bĝtiment B15, B-4000 Liège, Belgium; Blagoev, K., Institute of Solid State Physics, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, 72 Tzarigradsko Chaussee, BG-1784 Sofia, Bulgaria; Fivet, V., Service d'Astrophysique et de Spectroscopie, Université de Mons-Hainaut, 20 Place du Parc, B-7000 Mons, Belgium; Lundin, P., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, AlbaNova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden; Mannervik, S., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, AlbaNova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden; Norlin, L.-O., Department of Physics, Royal Institute of Technology, AlbaNova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden; Quinet, P., Service d'Astrophysique et de Spectroscopie, Université de Mons-Hainaut, 20 Place du Parc, B-7000 Mons, Belgium, Institut de Physique Nucléaire, Atomique et de Spectroscopie (IPNAS), Université de Liège, Bĝtiment B15, B-4000 Liège, Belgium; Rostohar, D., Institut de Physique Nucléaire, Atomique et de Spectroscopie (IPNAS), Université de Liège, Bĝtiment B15, B-4000 Liège, Belgium; Royen, P., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, AlbaNova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden; Schef, P., Department of Physics, Stockholm University, AlbaNova University Center, SE-10691 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: The two metastable levels 5d D 3 2 2 and 5d D 5 2 2 in Ba II both show extremely long lifetimes of the order of several tens of seconds each. This has been found both by experiments and by theoretical predictions. The small transition probabilities associated with these two levels make them interesting and challenging for theoreticians as well as for experimentalists. Several calculations and measurements of these two lifetimes have been made previously but discrepancies between the results are present. This article presents values of τ=89.4±15.6 s for the D 3 2 2 level and τ=32.0±4.6 s for the D 5 2 2 level measured in a beam-laser experiment performed at the ion storage ring CRYRING. These values are supported by our new calculations resulting in τ=82.0 s for the D 3 2 2 level and τ=31.6 s for the D 5 2 2 level. © 2007 The American Physical Society.
Index Keywords: Barium; Laser applications; Laser beams; Ion storage ring; Transition probabilities; Electron energy levels

Title: IEA members seek energy security, sustainability
Authors with affiliations: Leblond, D.
Abstract: Having confronted growing energy challenges, International Energy Agency members called for the identification of achieving energy security, sustainability and least-costly policies for combating energy-related climate change. It recognized the promotion of new technologies such as carbon sequestration capture and storage to promote clean coal and reduction in the costs of advanced biofuels, solar power, hydrogen fuel cells and electric vehicles through encouragement of research and development. Meanwhile, IEA said that it has good relations with Russia, which is the main gas supplier to Europe. IEA stated that there's nothing to fear on the possible creation of a gas cartel led by gas exporting countries because in any case, gas can more easily be replaced by other fuels.
Index Keywords: Energy resources; Gas supply; International trade; Security systems; Sustainable development; biofuel; carbon sequestration; climate change; energy policy; research and development; solar power; sustainability

Authors: Jelínková H., Šulc J., Němec M., Koranda P., Pašta J., Nejezchleb K., Škoda V.
Title: Microchip Nd:YAG laser for safe laser applications
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Faculty of Nuclear Sciences and Physical Engineering, Czech Technical University, Břehová 7, 115 19 Prague 1, Czech Republic; Clinic of Ophthalmology, Central Military Hospital, 169 02 Prague 6, Czech Republic; Crytur, Ltd. Turnov, Palackého 175, 511 01 Turnov, Czech Republic
Authors with affiliations: Jelínková, H., Faculty of Nuclear Sciences and Physical Engineering, Czech Technical University, Břehová 7, 115 19 Prague 1, Czech Republic; Šulc, J., Faculty of Nuclear Sciences and Physical Engineering, Czech Technical University, Břehová 7, 115 19 Prague 1, Czech Republic; Němec, M., Faculty of Nuclear Sciences and Physical Engineering, Czech Technical University, Břehová 7, 115 19 Prague 1, Czech Republic; Koranda, P., Faculty of Nuclear Sciences and Physical Engineering, Czech Technical University, Břehová 7, 115 19 Prague 1, Czech Republic; Pašta, J., Clinic of Ophthalmology, Central Military Hospital, 169 02 Prague 6, Czech Republic; Nejezchleb, K., Crytur, Ltd. Turnov, Palackého 175, 511 01 Turnov, Czech Republic; Škoda, V., Crytur, Ltd. Turnov, Palackého 175, 511 01 Turnov, Czech Republic
Abstract: For many applications, like micromanufacturing, remote sensing, data storage, etc. a microchip Nd:YAG laser is suitable. From the measurement of the laser radiation transmission through the eye tissue is evident that the injury probability of the retina is higher for the case of 1064 nm instead of 1338 nm. The main reason for that is the radiation water absorption. The Q-switched diode pumped (at 808 nm) microchip laser emitting radiation at wavelength 1338 nm was designed and realized. This laser was based on diffusion bonded crystal (diameter 5 mm) which combines in one piece the laser active part (Nd:YAG, 4 mm long) and saturable absorber (V:YAG, 0.7 mm, T0 = 85%). The microchip resonator mirrors were deposited directly on the bonded crystal surfaces, output coupler reflexivity was 90%. The constructed "alignment-free" Q-switched microchip laser was tested under pulsed, and CW diode pumping. In both cases, the generated pulse energy, pulse length, emission wavelength, polarization, and laser beam profile were measured. The energy up to 18.6 μJ in 1.7 ns long pulses was reached at the wavelength 1338 nm. TEM00 laser mode was linearly polarized. The interaction of the radiation from the near- and mid-infrared region with the eye tissue was investigated and as conclusion the microchip with the wavelength 1338 nm was chosen as a good compromise between the eye safe 1.5 μm radiation and commonly, in the application used, 1.06 μm radiation.
Author Keywords: Diffusion bounding; Eye-safe laser; Microchip laser; Nd:YAG; V:YAG
Index Keywords: Diffusion; Diodes; Neodymium; Polarization; Remote sensing; Tissue; Water absorption; Wavelength; Coupler reflexivity; Data storage; Microchips; Micromanufacturing; YAG lasers; Solid state lasers

Authors: Molokáč Š., Grega L., Rybár P.
Title: Using MRI devices for the energy storage purposes
Affiliations: Faculty of Mining, Ecology, Process Control and Geotechnologies, Technical University of Košice, Slovakia
Authors with affiliations: Molokáč, Š., Faculty of Mining, Ecology, Process Control and Geotechnologies, Technical University of Košice, Slovakia; Grega, L., Faculty of Mining, Ecology, Process Control and Geotechnologies, Technical University of Košice, Slovakia; Rybár, P., Faculty of Mining, Ecology, Process Control and Geotechnologies, Technical University of Košice, Slovakia
Abstract: It is well known, that the electrical energy storage in the large scale is basically a difficult process. Such a process is connected with energy losses, as most frequently it is the conversion of electrical energy into another form, for example mechanical, and then back to the primal electrical form. Though, the SMES technology offers the energy storage in an unchanged form, which is advantageous primarily in the achieved efficiency. The magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) devices, commonly used in the medical facilities are based on the basis of superconducting magnet. After its rejection from operation, (basically caused only by its "software fustiness" and not by functional faults), there is a possibility of using such devices for the energy storage purposes. Additionally, such a technology of storage is also ecological. A research project is running at the Faculty of Mining, Ecology, Process Control and Geotechnologies (F BERG), the Department of Business and Management, in the field of using rejected MRI for energy storage purposes.
Author Keywords: Cryogenics; Energy storage; MRI; Renewable energy; SMES; Superconducting magnet

Title: Products for breathing clean air
Abstract: Some of the products for breathing clean air are discussed. Lincoln Electric Co. has introduced the X-Tractor 1GC fume extractor, a portable, high-vacuum system designed to remove and to filter welding fumes. The 37 lb. system is good for light-duty welding use such as in light fabrication, maintenance and construction applications. Rimrock-Wolf Robotics Corp. has introduced a welding fume extractor for use with manual or automated welding torches. A Quality Air Breathing System, Model P-20, Personal Air Breathing Unit, manufactured by Martech Services Co. works with an existing filtered compressed air supply and provides OSHA compliant Grade D breathable air for a proper respirator. The system has an in-built filter with filter monitor, and a carbon monoxide monitor with both audible and visual alarms.
Index Keywords: Automation; Carbon monoxide; Cold storage; Compressed air; Energy storage; Heat affected zone; Monitoring; Optical design; Pressure vessels; Vacuum welding; Wave filters; Welding; Air breathing; air supply; Audible and visual alarms; Clean air; construction applications; High vacuum systems; Light duty; Lincoln Electric (CO); Monitor (CO); Welding fumes; welding torches; Industrial applications

Title: Could SuperCables deliver both hydrogen and electricity via a SuperGrid?
Affiliations: IBM
Authors with affiliations: Grant, P.M., IBM
Abstract: A SuperCable, using high-temperature superconductors (HTSC) cooled by hydrogen, can simultaneously deliver electricity and hydrogen to end users for domestic and industrial consumption and to power fuel cell cars. The electric portion of the grid would use high-current DC superconducting cables for power transmission, with liquid hydrogen as the core coolant. The nuclear plant also generates hydrogen, which is distributed along with the electricity by a SuperCable ring bus. The hydrogen in the SuperCable acts not only as a cryogen and an energy delivery agent but also as a possible electricity storage medium. A nationwide development of SuperCable infrastructure could enable the long-sought commoditization of electricity through its storage as liquid hydrogen. The principal losses from the SuperCable would be radiation form the surrounding environment and replenishment of the recooling booster stations with hydrogen to maintain design temperatures in the SuperCables.

Authors: Shuaib M., Khan I., Ali Z., Ali W., Ahmad T., Zeb A.
Title: Evaluation of different wheat varieties by SDS-PAGE electrophoresis
Affiliations: Department of Biotechnology, University of Malakand, Chakdara, Pakistan; Institute of Chemical Sciences, University of Peshawar, Peshawar, Pakistan; Nuclear Institute for Food and Agriculture Tarnab, Peshawar, Pakistan; Department of Biotechnology, University of Malakand, Chakdara, N.W.F.P., Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Shuaib, M., Department of Biotechnology, University of Malakand, Chakdara, Pakistan; Khan, I., Institute of Chemical Sciences, University of Peshawar, Peshawar, Pakistan; Ali, Z., Department of Biotechnology, University of Malakand, Chakdara, Pakistan; Ali, W., Department of Biotechnology, University of Malakand, Chakdara, Pakistan; Ahmad, T., Nuclear Institute for Food and Agriculture Tarnab, Peshawar, Pakistan; Zeb, A., Department of Biotechnology, University of Malakand, Chakdara, Pakistan, Institute of Chemical Sciences, University of Peshawar, Peshawar, Pakistan, Department of Biotechnology, University of Malakand, Chakdara, N.W.F.P., Pakistan
Abstract: Wheat seed-storage proteins represent not only an important source of food and energy but it is also involved in the determination of bread-making quality. Wheat grains of thirteen wheat varieties were collected from different ecological regions of Pakistan. The variability of seed storage-proteins was analyzed by using SDS-PAGE electrophoresis. Electrophorogram for each variety was scored and presence or absence of each band noted and entered in a binary data matrix. Based on electrophoresis band spectra, Jaccard's Similarity Index (JSI) was calculated. Genetic diversity of wheat was evaluated by constructing the dendrogram for High Molecular Weight (HMW) and Low Molecular Weight (LMW) gluten subunit bands. It is concluded that seed storage protein profiles could be useful markers in the studies of genetic diversity and classification of adapted cultivars, thereby improving the efficiency of wheat breeding programs in cultivar development especially in developing countries like Pakistan. © 2007 Asian Network for Scientific Information.
Author Keywords: Cluster analysis; Genetic diversity; SDS-PAGE; Wheat varieties
Index Keywords: Triticum aestivum

Authors: Chen C.Y., Liu D.H., Huang C.L., Chang C.L.
Title: Portable DMFC system with methanol sensor-less control
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER), No. 1000, Wunhua Rd., Jiaan Village, Taoyuan County 32546, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chen, C.Y., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER), No. 1000, Wunhua Rd., Jiaan Village, Taoyuan County 32546, Taiwan; Liu, D.H., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER), No. 1000, Wunhua Rd., Jiaan Village, Taoyuan County 32546, Taiwan; Huang, C.L., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER), No. 1000, Wunhua Rd., Jiaan Village, Taoyuan County 32546, Taiwan; Chang, C.L., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER), No. 1000, Wunhua Rd., Jiaan Village, Taoyuan County 32546, Taiwan
Abstract: This work develops a prototype 20 W portable DMFC by system integration of stack, condenser, methanol sensor-less control and start-up characteristics. The effects of these key components and control schemes on the performance are also discussed. To expedite the use of portable DMFC in electronic applications, the system utilizes a novel methanol sensor-less control method, providing improved fuel efficiency, durability, miniaturization and cost reduction. The operating characteristics of the DMFC stack are applied to control the fuel ejection time and period, enabling the system to continue operating even when the MEAs of the stack are deteriorated. The portable system is also designed with several features including water balance and quick start-up (in 5 min). Notably, the proposed system using methanol sensor-less control with injection of pure methanol can power the DVD player and notebook PC. The system specific energy and energy density following three days of operation are 362 Wh kg-1 and 335 Wh L-1, respectively, which are better than those of lithium batteries (∼150 Wh kg-1 and ∼250 Wh L-). This good energy storage feature demonstrates that the portable DMFC is likely to be valuable in computer, communication and consumer electronic (3C) markets. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Direct methanol fuel cell; Energy density; Membrane electrode assembly; Methanol sensor-less control; Power density; System integration

Title: Synthesis and interfacial properties of aminosilane derivative of acrylated epoxidized soybean oil
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Polymer Research Center, Boǧaziçi University, Bebek, Istanbul 34342, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Çolak, S., Department of Chemistry, Polymer Research Center, Boǧaziçi University, Bebek, Istanbul 34342, Turkey; Küsefoǧlu, S.H., Department of Chemistry, Polymer Research Center, Boǧaziçi University, Bebek, Istanbul 34342, Turkey
Abstract: In this study silanized acrylated epoxidized soybean oil (silanized-AESO), a multifunctional monomer, was synthesized by reacting acrylated epoxidized soybean oil with 3-Aminopropyltriethoxysilane via a Michael addition reaction using less than equivalent amount of the silane. The characterization of silanized-AESO was done by NMR and IR spectroscopy. Free radically initiated homopolymer of silanized-AESO was synthesized by using the residual acrylate groups. The silanized-AESO homopolymer was characterized by IR spectroscopy. The interfacial adhesion of the polymer on glass surface before and after moisture cure was measured according to ASTM D 4541 Pull-Off Adhesion Test. After moisture curing process, an approximate of eight-fold improvement was observed in the adhesion strength. Prolonged exposure to 92% humidity for 48 h caused to approximately 15% decrease in the adhesion strength. Silanized-AESO was copolymerized with styrene in 1 : 1 weight ratio via radical polymerization. The effect of increased crosslink density upon moisture cure on the mechanical and physical properties of silanized-AESO-styrene copolymer was analyzed by DMA (Dynamic Mechanical Analysis), swelling, and surface hardness tests. Upon moisture cure 35% improvement was observed in the storage modulus because of the increase in the crosslink density. According to tan 8 curves and surface hardness tests, silanized-AESO-styrene copolymer shows heterogeneous morphology in crosslinked areas. © 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
Author Keywords: Adhesion; Coatings; Crosslinking; Mechanical properties; Renewable resources
Index Keywords: Adhesion; Coatings; Crosslinking; Derivatives; Epoxidation; Interfaces (materials); Renewable energy resources; Synthesis (chemical); Aminosilane derivatives; Moisture curing process; Multifunctional monomers; Vegetable oils; copolymerization; cross linking; homopolymer; interfacial property; monomer; plant extract; synthesis

Title: Transportation - Quick takes: Sinotrans to store, ship oil for Sinochem
Abstract: Under an agreement, Chinas Sinotrans Group Corp will provide Sinochem with oil transportation by sea, air, rail, and road as well as storage services, all aimed at increasing efficiency and lowering costs. Under that contract, Nanjing will transport 600,000 ton of oil products in 2007, using 30,000-40,000 dwt tankers. Nanjing currently has nine product tankers and will increase its capacity through a further 24 vessels to be constructed by 2010. The transport agreements are consistent with Chinese government policy, which promotes use of domestic shipping firms to curb foreign currency outlays and to assume a tighter grip of the countrys energy supply chain.

Title: Special report: DOE partnerships testing sequestration
Authors with affiliations: Dittrick, P.
Abstract: The US Department of Energy in 2003 organized seven Regional Carbon Sequestration Partnerships which is currently testing sequestration as part of the validation phase. The validation phase is the second in the three-phase program where there are about 30 validation projects planned. Meanwhile, In order to assess mineral, chemical and hydrologic effects of injected CO2, the Big Sky Carbon Sequestration Partnership (BSCSP) plans field tests in basalt formations and sedimentary rock hosted saline formations. They are planning testing of how well basalt volcanic rocks can hold injected gas. Another is the Midwest Geological Sequestration Consortium which is investigating options for CO2 storage such including oil reservoirs, coal seams and deep saline water-bearing formations. Another is the Plains CO2 Reduction Partnership (PCOR). It is investigating sequestration technologies in the central US, and is currently developing three geologic field-validation projects.
Index Keywords: Basalt; Carbon dioxide; Geological surveys; Petroleum reservoirs; basalt; carbon sequestration; coal seam; energy planning; hydrocarbon reservoir; sedimentary rock; North America; United States

Title: Dynamic optimal power flow approach to account for consumer response in short term hydrothermal coordination studies
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Federal University of Minas Gerais - UFMG, Av. Antonio Carlos 6627, Belo Horizonte, MG 31270-010, Brazil; Department of Electrical Engineering, Federal University of Santa Catarina - UFSC, Campus Trindade, Florianópolis, SC 88040-900, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Uturbey, W., Department of Electrical Engineering, Federal University of Minas Gerais - UFMG, Av. Antonio Carlos 6627, Belo Horizonte, MG 31270-010, Brazil; Simões Costa, A., Department of Electrical Engineering, Federal University of Santa Catarina - UFSC, Campus Trindade, Florianópolis, SC 88040-900, Brazil
Abstract: This paper deals with the representation of price-responsive loads in the short term coordination of predominantly hydroelectric hydrothermal systems. The proposed approach allows the representation of cross-relationships between demand and price during different dispatch intervals of a given time horizon. Also, consumer energy constraints which behave as dynamic restrictions can be taken into account. By that means, a load shifting program in which the consumers' overall energy consumption remains constant throughout the time horizon can be simulated. The short-term hydrothermal coordination is solved as a single optimisation problem employing the primal-dual interior point method. Realistic subsystems, based on the Brazil interconnected power system, are used to illustrate the effect of price-responsive loads on reservoir storages. © The Institution of Engineering and Technology 2007.
Index Keywords: Energy utilization; Hydroelectric power; Hydrothermal synthesis; Optimal control systems; Power control; Consumer responses; Hydroelectric hydrothermal systems; Hydrothermal coordination; Optimisation problems; Realistic subsystems; Electric load flow

Title: Testing ternary content addressable memories with active neighbourhood pattern-sensitive faults
Affiliations: Advanced Reliable Systems (ARES) Laboratory, Department of Electrical Engineering, National Central University, Jhongli 320, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Y.-J., Advanced Reliable Systems (ARES) Laboratory, Department of Electrical Engineering, National Central University, Jhongli 320, Taiwan; Li, J.-F., Advanced Reliable Systems (ARES) Laboratory, Department of Electrical Engineering, National Central University, Jhongli 320, Taiwan
Abstract: With shrinking transistor sizes and growing transistor density, testing neighbourhood pattern-sensitive faults (NPSFs) is increasingly important for semiconductor memories. A test methodology for detecting active NPSFs (ANPSFs) and static NPSFs (SNPSFs) in ternary content addressable memories (TCAMs) is presented. March-like and two-group test methods are two commonly used testing techniques for NPSFs in random access memories. Because of the special TCAM cell structure, however, using a unique test algorithm with only either a March-like or a two-group test operations are not time-efficient. A test methodology that employs both March-based and two-group testing to cover 100 ANPSFs and SNPSFs in TCAMs is proposed. The total test complexity of the proposed test methodology is 156N for an N×K-bit TCAM. No TCAM circuit modification is needed to support the proposed test methodology. © The Institution of Engineering and Technology 2007.
Index Keywords: Computational complexity; Electronic equipment testing; Energy dissipation; Random access storage; Transistors; Neighbourhood pattern-sensitive faults (NPSF); Pattern-sensitive faults; TCAM cell structure; Transistor density; Data storage equipment

Title: Coal on the comeback
Authors with affiliations: Sampson, B.
Abstract: Various clean coal technologies has opened the opportunities for a cleaner fossil fuel to fulfill the energy gap. Applying post-combustion scrubbers in the fossil fuel clean coals, while removing carbon dioxide from the process. Coal gasification, specifically Integrated Combined Cycle Gasification (IGCC), has reduced emissions and increased the efficiency of burning coal. IGCC creates a separate concentrated stream of carbon dioxide, which makes capturing and storing it easier. IGCC can make a plant providing 45% efficiency, incorporating carbon capture and storage (CCS). The clean coal technologies, from a global perspective, are suitable in different locations, depending on the type of coal available and the level of demand.

Title: Take your partners
Authors with affiliations: Farrell, L.
Abstract: National Grid that operates and owns gas transmission and distribution networks in England and Wales introduced four Alliance partnerships in 2005 for gas mains replacement work in four of its distribution networks. The £1.6 billion contracts were awarded for an eight-year period. These contracts started a new approach of distributing energy, based on shared risks and rewards, with long-term sharing of workload. The company achieved significant success with these contracts and adopted a similar approach within its electricity transmission business. All partners in the Gas Alliances are also involved in the electricity contracts. The Electricity Alliances will cover a significant part of the company's overall capital investment in the electricity transmission network in England and Wales and contribute to the wider issue of security of supply of gas and electric energy.
Index Keywords: Contracts; Electric energy storage; Electric power transmission networks; Electricity; Investments; Capital investment; Electric energy; Gas transmission; Electric power distribution

Authors: Morales-Cas A.M., Moya C., Goto B., Vega L.F., Calleja G.
Title: Adsorption of hydrogen and methane mixtures on carbon cylindrical cavities
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Environmental Technology, ESCET, Rey Juan Carlos University, c/ Tulipan s/n, 28933 Mostoles, Madrid, Spain; Institut de Ciència de Materials de Barcelona (ICMAB-CSIC), Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Cientificas, Campus de la UAB, 08193 Bellaterra Barcelona, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Morales-Cas, A.M., Department of Chemical and Environmental Technology, ESCET, Rey Juan Carlos University, c/ Tulipan s/n, 28933 Mostoles, Madrid, Spain; Moya, C., Department of Chemical and Environmental Technology, ESCET, Rey Juan Carlos University, c/ Tulipan s/n, 28933 Mostoles, Madrid, Spain; Goto, B., Department of Chemical and Environmental Technology, ESCET, Rey Juan Carlos University, c/ Tulipan s/n, 28933 Mostoles, Madrid, Spain; Vega, L.F., Institut de Ciència de Materials de Barcelona (ICMAB-CSIC), Consejo Superior de Investigaciones Cientificas, Campus de la UAB, 08193 Bellaterra Barcelona, Spain; Calleja, G., Department of Chemical and Environmental Technology, ESCET, Rey Juan Carlos University, c/ Tulipan s/n, 28933 Mostoles, Madrid, Spain
Abstract: The purpose of this work is to provide some insights into the adsorption of hydrogen and methane mixtures on carbon cavities with cylindrical geometry. Hydrogen and methane mixture adsorption has been simulated in pore sizes ranging from micropores to mesopores at room temperature. The grand canonical Monte Carlo method provided the amount adsorbed as a function of pressure and bulk composition. In addition, the microscopic characteristics of the adsorbed phase have been accomplished by calculating density profiles and adsorption energy distribution functions. The results show that the first methane and hydrogen adsorbed layers are co-incident, and there is a second hydrogen layer that is not present in the pure compound adsorption. In addition, the adsorption energy stages for hydrogen in the mixture are more favorable than those for pure hydrogen, revealing that the presence of methane molecules favors energetic hydrogen stabilization (for micropores, hydrogen adsorption energy changes are observed from 6.3 to 75%, depending on the operational conditions). These results can shed light on the knowledge of the underlying adsorption behavior of these mixtures, which are of interest in hydrogen storage and purification by adsorption, and therefore of potential applications in hydrogen technology (clean hydrogen production, fuel cells, etc.). © 2007 American Chemical Society.
Index Keywords: Adsorption; Hydrogen; Methane; Microscopic examination; Monte Carlo methods; Pore size; Carbon cavities; Energy distribution functions; Methane mixture adsorption; Room temperature; Binary mixtures

Authors: Friis-Hansen L., Schjerling C.K., de la Cour C.D., Håkanson R., Rehfeld J.F.
Title: Characteristics of gastrin controlled ECL cell specific gene expression
Affiliations: Department of Clinical Biochemistry, Rigshospitalet, University of Copenhagen, Denmark; Department of Pharmacology, University of Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Friis-Hansen, L., Department of Clinical Biochemistry, Rigshospitalet, University of Copenhagen, Denmark; Schjerling, C.K., Department of Clinical Biochemistry, Rigshospitalet, University of Copenhagen, Denmark; de la Cour, C.D., Department of Pharmacology, University of Lund, Sweden; Håkanson, R., Department of Pharmacology, University of Lund, Sweden; Rehfeld, J.F., Department of Clinical Biochemistry, Rigshospitalet, University of Copenhagen, Denmark
Abstract: Background: The ECL cells are histamine-producing endocrine cells in the oxyntic mucosa that synthesize and secrete proteins and peptides. They are the primary target for gastrin and mediate the control of gastrin on acid secretion and oxyntic mucosal growth. Knowledge of the molecular biology of the ECL cell is therefore important for understanding gastric physiology. Accordingly, we wanted to identify genes that are characteristically expressed in the ECL cells and controlled by gastrin. Methods: Using Affymetrix GeneChips®, RNA expression profiles were generated from ECL cells isolated by counterflow elutriation from hyper- or hypogastrinemic rats. Contamination from non-endocrine cells was eliminated by subtraction of the expression profiles of the fundic and antral mucosa. Results: The expression of 365 genes was ECL cell characteristic. Gastrin was found to control the expression of 120 which could be divided into two major groups depending on the known or anticipated biological function of the encoded protein: genes encoding proteins involved in the secretory process and genes encoding proteins needed to generate energy for secretion. Interestingly, gastrin stimulation also increased ECL cells expression of anti-apoptotic genes. Conclusion: The ECL cell specific expression profile is reminiscent of that of neurons and other endocrine cells exhibiting high expression of genes encoding proteins involved in the synthesis, storage and secretion of neuropeptides or peptide hormones. Gastrin regulated the expression of one third of these genes and is thus involved in the control of secretion from the ECL cells. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: cDNA microarray; ECL cells; Gastrin; Gene expression; Rat

Title: Coal storage and oxygen access
Affiliations: ESI Eurosilo BV, Netherlands; PWH Eurosilo BV; Eurosilo Holland BV, Netherlands; Royal Dutch Institute of Professional Engineers; Newtonstraat 26-28, 1446 VR Purmerend, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Nijhof, H.ESI Eurosilo BV, Netherlands, PWH Eurosilo BV, Eurosilo Holland BV, Netherlands, Royal Dutch Institute of Professional Engineers, Newtonstraat 26-28, 1446 VR Purmerend, Netherlands
Abstract: Coal can be stored in properly designed Bunkers, Silos or Piles. Decisive factors in determining the type of storage to be used are initial capital investment, and pay back period. However, in addition to the economics, the factors spontaneous combustion, self heating, and minimizing the flow of air through the stack should be assessed. The storage process as well as the configuration of the coal storage are significant in evaluating these factors. This paper focuses on the importance of limiting oxygen access to the stored coal, and is illustrated by calculations which predict possible self heating scenarios of a multiple coal silo storage facility at Helsinki Energy, Finland.
Index Keywords: Oxygen access; Storage process; Combustion; Containers; Flow of fluids; Heating; Investments; Oxygen supply; Coal storage; Coal; Heating; Oxygen; Storage Containers

Title: Nodes are finally making their mark
Abstract: Seabed Geophysical, a subsidiary of SeaBird, has developed two node systems, CASE (Cableless Seismic System) and CASE Abyss, for deepwater application. Both systems have a CPU (central processing unit), 24-bit resolution, 200 days worth of 2 ms seismic data storage, a quality-control data link, three geophones, and a hydrophone and individually calibrated sensors. These types of node systems offer several advantages over other forms of seismic acquisition. They can be useful in reducing uncertainty and dry holes in expensive deepwater environments in a simple 2-D exploration mode. The high-quality data acquired can help geoscientists improve their definition of reservoir volume, lithology, fluid content, porosity, permeability, fracturing, principle stress direction, and azimuthal anisotropy. SeaBird and Seabed are also planning to examine the possibility of using the nodes for passive seismic work, in which they are left on the seafloor to listen to naturally occurring noises and hydrofrac-induced seismic energy.

Authors: Velikhov E.P., Ponomarev-Stepnoi N.N., Volkov V.G., Gorodetskii G.G., Zverkov Yu.A., Ivanov O.P., Koltyshev S.M., Muzrukova V.D., Semenov S.G., Stepanov V.E., Chesnokov A.V., Shisha A.D.

Abstract: This article is devoted to work done in 2002-2006 as part of the unified project Reabilitatsiya to rehabilitate radiation hazardous objects and sections of the radioactively contaminated territory of the Russian Science Center Kurchatov Institute. The main objects of the rehabilitation work were old storage sites built for radioactive wastes on the territory of the Institute when military and civilian nuclear technologies were under development. The structural features of the storage sites, including the volumes and characteristics of the wastes stored, are presented. The salient aspects of the disposal sites, taken into account during the rehabilitation work, are discussed. The organization of the rehabilitation operations and the sequence in which they are performed, the special features of the technical design solutions used, the technological methods, and ways for conducting the work are described. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.

Authors: Bergel'son B.R., Gerasimov A.S., Zaritskaya T.S., Tikhomirov G.V.
Title: Residual energy release and actinide and fission product radiotoxicities during long-term storage of high burnup spent VVÉR fuel
Affiliations: Institute of Theoretical and Experimental Physics, State Science Center of the Russian Federation, Russian Federation

Abstract: The residual energy release and radiotoxicity of spent high burnup VVÉR-1000 fuel during long-term storage is investigated as a function of time. The contributions of α, β, γradiation and radiotoxicity-the maximum admissible activity of nuclides in air and water-are taken into account in the calculations of the energy release. The data presented can be used to develop methods for handling spent nuclear fuel from prospective power reactors. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.

Title: Automatic constants optimization and self-certification of the algorithms of the special software in the SKALA-mikro system of RBMK-1000 reactors during reactor operation

Abstract: The problems of increasing the accuracy of energy release distribution and storage monitoring up to the limits of safe operation of RBMK-1000 reactors are examined. Accuracy can be increased by automatically optimizing some constants used in the special software of the SKALA-mikro system and by periodic self-certification of the algorithm used to determine the computational error in the energy-release distribution. It is shown that tests performed by periodically scanning the core with a calibrated detector and by successively switching off the detectors give close results. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.

Authors: Panchenko A.N., Suslov A.I., Tarasenko V.F., Tel'minov A.E.
Title: Laser on mixtures of nitrogen with electronegative gases pumped by a transverse discharge from a generator with inductive energy storage: Theory and experiment
Affiliations: Institute of High Current Electronics, Siberian Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, prosp. Akademicheskii 2/3, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation

Akademicheskii 2/3, 634055 Tomsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: Lasing and discharge characteristics of a nitrogen laser pumped by a transverse discharge from a generator with an inductive energy storage and a semiconductor current interrupter are investigated experimentally. A numerical model is proposed and the operation of a nitrogen-electro-negative gas mixture laser is simulated. It is shown both theoretically and experimentally that admixtures of electronegative gases make it possible to control the laser pulse shape at the C3∏u -B3∏g transition of nitrogen. Laser pulses at a wavelength of 337.1 nm, consisting of two peaks, as well as rectangular pulses of duration 40-50 ns, are obtained in mixtures of nitrogen with NF3 and SF6 due to an increase in the electron attachment coefficient and an increase in the electric field. The output UV energy is ∼ 25 mJ. © 2007 Kvantovaya Elektronika and Turpion Ltd.

Authors: Chao P.C.-P., Sung C.-K., Wu S.-T., Huang J.-S.
Title: Nonplanar modeling and experimental validation of a spindle-disk system equipped with an automatic balancer system in optical disk drives
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Control Engineering, National Chiao-Tung University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Department of Power Mechanical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Chung-Yuan Christian University, Chung-Li 320, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Chao, P.C.-P., Department of Electrical and Control Engineering, National Chiao-Tung University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Sung, C.-K., Department of Power Mechanical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Wu, S.-T., Department of Power Mechanical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Huang, J.-S., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Chung-Yuan Christian University, Chung-Li 320, Taiwan
Abstract: Non-planar dynamic modeling and experimental validation of a spindle-disk system equipped with an automatic ball-type balancer system (ABS) in optical disc drives are performed in this study. Recent studies about planar dynamic modeling and analysis have shown the capability of the ABS in spindle-disk assembly via counteracting the inherent imbalance. To extend the analysis to be practical, non-planar dynamic modeling are conducted in this study to re-affirm the pre-claimed capability of the ABS system, along with experiments being designed and conducted to validate the theoretical findings. Euler angles are first utilized to formulate potential and kinetic energies, which is followed by the application of Lagrange's equation to derive governing equations of motion. Numerical simulations are next carried out to explore dynamic characteristics of the system. It is found that the levels of residual runout (radial vibration), as compared to those without the ABS, are significantly reduced, while the tilting angle of the rotating assembly can be kept small with the ABS installed below the inherent imbalance of the spindle-disk system. Experimental study is also conducted, and successfully validates the aforementioned theoretical findings. It is suggested that the users of the ABS need to cautiously operate the spindle motor out of the speeds close to the resonances associated with various degrees of freedom. In this way, the ABS could hold the expected capability of reducing vibration in all important directions, most importantly in radial directions. © 2006 Springer-Verlag.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Degrees of freedom (mechanics); Dynamic models; Equations of motion; Kinetic energy; Vibration analysis; Nonplanar modeling; Optical disk drives; Spindle-disk system; Optical disk storage

Title: Developing the algorithm and device for automatic connection of an out-of-phase standby power-supply system without a disruption of load powering
Authors with affiliations: Serebryakov, D.S.
Abstract: The processes of switching from an AC (50/60 Hz) main power-supply system to a standlby system in the presence of different initial phases and a certain delay in switching are considered under the following loads: an asynchronous motor and a power transformer. A new device and algorithm for switching without time delay and, consequently, without load voltage surges are proposed. Switching of power-supply systems using the proposed device and the influence of the switching time on the capacity of the energy-storage unit of the device are considered. The potentialities of a multifunctional device for connecting a standby power-supply system are described. © 2007 Allerton Press, Inc.
Index Keywords: Electric loads; Induction motors; Power transformers; Standby power systems; Switching functions; Automatic connection; Load powering; Load voltage; Standby power supply systems; Algorithms

Title: The global energy future - Part 3
Authors with affiliations: Lipták, B.
Abstract: The solar updraft tower is an energy converter that converts solar-based thermal energy into concentrated aerodynamic energy. Air is heated under a circular greenhouse-like canopy. The roof of the canopy slopes upwards from the perimeter toward the center, where the the tower stands. Sun heats the air, which rises up the lower and generates electricity by driving an array of turbine generators. The chimney of this model has a 10-meter diameter and is 195 meter tall, while the diameter of the canopy is 244 meter. This prototype operates for nine years, reaching a maximum production of 50 kW. The storage of solar energy is an important consideration as storage is required to compensate for the diurnal, seasonal, and weather-related variations in the amount of solar energy received on a unit area.
Index Keywords: Aerodynamics; Electricity; Energy conversion; Heating; Turbogenerators; Aerodynamic energy; Solar updraft tower; Weather-related variations; Solar energy

Title: Asia: Spotlight on energy: Asian East and West must make the right decisions for securing the future - El-Badri
Authors with affiliations: Salem El-Badri, A.
Abstract: Speaking at the Asian Ministerial Energy Roundtable, OPEC Secretary General El-Badri noted that the East/West relationship from the perspective of the oil market is very much complementary. By 2030, Asian oil demand is expected to rise to 43 million bpd, an increase of around 18 million bpd from today. This demand will be driven by regional economic growth in a similar manner to recent years. New refining capacities in Asia will be increasingly dependent on incremental supply from the West and thus cooperation in product movements in areas such as the physical swaps for supply and the sharing of storage infrastructure will be significant.

Title: Digital mammography for screening and diagnosis of breast cancer: An overview
Affiliations: Dpt. of Radiology, KULeuven, UZ Gasthuisberg, Leuven, Belgium; Dpt. of Radiology, KULeuven, UZ Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Van Ongeval, Ch., Dpt. of Radiology, KULeuven, UZ Gasthuisberg, Leuven, Belgium, Dpt. of Radiology, KULeuven, UZ Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Digital mammography is an emerging technique for the evaluation of the breast. Unless the low spatial resolution, the systems performs very well in diagnostic imaging because they improve lesion conspicuity through their better efficiency of absorption of x-ray photons and a linear response over a wide range of radiation intensities and the inherent high contrast resolution. With digital imaging, separation of the process of x-ray detection from the image display and storage is possible and makes optimization of each of these steps possible. In this regard, applying image processing can have a high impact on image quality. Different clinical trials are available to evaluate the accuracy of digital mammography. To control the image quality, dedicated quality parameters are developed and approved by the European Commission. However, unless the experience in diagnostic imaging with digital mammography, introduction in a screening environment still has difficulties. As telemammography is an advantage of digital imaging, practical implementation of different imaging systems in one large screening network is not solved yet. The radiologist also must be aware with the different kind of images coming from the different systems. The disadvantage of digital imaging is the high cost and the sharing of digital images with other facilities which not have a similar technology. Future technology is tomosynthesis, dual energy mammography and cone beam CT of the breast.
Index Keywords: algorithm; breast; breast cancer; clinical trial; computer assisted radiography; diagnostic accuracy; digital imaging; digital mammography; human; image display; image processing; image quality; mammography; photon; priority journal; radiologist; review; X ray; Breast Neoplasms; Data Display; Europe; Female; Humans; Image Processing, Computer-Assisted; Information Storage and Retrieval; Mammography; Mass Screening; Radiation Dosage; Radiographic Image Enhancement; Radiographic Image Interpretation, Computer-Assisted; Radiology Information Systems

Title: Effects of Pd particle size on the rates of oxygen back-spillover and CO oxidation under dynamic oxygen storage and release measurements over Pd/CeO2 catalysts
Affiliations: Heterogeneous Catalysis Laboratory, Chemistry Department, University of Cyprus, P.O. Box 20537, CY 1678 Nicosia, Cyprus
Authors with affiliations: Christou, S.Y., Heterogeneous Catalysis Laboratory, Chemistry Department, University of Cyprus, P.O. Box 20537, CY 1678 Nicosia, Cyprus; Efstathiou, A.M., Heterogeneous Catalysis Laboratory, Chemistry Department, University of Cyprus, P.O. Box 20537, CY 1678 Nicosia, Cyprus
Abstract: A kinetic mathematical model has been applied to investigate for the first time the effects of Pd particle size on the rates of oxygen back-spillover and CO oxidation during Oxygen Storage Capacity (OSC) measurements under dynamic conditions over Pd/CeO2 catalysts in the 500-700°C range. The dependence of the intrinsic rate constant k1 of the CO oxidation reaction on PdO, and that of k2app of the oxygen back-spillover from ceria to Pd/PdO on the palladium particle size was estimated by performing curve-fitting of the experimental CO and CO2 pulse transient responses obtained. Activation energies of 8.0, 9.5 and 21.1 kJ/mol were calculated for the Eley-Rideal step of CO oxidation for the 1.3, 1.8 and 16.4 nm Pd particles, respectively, supported on CeO2. The transient rates of CO oxidation and oxygen back-spillover were found to decrease with increasing Pd particle size. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
Author Keywords: CeO2; Eley-Rideal kinetics; OSC; Pd; Transient CO oxidation

Authors: Gutwirth J., Wágner T., Kotulánová E., Bezdička P., Peřina V., Hrdlička M., Vlček Mil., Drašar C., Frumar M.
Title: On RF magnetron-sputtering preparation of Ag-Sb-S thin films

Authors with affiliations: Gutwirth, J., University of Pardubice, Department of General and Inorganic Chemistry, Research Centre LC 523, Legions' Sq. 565, 53210 Pardubice, Czech Republic; Wágner, T., University of Pardubice, Department of General and Inorganic Chemistry, Research Centre LC 523, Legions' Sq. 565, 53210 Pardubice, Czech Republic; Kotulánová, E., Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, AS CR v.v.i., 25068 Husinec-Řež, Czech Republic; Bezdička, P., Institute of Inorganic Chemistry, AS CR v.v.i., 25068 Husinec-Řež, Czech Republic; Peřina, V., Nuclear Physics Institute, AC CR v.v.i., 25068 Husinec-Řež, Czech Republic; Hrdlička, M., University of Pardubice, Department of General and Inorganic Chemistry, Research Centre LC 523, Legions' Sq. 565, 53210 Pardubice, Czech Republic; Vlček, Mil., Joint Laboratory of Solid State Chemistry, University of Pardubice, Institute of Macromolecular Chemistry AS CR v.v.i., Studentska 84, 53210 Pardubice, Czech Republic; Drašar, C., University of Pardubice, Department of Physics, Studentska 84, 53210 Pardubice, Czech Republic; Frumar, M., University of Pardubice, Department of General and Inorganic Chemistry, Research Centre LC 523, Legions' Sq. 565, 53210 Pardubice, Czech Republic
Abstract: One important application area of chalcogenide materials is rewritable optical data storage. This technology is based on a reversible phase transition between the crystalline and the amorphous state and vice versa. Currently dominant materials for rewritable optical recording are Ge-Sb-Te and Ag-In-Sb-Te alloys. Material research still continues due to the need for increasing storage capacity and data rates. Polycrystalline bulks of AgSbS2 were prepared by melt-quench technique. Composition and homogeneity of these bulks were checked by scanning electron microscopy with energy dispersive X-ray analysis (SEM-EDX), crystallinity was studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD). Targets for RF magnetron sputtering were prepared from pulverized bulks by hot-pressing technique. Targets were characterized the same way as bulks. Thin Ag-Sb-S films were prepared by RF magnetron sputtering as potential candidates for rewritable optical data storage films. Composition and homogeneity of prepared thin films were characterized by SEM-EDX, Rutherford Back Scattering (RBS) and Elastic Recoil Detection Analysis (ERDA); character (amorphous/crystalline) was traced by XRD. Optical properties (spectral dependence of refractive index) were evaluated on the basis of UV-Vis-NIR spectroscopy and variable angle spectral ellipsometry (VASE). Crystallization abilities were studied by the measurement of thermal dependence of the prepared thin films optical transmission. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Liu Y., Hu J.J., Xiong Z., Wu G., Chen P.
Title: Improvement of the hydrogen-storage performances of Li-Mg-N-H system
Affiliations: Department of Physics, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117542, Singapore; Department of Chemistry, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117543, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Liu, Y., Department of Physics, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117542, Singapore; Hu, J.J., Department of Physics, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117542, Singapore; Xiong, Z., Department of Physics, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117542, Singapore; Wu, G., Department of Physics, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117542, Singapore; Chen, P., Department of Physics, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117542, Singapore, Department of Chemistry, National University of Singapore, Singapore 117543, Singapore
Abstract: Li2MgN2H2 can reversibly store more than 5.5 wt% hydrogen. However, the high activation energy of hydrogen desorption poses a kinetic barrier for low-temperature operation. In this work, the composition of the Li-Mg-N-H system has been modified by the partial substitution of Mg or Li by Na. The changes in structure and hydrogen absorption/desorption kinetics have been investigated. It was found that the peak temperature for hydrogen desorption was decreased by ∼10 °C, and that the hydrogen absorption/desorption isotherms were also significantly changed. Furthermore, the activation energy calculated by the Kissinger's approach was reduced after the substitution of Mg or Li by Na. In addition, the different dehydrogenation structures were detected at different molar ratios of Mg, Li, and Na. © 2007 Materials Research Society.
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Dehydrogenation; Desorption; Gas absorption; Hydrogen storage; Structure (composition); Kissinger's approach; Molar ratio; Lithium alloys

Title: Thyroid and leptin
Affiliations: Department of Medical Endocrinology, Rigshospitalet, National University Hospital, Copenhagen, Denmark; Department of Medical Endocrinology PE 2132, Rigshospitalet, National University Hospital, Blegdamsvej 9, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Feldt-Rasmussen, U., Department of Medical Endocrinology, Rigshospitalet, National University Hospital, Copenhagen, Denmark, Department of Medical Endocrinology PE 2132, Rigshospitalet, National University Hospital, Blegdamsvej 9, DK-2100 Copenhagen, Denmark
Abstract: Leptin, which is produced by adipocytes, is known to be an important regulator of food intake and energy storage. Disturbance of thyroid function is associated with marked changes in both body weight and energy expenditure, and it has therefore been the subject of much research to study the mutual roles of leptin and thyroid hormones in this respect. Despite intensive research in this field, results are still not very clear. The aim of this review has been to update the current state of knowledge of leptin related to thyroid pathophysiology. © Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.

Authors: Dolgachev G.I., Maslennikov D.D., Ushakov A.G., Fedotkin A.S., Khodeev I.A.
Title: Electric strength of a vacuum gap during breakdown in an inhomogeneous electric field for switching high-power pulses
Affiliations: Russian Research Centre, Kurchatov Institute, pl. Kurchatova 1, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dolgachev, G.I., Russian Research Centre, Kurchatov Institute, pl. Kurchatova 1, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Maslennikov, D.D., Russian Research Centre, Kurchatov Institute, pl. Kurchatova 1, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Ushakov, A.G., Russian Research Centre, Kurchatov Institute, pl. Kurchatova 1, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Fedotkin, A.S., Russian Research Centre, Kurchatov Institute, pl. Kurchatova 1, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation; Khodeev, I.A., Russian Research Centre, Kurchatov Institute, pl. Kurchatova 1, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: A system for matching the output of a multimodular plasma opening switch (POS) to a "liner"-type load having a small initial impedance is described. The main element of this system is an isolating spark gap that allows synchronization of the POS modules and prevents a repeated POS closure cutting off the inductive storage from the load. A spark gap based on a multigap explosive-emission diode, which was proposed and tested earlier, is insufficiently strong electrically to be used in the Baikal project aimed at the development of a superpowerful pulsed generator. An urgent problem of increasing the electrical strength of a 1-mm-wide vacuum gap, which is a basic element of the aforementioned spark gap, is being solved. It is proposed to use electrodes of the point (anode)-plane (cathode) type that allow the electric field to be concentrated at the point-type anode, thereby increasing the gap's electrical strength. The results of experiments aimed at the study of vacuum breakdown in this system of electrodes are presented. It is shown that this design allows the gap's strength to be raised by several times, a long service life of electrodes to be ensured thanks to the low energy-deposition density, and a multichannel (i.e., low-inductance) breakdown to be stably attained. A diagram of the spark-gap prototype is presented, its breakdown characteristics are obtained, and a full-scale scheme of the spark gap is presented. © Nauka/Interperiodica 2007.
Index Keywords: Electric fields; Electric spark gaps; Electrodes; Switching theory; Synchronization; Vacuum applications; Explosive emission diodes; Inhomogeneous electric field; Plasma opening switch (POS); Spark-gap prototypes; Electric breakdown

Title: Gene-diet interactions in childhood obesity: Paucity of evidence as the epidemic of childhood obesity continues to rise
Affiliations: Harokopio University, Department of Nutrition and Dietetics, 70 El. Venizelou Street, 17671 Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Papoutsakis, C., Harokopio University, Department of Nutrition and Dietetics, 70 El. Venizelou Street, 17671 Athens, Greece; Dedoussis, G.V., Harokopio University, Department of Nutrition and Dietetics, 70 El. Venizelou Street, 17671 Athens, Greece
Abstract: Childhood obesity is growing rapidly worldwide. Although there have been enormous advances in the genetic underpinnings of obesity in recent years, the pathways that lead to obesity are still not completely understood. One of the ongoing challenges is the lack of a comprehensive definition of the obese phenotype that encompasses intermediary phenotypic expressions of biological and behavioral nature. Interactions between genetic and environmental factors, including nutrient exposures and dietary behaviors, can influence the development of the obese phenotype. Specifically, genes play a decisive role in the etiology of childhood obesity under the permissive circumstances of an obesogenic environment (increase in energy intake with a decrease in physical activity). Like many diseases, the causes of obesity are complex and their investigation requires novel approaches. Given the many contributors to obesity (weight gain, weight loss, weight maintenance, variability in body composition), as well as the dynamic nature of this issue, genomic tools must continue to be employed to evaluate all dimensions of the obesity phenotype, such as biochemical characteristics, susceptibility markers, nutrient intake, feeding practices and gene-environment interactions. Fundamental knowledge of the types of genes involved and available gene-diet interaction studies in children's obesity are reviewed. Although there is a paucity of existing literature in this specific domain of childhood obesity, ongoing investigations utilizing large cohorts have potential for providing the knowledge needed for targeted interventions in the future. © 2007 Future Medicine Ltd.
Author Keywords: Children; Diet; Gene; Interaction; Obesity

Title: A farewell at Fernald
Abstract: Fernald plant cleanup celebration was held on January 19, 2007, at Ohio. About 600 former workers, current staffs, government representatives, and media personnels gathered at the former silos warehouse building that is now the Fernard site to celebrate the successful cleanups of the old Cold War uranium factory, Columbus and Ashtabula sites. Energy Secretary Samuel Bodman, US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Stephen Johnson, and Sen. George Voinovich also attended the party. The warehouse was filled with displays that represented Fernard's uranium production and cleanup missions. Fluor Fernard, the site's cleanup contractor, announced to the US Department of Energy that work was complete. He stated that about 1.5 millions tons of the most contaminated waste had been shifted offsite to Texas, Nevada, and Arizona, while 4.7 million tons were disposed of at a specially designed storage facility.
Index Keywords: Contamination; Contractors; Environmental Protection Agency; Personnel; Radioactive wastes; Uranium; Cleanup missions; Contaminated waste; Department of Energy; Plant cleanup; Industrial plants; cleanup; radioactive waste; storage tank; waste disposal; waste facility; Fernald; Hamilton County [Ohio]; North America; Ohio; United States

Title: Contractors report success with Wassara
Abstract: Contractors that are drilling in southern Sweden report success with Wassara. Malmberg Borrning AB worked on an energy storage system consisting of 35 holes to a depth of 190m, for a total of 6,650m. It was responsible for drilling and installing the heat pump facility. It has benefited from using Wassara when drilling deep in unstable rock, shale or sandstone. Another Swedish drilling contractor using Wassara is Hercules Grundläggning. The company says that Wassara has good performance such that hammer that is blocked are not problems with Wassara.

Authors: Trounov V.A., Lebedev V.T., Sokolov A.E., Grushko Yu.S., Török Gy., Van Den Heuvel J.C., Batyrev É., Yurieva T.M., Plyasova L.M.
Title: Investigation of the hydrogen capacity of composites based on ZnOCu
Affiliations: Petersburg Nuclear Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leningradskaya oblast, 188300, Russian Federation; Research Institute for Solid State Physics and Optics, Konkoly-Thege ut. 29-33, POB-49 Budapest, 1525, Hungary; Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Amsterdam, Nieuwe Achtergracht 166, Amsterdam, 1018 WV, Netherlands; Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Siberian Division, Russian Academy of Sciences, pr. Akademika Lavrent'eva 5, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Trounov, V.A., Petersburg Nuclear Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leningradskaya oblast, 188300, Russian Federation; Lebedev, V.T., Petersburg Nuclear Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leningradskaya oblast, 188300, Russian Federation; Sokolov, A.E., Petersburg Nuclear Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leningradskaya oblast, 188300, Russian Federation; Grushko, Yu.S., Petersburg Nuclear Physics Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Leningradskaya oblast, 188300, Russian Federation; Török, Gy., Research Institute for Solid State Physics and Optics, Konkoly-Thege ut. 29-33, POB-49 Budapest, 1525, Hungary; Van Den Heuvel, J.C., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Amsterdam, Nieuwe Achtergracht 166, Amsterdam, 1018 WV, Netherlands; Batyrev, É., Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Amsterdam, Nieuwe Achtergracht 166, Amsterdam, 1018 WV, Netherlands; Yurieva, T.M., Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Siberian Division, Russian Academy of Sciences, pr. Akademika Lavrent'eva 5, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation; Plyasova, L.M., Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Siberian Division, Russian Academy of Sciences, pr. Akademika Lavrent'eva 5, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russian Federation
Abstract: The composites ZnOCuH(D) saturated with hydrogen (deuterium) to a content of 1 wt % are investigated by the neutron scattering methods. Upon cooling of the samples (the ZnO matrix containing Cu crystals 10 nm in size) from 300 to 4 K, hydrogen (deuterium) is condensed on the cluster surface and penetrates inside the clusters in which the atomic hydrogen content with respect to copper can be as high as 30% at 20 K. Simultaneously, hydrogen fills nanopores of the ZnO matrix. It is revealed that, at temperatures of 90-300 K, approximately one-third of the hydrogen amount participates in the fast diffusion (the diffusion constant is approximately equal to 8 × 10-5 cm 2/s) and the other two-thirds are immobilized. At 20 K, the fraction of mobile hydrogen decreases to 10%. An analysis of the results obtained demonstrates that the energy barriers retaining hydrogen in defect regions are relatively low. © Nauka/Interperiodica 2007.
Index Keywords: Deuterium; Energy barriers; Hydrogen storage; Neutron scattering; Saturation (materials composition); Zinc oxide; Atomic hydrogen; Cluster surfaces; Hydrogen content; Composite materials

Title: Where is the energy of slow light stored?
Affiliations: Instituut voor Kern- and Stralingsfysica, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Celestijnenlaan 200 D, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium; Kazan Physical Technical Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Sibirsky Trakt 10/7, Kazan, 420029 Tatarstan, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Shakhmuratov, R.N., Instituut voor Kern- and Stralingsfysica, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Celestijnenlaan 200 D, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium, Kazan Physical Technical Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences, Sibirsky Trakt 10/7, Kazan, 420029 Tatarstan, Russian Federation; Odeurs, J., Instituut voor Kern- and Stralingsfysica, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Celestijnenlaan 200 D, B-3001 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: We analyze the energy storage process of light propagating with slow group velocity in a sample where electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT) is created by a strong coupling field. We compare the formation of slow light in EIT and in self-induced transparency (SIT). For SIT, soliton-like propagation of light with essentially reduced group velocity takes place because of the temporary storage of an appreciable part of the pulse energy in the atoms. For EIT, no energy of the probe is stored in the atoms. This energy is transformed to the coupling field and leaves the sample with phase velocity c without absorption. Slow light is formed by a low frequency coherence induced at the input by the probe and coupling fields in a two-quantum excitation process. This coherence propagates as a "spin wave" with small group velocity, and at a large distance from the input, the coherence rules the process of the energy transformation from the coupling field to the probe, reproducing exactly the temporal profile of the probe at the input. © Nauka/Interperiodica 2007.
Index Keywords: Coherent light; Energy absorption; Phase velocity; Solitons; Transparency; Electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT); Energy transformation; Group velocity; Light propagation

Title: DOE looks into possible vitrification plant at SRS
Abstract: The Department of Energy (DOE) is planning to evaluate the potential environmental impacts of a proposed plutonium vitrification plant at the Savannah River Site (SRS), in South Carolina. DOE is preparing a supplemental environmental impact statement (SEIS) for a vitrification facility for stabilizing up to 19 metric tons of surplus weapons plutonium. The plutonium will be stabilized in a lanthanide borosilicate glass packaged inside stainless steel cans placed within larger canisters. The agency also aims to construct a mixed-oxide (MOX) fuel fabrication plant at SRS to convert 34 t of surplus weapons plutonium into reactor fuel. The DOE has estimated the life-time cost of the MOX plant and associated facilities at $14 billion. The MOX plant will be built in order to meet the nation's disposition obligations under a US-Russia nonproliferation agreement. The DOE's SEIS will also evaluate the proposed disposition of plutonium materials brought to SRS for consolidated storage.

Title: Power shopping in New York City
Authors with affiliations: Mcneely, M.
Abstract: Kings Plaza Shopping Center at New York has renovated its ageing cogeneration machinery with a Total Energy Plant (TEP) Deutz TBG632 gas engine driving AvK generators with a maximum output of 3.2 MW. The new power generation equipment of TEP meets the storage techniques that matches 4610 V distribution system meant to preserve the generators. The main balance of the power plant components include Hurst heat recovery steam generators capable of producing saturated steam at 1.0 bar. The plant operates in an N plus 1 configuration due to its necessity of the high reliability factor. Each tenant in Kings Plaza is metered individually and the AvK generators handle the sub-tenant billing for 120m tenants. Kings Plaza has created a robust and flexible power plant with the new AvK generators that are capable of meeting the power demands of customers.

Title: Europe technology: Tapping into EC funding
Authors with affiliations: Nuthall, K.
Abstract: The European Commission unveiled the grants that will be made available to the oil and gas sector under its Seventh Framework Programme. Out of the total budget, a further €1.8 billion will be spent on environmental research, including new technology that reduces greenhouse gas emissions. A discussion covers priority policy areas for energy policy funding, which have relevance to the petroleum and related industries, i.e., hydrogen and fuel cells, renewable fuel production, and CO2 capture and storage technologies; research topics that calls funding; and specific calls for proposals affecting oil and gas related topics.

Title: News upstream: Storing carbon dioxide in coal beds
Abstract: Composite Energy has commissioned a two-year study to evaluate CO2 storage in coal beds. Co-funded by BG Group, ScottishPower and Royal Bank of Scotland, the £300,000 project will focus on the potential of enhancing methane recovery through storing CO2 in coal. Composite Energy is in the process of developing methane (natural gas) production from deep coal beds in Scotland. As part of the CO2 study, the company will provide horizontal drilling expertise for the long extended- reach boreholes required for the project. Strathclyde University in Glasgow will assess the gas adsorption and desorption properties of the coal, while Imperial College of London will assess the mechanical properties of the coal to model and predict the performance of a pilot scheme. While other CO2 storage projects store the gas in an underground void or rock-matrix, this project will evaluate the ability of CO2 to chemically bond to coal. Coal can typically absorb five times more CO2 than the methane it releases, indicating that this may be a very real solution for reducing greenhouse gases. The 2-yr program will focus on evaluating the direct injection of flue-gas into un-mineable coal seams in the central belt of Scotland.

Title: An improved dynamic neurocontroller based on christoffel symbols
Affiliations: Departamento de Ingeniería de Sistemas y Automática, Universidad Politécnica de Cartagena, Cartagena 30203, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Mulero-Martínez, J.I., Departamento de Ingeniería de Sistemas y Automática, Universidad Politécnica de Cartagena, Cartagena 30203, Spain
Abstract: In this paper, a dynamic neurocontroller for positioning of robots based on static and parametric neural networks (NNs) has been developed. This controller is based on Christoffel symbols of first kind in order to carry out coriolis/centripetal matrix. Structural properties of robots and Kronecker product has been taken into account to develop NNs to approximate nonlinearities. The weight updating laws have been obtained from a nonlinear strategy based on Lyapunov energy that guarantees both stability and boundedness of signals and weights. The NN weights are tuned online with no "offline learning phase"and are initialized to zero. The neurocontroller improves the implementation with respect to other dynamic NNs used in the literature. © 2007 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Christoffel symbols; Kronecker product; Lyapunov energy; Neural network (NN) controller; Position control of robots

Title: UKAEA fined £140,000 for radioactive particles offences
Abstract: The United Kimgdom Atomic Energy Authority (UKAEA) was fined on February 15 for pleading guilty at Wick Sheriff Court to four charges under the Radioactive Substances Act 1960. It admitted illegally discharging radioactive particles from its Dounreay nuclear research facility in Caithness from 1976 to 2006 causing long-lasting contamination of the seabed and local beaches. The charges include unauthorized disposals of solid radioactive waste, failure to prevent fragments of irradiated nuclear fuel being discharged, unauthorized disposal of fragments of irradiated nuclear fuel from a reactor fuel storage pond to a surface water drain between 1964 and 1967 and unauthorized disposals of solid radioactive waste to the conventional foul drainage and surface water drainage system.
Index Keywords: Beaches; Discharge (fluid mechanics); Drainage; Marine pollution; Nuclear fuels; Nuclear reactors; Radioactive waste disposal; Solid wastes

Title: Effects of gas atmosphere and temperature on the respiration rates of whole and sliced mushrooms (Agaricus bisporus) - Implications for film permeability in modified atmosphere packages
Affiliations: Food Science Research Centre, Dept. of Life Sciences, Univ. of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Cliffe-Byrnes, V., Food Science Research Centre, Dept. of Life Sciences, Univ. of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland; O'Beirne, D., Food Science Research Centre, Dept. of Life Sciences, Univ. of Limerick, Limerick, Ireland
Abstract: An open flowthrough respirometer was used to determine the respiration rates of whole and sliced mushrooms as a function of O2, CO 2, and storage temperature. Respiration rates were measured under the following O2 concentrations: 20, 15, 10, 5, and 2% at 5 temperatures (4, 8, 10, 13, and 16 °C). The effects of 5 CO2 concentrations (0, 2, 5, 10, 15%) at two O2 levels (2 and 20%) were also examined at these temperatures. Mushroom respiration increased with temperature following an Arrhenius-type relationship; activation energies and corresponding Q 10 values were calculated. Lowering the oxygen concentration significantly decreased the respiration rate. The effects of reducing O 2 levels were greater at higher storage temperatures. Both activation energies and Q10 values were lower under reduced O2 atmospheres compared with those in air. A Michaelis-Menten enzyme kinetics model was evaluated for describing the influence of gas concentrations on respiration rate. The effects of O2 fitted the O2 enzyme kinetics model well. CO2 exhibited small inhibitory effects on respiration of whole and sliced mushrooms, especially at low O2 concentrations and low temperatures. The enzyme model was used to predict respiration under an optimal modified atmosphere for mushrooms, and the required film O2 and CO2 permeabilities were defined for key pack design parameters. © 2007 Institute of Food Technologists.
Author Keywords: CO2 production; O2 consumption; Respiration modeling; Respiratory quotient; Storage temperature

Authors: Sancho A., Etxeberria J.A., Gracia F.J.
Title: 3D macroporous structures for the development of high capacitance silicon integrated microcapacitors
Affiliations: CEIT, TECNUN, University of Navarra, Manuel de Lardizábal 15, 20018 San Sebastián, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Sancho, A., CEIT, TECNUN, University of Navarra, Manuel de Lardizábal 15, 20018 San Sebastián, Spain; Etxeberria, J.A., CEIT, TECNUN, University of Navarra, Manuel de Lardizábal 15, 20018 San Sebastián, Spain; Gracia, F.J., CEIT, TECNUN, University of Navarra, Manuel de Lardizábal 15, 20018 San Sebastián, Spain
Abstract: Today, in the new MEMS scenario, self-powered microdevices are in demand. A high capacitive value microcapacitor, integrated into the microsystem itself, can fulfill the requirements of an energy storage element in an autonomous microsystem. In this work, highly doped deep macroporous structures have been developed by means of electrochemistry. These structures allow an improved area, a low series resistance and are playing a major role in establishing the bottom electrode of a high capacitance silicon integrated microcapacitor. Some first results related with the capacitance associated to some oxidized silicon macroporous structures are presented. © 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Electrochemistry; Macroporous silicon; Microcapacitors
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Electrochemistry; Energy storage; Microsystems; Macroporous structures; Silicon integrated microcapacitors; MEMS

Title: The interplay between nutrients and the adipose tissue: Plenary lecture
Affiliations: Department of Nutrition, Institute of Basic Medical Sciences, University of Oslo, Blindern, 0316 Oslo, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Haugen, F., Department of Nutrition, Institute of Basic Medical Sciences, University of Oslo, Blindern, 0316 Oslo, Norway; Drevon, C.A., Department of Nutrition, Institute of Basic Medical Sciences, University of Oslo, Blindern, 0316 Oslo, Norway
Abstract: The importance of adipose tissue in health as well as disease has been demonstrated in several studies recently, and it has become appropriate to use the term 'adipose organ' when referring to adipose tissue as a whole. The obesity epidemic, with a marked increase in the incidence of the metabolic syndrome leading to diabetes type 2 as well as cardiovascular complications, has stimulated considerable interest in adipose tissue biology. Moreover, several studies in different species have shown that limited energy intake is associated with less inflammation, improved biomarkers of health and a marked increase in longevity. In addition, there is convincing evidence that an optimal amount of adipose tissue is essential for many body functions such as immune response, reproduction and bone quality. Some nutrients and their metabolites are important as energy sources as well as ligands for many transcription factors expressed in adipose tissue, including all energy-providing nutrients both directly and indirectly as well as cholesterol, vitamin E and vitamin D. In particular, fatty acids can be effectively taken up by adipocytes and they can interact with several transcription factors crucial for growth, development and metabolic response, e.g. PPARα, -δ and -γ, sterol regulatory element-binding proteins1 and 2 and liver X receptors α and β). Moreover, glucose is also readily taken up and stored as fatty acids via lipogenesis in adipocytes. It is known that some metabolic signals released as proteins from adipose tissue (adipokines) are important for normal as well as pathological responses to the amount of energy stored in the adipose organ. The future challenge will be to understand the function of adipose tissue in energy homeostasis and the interplay with nutrients in order to be able to give optimal advice for the prevention and treatment of obesity. © 2007 The Author.
Author Keywords: Adipokines; Adipose tissue; Energy homeostasis; Fatty acids; Nutrients
