Title: The power of pressure
Affiliations: Pressure Welding Machines
Authors with affiliations: Mepsted, S., Pressure Welding Machines
Abstract: Pressure Welding Machines (PWM), a UK based rod welding company, has included low-cost welding processes, after an increase in the price of raw materials and energy. The company's P1500 hydraulically powered and electrically controlled model, is both dependable and easy to use, and eliminates the need for operator's training. The company's smaller and hydraulically powered models, the HP100 and HP200, require a supply of compressed air, and are fitted with air/hydraulic intensifier to increase the air input of 70-80 psi to 5000 psi. PWM's comprehensive range includes hand-held, bench-mounted and trolley-mounted designs, that are light and comfortable to use. The small HP30 machine provides an effortless weld on copper wire that is 0.30 to 1.80 mm in diameter and aluminum wire that is 0.30 to 2.00 mm in diameter.
Index Keywords: Alumina; Cold storage; Compressed air; Copper; Counting circuits; Personnel training; Pulse modulation; Pulse width modulation; Wire; Aluminum wires; Controlled models; Copper wires; Welding processes; Welding

Title: Systems approaches and communication research: The age of entropy
Authors with affiliations: Gunaratne, S.
Abstract: This essay examines the contemporary approaches to systems theory, the strengths and limitations of these approaches, and how communication researchers can apply them creatively. It points out that using system approaches requires communication scholars to study the mutual interaction of both information inputs and matter/energy inputs. Overloads of these inputs coupled with storage problems could engender positive feedback loops and move the system away front the linear region of stability toward the edge of chaos (bifurcation). It could then self-organize as a more complex system in a new phase space of its trajectory. This complexity approach could be used to trace the trajectory of the global mass communication system or to conduct empirical research on all or any of the information-processing subsystems within the eight hierarchical levels of nested systems ranging from cell to supranational systems. Although systems thinking is writ large in the onto-cosmology of Eastern philosophies, its epistemological and methodological refinements did not occur until quantum physics challenged the 'atomism' of the dominant Newtonian-Cartesian model. © Walter de Gruyter.
Author Keywords: Autopoiesis; Cognition; Communications research; Dependent coarising; Dissipative structures theory; Living systems theories; Social entropy theory

Title: Regas vessels put to the test
Authors with affiliations: Clark, M.
Abstract: The number of LNG tankers with onboard regasification facilities is increasing, as operators look for greater flexibility in where they can deliver their cargoes. The advantages are that gas can be delivered away from sensitive onshore areas, without the need for expensive import infrastructure. It presents a relatively quick solution to injecting more gas into the grid. In markets that have faced opposition to conventional receiving terminals, such as the US, regasification ships offer a solution. US' Excelerate Energy is the only company operating regas ships. It has three ships in operation ? the third, Excelerate, was named and delivered by Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering in October 2006. Another two are under construction. The market is also waking up to conversions. Norwegian classification society Det Norske Veritas is about to approve the world's first floating storage and regasification unit (FSRU), a converted ship, on behalf of Golar LNG. The vessel, under construction at the Keppel Shipyard, is due for delivery later in 2007. The LNG carrier Suez Matthew is also being transformed into a regasification vessel for Suez Energy for use in the US. As the market gets more comfortable with the technology, more FSRU will be built, as ship operators such as Exmar continue to push the use of regasification vessels and their alternative discharge solutions.

Title: Engineering the way back to corporate health
Abstract: Ford Research and Advanced Engineering is exploiting the emerging science of nanotechnology for the development of collision avoidance devices and hydrogen storage, battery technologies and other automotive applications. Research and Advanced Engineering is systematically networked among all Ford Motor Company brands and regions, including Europe, Asia, and the US. It designs new safety devices that protect passengers and provide a new level of occupant comfort in a Ford-made vehicles. Advanced engineers follows three specific areas of research, including safety, sustainability, and design. They works to develop efficient design that improves safety, emissions, fuel economy, materials, comfort and convenience, and power and performance of the company's cars and trucks. They are also developing many technologies that address issues, such as climate change, energy security, safety, and noise.
Index Keywords: Automotive industry; Climate change; Collision avoidance; Hydrogen storage; Nanotechnology; Safety devices; Sustainable development; Automotive applications; Energy security; Ford Research and Advanced Engineering (CO); Health care

Title: Former BMW research & development chief Burkhard Goeschel joins Maxwell technologies board of direct
Authors with affiliations: Hilton, J.
Abstract: Professor Burkhard Goeschel, Former BMW Research & Development Chief, has been appointed as a member of the six-person Management Board of BMW Group. Goeschel will have the overall responsibility for research, development, and purchasing. Dr. Richard Balanson, Maxwell's president and chief executive officer, has described Goeschel as a valuable strategic resource to management as the company accelerates development and delivery of ultracapacitor based energy storage and power delivery solutions for transportation applications. Goeschel holds a PhD degree in engineering from Stuttgart University and bachelors and masters degrees in mechanical engineering from the Technical University of Munich. Goeschel is presently serving as the professor of the Technical University in Graz, Austria, and holds a doctorate from the Technical University of Munich and is a member of the university's management board and a trustee of its Institute for Advanced Studies.
Index Keywords: Automotive industry; Mechanical engineering; Purchasing; Research and development management; Resource allocation; Strategic planning; Institute for Advanced Studies; Maxwell technologies (CO); Trustee; Professional aspects

Title: Supercapacitors as advanced energy storage devices
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Drexel University; Drexel Nanotechnology Institute
Authors with affiliations: Chmiola, J., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Drexel University; Gogotsi, Y., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Drexel University, Drexel Nanotechnology Institute
Abstract: Supercapacitors (also going by the labels ultracapacitors, or electrochemical double layer capacitors) are energy storage devices, akin to batteries, but with completely different energy storage mechanisms. They occupy a primary place among other energy storage technologies due to a number of desirable properties: they are fast charging, reliable, have a large number of recharge cycles (>100,000), are free of toxic metals, have wide operating temperatures, and most notably have the ability to deliver >10x more power than batteries and store more energy than traditional capacitors. Recently, industry has given them increased attention as viable energy solutions as their energy densities gain ground on batteries. Consumers have also increased attention as they are leaking into ever increasing markets-from vehicles, cell phones, and photocopiers to larger industrial drive systems. With novel materials coming out of labs and the intricacies of their energy storage mechanisms finally being elucidated, they may well find themselves positioned as the key energy storage technology of tomorrow.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric drives; Energy storage; Marketing; Toxic materials; Supercapacitors; Toxic metals; Capacitors

Title: Carbon nanotube-based supercapacitors
Affiliations: Nanomaterials in the Environment, Agriculture, and Technology (NEAT); University of California, Davis; Department of Textiles, University of California, Davis, CA 95616; Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Nanostructure Materials
Authors with affiliations: Du, C., Nanomaterials in the Environment, Agriculture, and Technology (NEAT), University of California, Davis; Pan, N., Department of Textiles, University of California, Davis, CA 95616, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Nanostructure Materials
Abstract: Due to the need for increased power performance, supercapacitors are emerging as an alternative to conventional electric energy storage devices. Because of their unique properties, carbon nanotubes are a promising material for next generation supercapacitors. Specifically, the use of nanotubes to construct supercapacitor electrodes can increases the power density and performance of supercapacitors relative to conventional dielectric capacitors. The authors explain different methods of constructing supercapacitors using nanostructure materials and also outline the benefits of this innovative form of energy storage.
Index Keywords: Capacitors; Electrodes; Energy storage; Supercapacitor electrodes; Supercapacitors; Carbon nanotubes

Title: Storage stability of selected agricultural grains
Source title: AMA, Agricultural Mechanization in Asia, Africa and Latin America
Affiliations: Department of Agricultural Engineering, Federal University of Technology, P.M.B. 65, Minna, Niger State, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Ajisegiri, E.S.A., Department of Agricultural Engineering, Federal University of Technology, P.M.B. 65, Minna, Niger State, Nigeria; Idah, P.A., Department of Agricultural Engineering, Federal University of Technology, P.M.B. 65, Minna, Niger State, Nigeria
Abstract: Three grains maize, sorghum and millet were stored at different levels of moisture contents 10 %, 20 %, 30 %, 40 %, 50 %, 60 %, 70 %, 80 %, 90 % and 98 % wet basis in order to determine the optimum moisture content for maximum grain stability. The effects of moisture content levels on their quality at three different temperatures levels (20 °C, 25 °C and 40 °C) were evaluated. The Rockland (1969) concept of local isotherm was used to interpret the responses of the physical properties while the free energy equation was used to evaluate the energy levels of the grains at these moisture contents. This resulted in stability curves which showed that grains equilibrated by desorption (drying) have a two point minima levels (11.40 and 18.81 % at 20 °C, 12.75 and 18.84 % at 25 °C and 15.00 and 18.48 % at 40 °C for maize; 11.46 and 18.92 % at 20 °C, 11.36 and 18.92 % at 25 °C and 12.29 and 18.62 % at 40 °C for sorghum; 13.45 and 19.81 % at 20 °C, 14.79 and 21.20 % at 25 °C and 14.25 and 20.85 % at 40 °C for millet) that gives rise to a wider safe moisture range than by adsorption (humidification). The results further revealedthat the three grains showed optimum moisture for stability above and below which deterioration takes place rapidly.
Index Keywords: Agricultural products; Crops; Desorption; Free energy; Moisture determination; Thermal effects; Free energy equations; Grain stability; Moisture range; Storage stability; Storage (materials); Zea mays

Authors: Nevdakh V.V., Ganjali M., Arshinov K.I.
Title: On the temperature model of CO2 lasers
Affiliations: B.I. Stepanov Institute of Physics, National Academy of Sciences of Belarus, prosp. Nezavisimosti 68, 220072 Minsk, Belarus; Institute ol Technical Acoustics, National Academy of Sciences of Belarus, prosp. Lyudnikova 13, 210023 Vitebsk, Belarus

Nezavisimosti 68, 220072 Minsk, Belarus; Arshinov, K.I., Institute ol Technical Acoustics, National Academy of Sciences of Belarus, prosp. Lyudnikova 13, 210023 Vitebsk, Belarus
Abstract: A refined temperature model of CO2 lasers is presented, which takes into account the fact that vibrational modes of the CO2 molecule have the common ground vibrational level. New formulas for the occupation numbers and the vibrational energy storage in individual modes are obtained as well as expressions relating the vibrational temperatures of the CO2 molecules with the excitation and relaxation rates of lower vibrational levels of modes upon excitation of the CO2 - N 2 - He mixture in an electric discharge. The character of dependences of the vibrational temperatures on the discharge current is discussed. © 2007 Kvantovaya Elektronika and Turpion Ltd.

Authors: di Valdalbero D.R., Schmitz B., Raldow W., Poireau M.
Title: European Union energy research
Affiliations: European Commission, DG Research
Authors with affiliations: di Valdalbero, D.R., European Commission, DG Research; Schmitz, B., European Commission, DG Research; Raldow, W., European Commission, DG Research; Poireau, M., European Commission, DG Research
Abstract: This article presents an extensive state of the art of the energy research conducted at European Union level between 1984 and 2006, i.e. from the first to the sixth European Community Framework Programmes (FP1-FP6) for Research, Technological Development and Demonstration (RTD&D). The FP is the main legal tool and financial instrument of EU RTD&D policy. It sets the objectives, priorities and budgets for a period of several years. It has been complemented over time with a number of policy oriented initiatives and notably with the launch of the European Research Area. FP7 will cover the period 2007-2013 and will have a total budget of more than € 50 billion. Energy has been a main research area in Europe since the founding Treaties (European Coal and Steel Community, European Atomic Energy Community-Euratom and European Economic Community), and energy RTD&D has always been a substantial part of common EU research. Nevertheless, when inflation and successive European enlargements are taken into account, over time the RTD&D effort in the field of energy has decreased significantly in relative terms. In nominal terms it has remained relatively stable at about € 500 million per year. For the next year (FP7), it is expected that energy will still represent about 10% of total EU research effort but with an annual budget of more than € 800 million per year. This article presents a detailed review of the thematic areas and budget in both European nuclear energy research (fusion and fission) and non-nuclear energy research (energy efficiency/rational use of energy, fossil fuels, CO2 capture and storage, fuel cells and hydrogen, renewable energy sources, strategic energy research/ socio-economy).
Index Keywords: Energy policy; Fossil fuels; Fuel cells; Research; Societies and institutions; Energy research; Nuclear energy; Energy policy; Fossil fuels; Fuel cells; Nuclear energy; Research; Societies and institutions; energy budget; energy efficiency; energy policy; energy use; European Union; fossil fuel; fuel cell; inflation; renewable resource

Authors: Barea R., Nieto R., Aguilera J.F.
Title: Effects of the dietary protein content and the feeding level on protein and energy metabolism in Iberian pigs growing from 50 to 100 kg body weight
Affiliations: Unidad de Nutriciòn Animal, Estaciòn Experimental del Zaidín (CSIC), Camino del Jueves s/n, 18100 Armilla, Granada, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Barea, R., Unidad de Nutriciòn Animal, Estaciòn Experimental del Zaidín (CSIC), Camino del Jueves s/n, 18100 Armilla, Granada, Spain; Nieto, R., Unidad de Nutriciòn Animal, Estaciòn Experimental del Zaidín (CSIC), Camino del Jueves s/n, 18100 Armilla, Granada, Spain; Aguilera, J.F., Unidad de Nutriciòn Animal, Estaciòn Experimental del Zaidín (CSIC), Camino del Jueves s/n, 18100 Armilla, Granada, Spain
Abstract: Nutritional requirements of the Iberian pig, a slow-growing, obese porcine breed, are not well defined and seem to differ from those of conventional or high-performing pigs. The effects of the dietary protein content and the feeding level on the utilisation of metabolisable energy (ME) and the rates of gain, protein, and fat deposition were studied with 81 Iberian castrates growing from 50 to 100 kg body weight (BW) by using the comparative slaughter technique. The animals were fed 4 diets providing 145, 120, 95, and 70 g ideal crude protein (CP) per kg dry matter (DM), and containing 13.94, 14.29, 14.56, and 14.83 MJ ME per kg DM, respectively. Three levels of feeding were evaluated: 0.60, 0.80, and 0.95 x ad libitum intake. Growth rate increased (linear and quadratic, P < 0.001) as the dietary ideal CP content decreased. It also increased with the feeding level (linear, P < 0.001; quadratic, P < 0.05). Gain:feed and gain:ME intake improved by decreasing the ideal CP content in the diet (linear, P < 0.001 and P < 0.05, respectively; quadratic P < 0.001 for both variables). Increasing the feeding level improved linearly gain:feed and gain:ME intake ( P < 0.001). Protein deposition (PD):ME intake ranged between 1.23 and 1.44 g/MJ, and it showed a tendency to reach the maximum value when the diet providing 95 g ideal CP per kg DM was fed (quadratic, P = 0.078). When this diet was offered at 0.95 x ad libitum, PD reached a maximum value of 71 g/day. This dietary treatment resulted in average values for average daily gain and retained energy (RE) of 854 g/day and 21.4 MJ/day, respectively. The average rate of gain was 19.93 g/MJ increase in ME intake, equivalent to an energy cost of 50.2 kJ ME per g gain, irrespective of the dietary ideal CP content. Also, the overall marginal efficiency of protein deposition (ΔPD:ΔME; g/MJ) was 1.34. Increasing the feeding level led to increases in PD (linear, P < 0.001) and RE (linear, P < 0.001; quadratic, P < 0.01) irrespective of the dietary ideal CP concentrations. Between 50 and 100 kg BW, the chemical composition of 1 kg gain averaged 78, 592, 28.7, and 284 g for CP, fat, ash, and water respectively. The net efficiency of use of ME for growth ( kg) and the maintenance energy requirements were 0.606 and 396 kJ/kg BW 0.75 per day, respectively. The results support earlier findings that the genotype has marked effects on protein and energy metabolism of growing pigs and underline important compositional differences of the Iberian pig compared with conventional or modern porcine genotypes. © 2007 The Animal Consortium.
Author Keywords: Energy requirement; Energy retention; Pigs; Protein requirement; Protein retention

Authors: Van Hauwermeiren A., Coene H., Engelen G., Mathijs E.
Title: Energy lifecycle inputs in food systems: A comparison of local versus mainstream cases
Source title: Journal of Environmental Policy and Planning
Affiliations: Division of Agricultural and Food Economics, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Belgium; Vredeseilanden, Leuven, Belgium; Division of Agricultural and Food Economics, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, W. de Croylaan 42, 3001 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Van Hauwermeiren, A., Division of Agricultural and Food Economics, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Belgium; Coene, H., Vredeseilanden, Leuven, Belgium; Engelen, G., Vredeseilanden, Leuven, Belgium; Mathijs, E., Division of Agricultural and Food Economics, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Belgium, Division of Agricultural and Food Economics, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, W. de Croylaan 42, 3001 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: There is increasing interest from consumers in local food systems (LFS) in which consumers purchase their food from predominantly local sources. This paper investigates the claim that LFS use less energy and emit less greenhouse gasses than mainstream food systems (MFS), such as supermarkets. We calculated the energy required during part of the lifecycle of a selected number of food items sourced by different food supply systems and their resulting greenhouse gas emissions. Data were collected from literature, interviews with producers and suppliers of food, experts, and internet. Our results show that in the base simulation of full summer season and only inland, open-air production, energy uses and carbon dioxide emissions are slightly higher in LFS compared to the MFS, but in the same order of magnitude. LFS can be more sustainable by optimizing their transport and storage through minimizing the transport distance and by increasing the stored and traded quantities. Supermarkets could be more sustainable through choosing in-season food products that are homegrown in open air as well and by minimizing distances and storage times. Also consumers could have a large impact through a consistent choice for these in-season, inland products and through their shopping trips. © 2007 Taylor & Francis.
Author Keywords: Carbon dioxide emissions; Energy; Lifecycle analysis; Local food systems; Mainstream food systems; Transport

Title: Coping with accession in Eastern Europe
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Abstract: The decision of many Central and Eastern European states to join the European Union (EU) was always going to have massive repercussions for their power sectors. The EU is encouraging new members to develop more small and mini hydro ventures. The impact of EU policy on the hydro sectors of new member states depends on two main factors: the current size and future potential of hydroelectric production in each state and the timing of their accession. Slovakia is the most hydro reliant country among the EU10. It remains to be seen if the country can create an investment climate that will encourage private sector companies to opt for hydro over thermal plants. The hydro sector is helping to improve grid reliability in Hungary, through the construction of a new 1000MW pumped storage hydroelectric power plant on the Tisza river. Pumped storage also dominates the Czech Republic's hydro sector. While some of the EU10 are approaching the end of their original power reform plans, one of the more recent additions to the EU fold is currently restructuring its entire stock of hydroelectric plants. Meanwhile, a number of direct grants and loans are offered by a variety of EU institutions to support small hydro and other renewables schemes, but most relate to the development rather than the ongoing viability of such ventures.

Authors: Andreeshchev E.A., Voǐtenko D.A., Krauz V.I., Markoliya A.I., Matveev Yu.V., Reshetnyak N.G., Khautiev É.Yu.
Title: Study of the dynamics of a plasma current sheath in the KPF-4 Phoenix plasma-focus facility
Affiliations: Sukhumi Physicotechnical Institute, Sukhumi, 384914 Abkhazia, Georgia; Nuclear Fusion Institute, Russian Research Centre Kurchatov Institute, pl. Authors with affiliations: Andreeshchev, E.A., Sukhumi Physicotechnical Institute, Sukhumi, 384914 Abkhazia, Georgia; Voǐtenko, D.A., Sukhumi Physicotechnical Institute, Sukhumi, 384914 Abkhazia, Georgia; Krauz, V.I., Nuclear Fusion Institute, Russian Research Centre Kurchatov Institute, pl. Akademicheskaya 1, Kharkiv, 61108, Ukraine; Khautiev, É.Yu., Nuclear Fusion Institute, Russian Research Centre Kurchatov Institute, pl. Kurchatova 1, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: The engineering characteristics of the KPF-4 Phoenix megajoule Mather-type plasma focus facility constructed at the Sukhumi Physicotechnical Institute are described. Results from preliminary studies of the plasma dynamics at a capacitive-storage energy of up to 700 kJ are discussed. Future experiments in KPF-4 will be oriented at technological applications and will complement the studies carried out in the 2.8-MJ Filippovtype PF-3 plasma focus facility at the Nuclear Fusion Institute of the Russian Research Centre Kurchatov Institute. © 2007 Pleiades Publishing, Ltd.

Authors: Gerasimov A.I., Zelenskii K.F., Kul'gavchuk V.V., Troshkin I.A.
Title: An transportable high-power pulse X-ray radiation source
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear and Radiation Physics, Russian Federal Nuclear Center, All-Russia Research Institute of Experimental Physics, pr. Mira 37, Nizhni Novgorod oblast, 607190, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Gerasimov, A.I., Institute of Nuclear and Radiation Physics, Russian Federal Nuclear Center, All-Russia Research Institute of Experimental Physics, pr. Mira 37, Nizhni Novgorod oblast, 607190, Russian Federation; Zelenskii, K.F., Institute of Nuclear and Radiation Physics, Russian Federal Nuclear Center, All-Russia Research Institute of Experimental Physics, pr. Mira 37, Nizhni Novgorod oblast, 607190, Russian Federation; Kul'gavchuk, V.V., Institute of Nuclear and Radiation Physics, Russian Federal Nuclear Center, All-Russia Research Institute of Experimental Physics, pr. Mira 37, Nizhni Novgorod oblast, 607190, Russian Federation; Troshkin, I.A., Institute of Nuclear and Radiation Physics, Russian Federal Nuclear Center, All-Russia Research Institute of Experimental Physics, pr. Mira 37, Nizhni Novgorod oblast, 607190, Russian Federation
Abstract: Characteristics of the pulse (∼50 ns) X-ray radiation generator with a boundary quantum energy of ∼700 keV and a dose of ∼1 R at 1 m from the target are presented. The is intended for prompt checking of the response of the studied object at its location to the radiation effect at specified time moments at an ambient temperature from +40 to -10°C and also for the x-ray radiographic monitoring (diameter of the beam focus is ∼5 mm) of positions of an object's parts behind an opaque shield. The jitter in delays of the source's response times with respect to the start pulse is < ±30 ns. The is based on an electron-beam accelerator with a pulse current of ∼80 kA. A double forming line (DFL) with glycerin insulation serves as the energy storage and former of accelerating-voltage pulses. The DFL is charged from a six-stage Marx generator for 280 ns. The charging current of the DFL internal line passes through the resistance of the prepulse plasma formed in the volume of a strong-current electron diode between its specially shaped electrodes. In order to ensure ≥20 serial startups of the without replacing anode and cathode parts, a backward diode with a massive anode and electron-beam pinching in the interelectrode gap was used. X rays are extracted into the air through a polyethylene window withstanding ≥200 source startups. The has a modular demountable structure and, hence, can be quickly dismantled and moved to a new place. The can be put into operation within ∼2 h. Two used for radiation studies since 1998 have demonstrated performance stability and ease of service. © Nauka/Interperiodica 2007.
Index Keywords: High temperature effects; Jitter; Opacity; Radiation; Radiation shielding; X ray analysis; Double forming line (DFL); Pulse X-ray radiation source; Acoustic generators

Authors: Avgustinovich V.A., Artemenko S.N., Novikov S.A., Yushkov Yu.G.
Title: Studying a gas-discharge switch of a high-power microwave compressor
Affiliations: Research Institute of Nuclear Physics, pr. Lenina 2a, Tomsk, 634050, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Avgustinovich, V.A., Research Institute of Nuclear Physics, pr. Lenina 2a, Tomsk, 634050, Russian Federation; Artemenko, S.N., Research Institute of Nuclear Physics, pr. Lenina 2a, Tomsk, 634050, Russian Federation; Yushkov, Yu.G., Research Institute of Nuclear Physics, pr. Lenina 2a, Tomsk, 634050, Russian Federation
Abstract: The results of a study of a high-pressure gas-discharge switch with a blown-through discharge gap are presented. This switch is designed for controlling the energy-storage and-extraction processes in a high-power resonance microwave compressor operating in the 10-cm wavelength region. The dependences of the amplitude stability of the compressor output pulses on the level of the switched power, pulse repetition rate, pressure of the insulating gas, composition of the gaseous mixture (N2 and SF6), blowing-through rate, and features of the discharge-gap configuration are presented. A version of the switch design with a high junction attenuation (∼40 dB) of the compressor's interference switch, which operates at a switched power of ∼160 MW at a maximum switching power of 200 Hz and an rms deviation of the output-signal amplitude of ∼2-5%, is given. © Nauka/Interperiodica 2007.
Index Keywords: Compressors; Discharge (fluid mechanics); Energy storage; Flow of gases; Microwaves; Resonance; Gas-discharge switch; Microwave compressors; Resonance microwave compressors; Switching systems

Title: Centralised materials handling makes sense for small installations as well as large
Abstract: Piovan UK has installed a centralized materials handling system at G&A Technology's training and development site at Orton Southgate near Peterborough. The system uses a 3 kW central vacuum pump and automatic filter cleaning facility, feeding 10 machine-mounted vacuum receivers. Two 200 liter capacity drying hoppers are connected to a desiccant dryer and they are available when needed. Energy usage is optimized with Piovan's Intelligent Energy Supervisor and Intelligent Material Drying so that polymers are not over-dried. Material is supplied through six vacuum wands from storage bins and its destinations are switched through a materials selection table with the outbound hoses matched through electronic identity keys to prevent mis-selection. The system, after each slug of material, automatically purges the pipe work to clear any possible contamination.

Title: Budweiser of Greenville warehouse and distribution center Piedmont, South Carolina
Abstract: Budweiser's new two-story industrial warehouse and distribution center near Greenville, South Carolina, has effectively used load-bearing precast concrete sandwich wall panels for cost-effective and energy saving operations. The contractor and the precaster, to meet the requirements of the project, have designed a loadbearing, thermally efficient, precast concrete wall panel system for the building envelope, an interior cool storage area, an interior drive-in refrigerator, an exterior office, and an exterior maintenance building. These wall panels achieve high R-values because of concrete's thermal mass and the center wythe of insulation. Low conductivity, non-corrosive, composite wythe connectors are used for shear transfer, connecting the inner and outer concrete wythes to yield a 100% composite panel. Precast concrete is also used in the executive office, training area, and sales room, in addition to the state-of-the-art warehouse and refrigeration space.
Index Keywords: Cost effectiveness; Energy conservation; Precast concrete; Refrigerators; Sandwich structures; Drive in refrigerators; Exterior maintenance buildings; Precast concrete sandwich wall panels; Precast concrete wall panel systems; Warehouses; Concrete; Cost Effectiveness; Energy Conservation; Ware Houses

Authors: Cao X., Chiang W.-J., King Y.-C., Lee Y.-K.
Title: Electromagnetic energy harvesting circuit with feedforward and feedback dc-dc PWM boost converter for vibration power generator system
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Kowloon, Hong Kong; Department of Electrical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Kowloon, Hong Kong; School of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Singapore 639798, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Cao, X., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Kowloon, Hong Kong, School of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Singapore 639798, Singapore; Chiang, W.-J., Department of Electrical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; King, Y.-C., Department of Electrical Engineering, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu 300, Taiwan; Lee, Y.-K., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Kowloon, Hong Kong
Abstract: This paper presents an integrated vibration power generator system. The system consists of a mini electromagnetic vibration power generator and a highly efficient energy harvesting circuit implemented on a minute printed circuit board and a 0.35-μm CMOS integrated chip. By introducing a feedback control into the dcdc pulsewidth modulation (PWM) boost converter with feedforward control, the energy harvesting circuit can adjust the duty ratio of the converter following the variation of the input voltage and the voltage of energy storage element to get high energy conversion efficiency. The energy harvesting circuit rectifies the input ac voltage, steps up the dc output of the rectifier by the dcdc PWM boost converter with feedforward and feedback control and stores the electric energy into a super capacitor, which can be used as a small electrical power supply for an intelligent micro sensor network. © 2007 IEEE.
Author Keywords: DC-DC pulsewidth modulation (PWM) boost converter; Energy harvesting; Integrated power generator; Micro sensor network; Vibration
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Electromagnetic waves; Energy conversion; Feedback control; Feedforward control; Machine vibrations; Printed circuit boards; Pulse width modulation; Sensor networks; Energy harvesting; Integrated power generator; PWM boost converter; Electric generators

Authors: Routimo M., Salo M., Tuusa H.
Title: Comparison of voltage-source and current-source shunt active power filters
Affiliations: Institute of Power Electronics, Tampere University of Technology, Tampere FI-33101, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Routimo, M., Institute of Power Electronics, Tampere University of Technology, Tampere FI-33101, Finland; Salo, M., Institute of Power Electronics, Tampere University of Technology, Tampere FI-33101, Finland; Tuusa, H., Institute of Power Electronics, Tampere University of Technology, Tampere FI-33101, Finland
Abstract: In recent years, active power filters have been widely studied. The research has mainly concentrated on voltage-source active filters, but some attention has also been paid to an alternative - to current-source active filters. Since voltage-source pulsewidth modulation (PWM) technology is widely used in industrial applications, this has also been more common in active filter use. In addition, current-source technology has been said to have drawbacks compared to voltage-source systems, such as high on-state losses in the PWM bridge and inefficient inductive energy storage element on the dc side of the bridge. In the paper, the two active filter topologies are compared. First, the main circuits and space-vector modulation techniques used are studied and the digital control systems are presented. The filtering performances of the systems with different kinds of nonlinear load are examined and finally the power losses of the active filters are studied. The comparison is based on measurements with the prototypes built. The results clearly show the properties of the active filters examined. In addition, the results prove that current-source active filters also offer a considerable choice for harmonic filtering. © 2007 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Current-source active filters (CSAPFs); Pulse width modulation (PWM); Voltage-source active filters (VSAPFs)
Index Keywords: Digital control systems; Electric currents; Electric losses; Electric potential; Pulse width modulation; Current-source active filters; Harmonic filtering; Space-vector modulation; Voltage-source active filters; Active filters

Authors: Keane A., Denny E., O'Malley M.
Title: Quantifying the impact of connection policy on distributed generation
Affiliations: School of Electrical, Electronic and Mechanical Engineering, University College Dublin, Dublin 4, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Keane, A., School of Electrical, Electronic and Mechanical Engineering, University College Dublin, Dublin 4, Ireland; Denny, E., School of Electrical, Electronic and Mechanical Engineering, University College Dublin, Dublin 4, Ireland; O'Malley, M., School of Electrical, Electronic and Mechanical Engineering, University College Dublin, Dublin 4, Ireland
Abstract: Increasing connections for distributed generation (DG), and in particular, for wind generation, are being sought in power systems across the world. These increased applications present a significant challenge to the existing connection policies of distribution network operators. In particular, nonfirm access to the network has been proposed as a method to increase the penetration of DG. The impact of the connection policies arising from nonfirm access are investigated in detail here. The Irish system is used as a case study, and with reference to the available energy resource and network parameters, the costs and benefits of DG are determined under a number of planning policies. The costs and benefits assessed include connection and cycling costs along with emissions, capacity value, and fuel bill saving. It is shown that a significant increase in the net benefits of DG is gained if the appropriate connection policy is utilized from the outset, and conversely, significant costs are incurred if ad hoc policies are employed. Furthermore, it is shown that nonfirm access has the scope to facilitate a significant extra amount of DG capacity. © 2007 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Costs; Dispersed storage and generation; Energy resources; Linear programming; Power distribution planning; Power system economics; Wind power generation
Index Keywords: Economics; Electric power generation; Electric power systems; Energy policy; Energy resources; Linear programming; Power generation; Dispersed storage and generation; Distributed generation (DG); Power distribution planning; Power system economics; Wind power

Title: Drilling advances
Abstract: Stick-slip drilling is defined as energy storage in a moving system that, when released, results in some system component reaching forward at high velocity only to stop again shortly thereafter, which amounts to several problems. The bit stops rotating in the hole, in stick-slip drilling, because of excessive friction at the rock face or on some BHA components. There are ways to identify stick-slip during drilling, and one is through the use of monitoring devices on the surface. The sine wave of amperage versus time can show the stick-slip, if the monitoring device takes voltage readings frequently. Rotary tables can sometimes speed up and slow down in response to stick-slip with a growling sound which indicates increased rotary torque and an RPM counter can show a cyclic decrease/increase in rotary speed, which in turn indicates stick-slip. The second method involves the use of less aggressive bits, which provide less wear and tear.

Authors: Gbaruko B.C., Igwe J.C., Gbaruko P.N., Nwokeoma R.C.
Title: Gas hydrates and clathrates: Flow assurance, environmental and economic perspectives and the Nigerian liquified natural gas project
Source title: Journal of Petroleum Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Industrial Chemistry, Abia State University, P.M.B. 2000, Uturu, Abia State, Nigeria; Riejom Chemical Industries Nigeria Limited, 184 Aba/Owerri Road, Aba, Abia State, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Gbaruko, B.C., Department of Industrial Chemistry, Abia State University, P.M.B. 2000, Uturu, Abia State, Nigeria; Igwe, J.C., Department of Industrial Chemistry, Abia State University, P.M.B. 2000, Uturu, Abia State, Nigeria; Gbaruko, P.N., Riejom Chemical Industries Nigeria Limited, 184 Aba/Owerri Road, Aba, Abia State, Nigeria; Nwokeoma, R.C., Department of Industrial Chemistry, Abia State University, P.M.B. 2000, Uturu, Abia State, Nigeria
Abstract: Gas hydrates are nonstoichiometric crystalline compounds that belong to the inclusion group known as clathrates. They occur when water molecules attach themselves together through hydrogen bonding and form cavities which can be occupied by a single gas or volatile liquid molecule. Gas hydrates, asphaltenes and waxes are three major threats to flow assurance that must be well assessed by design team uptime. Gas hydrates are also looked upon as a future energy source and as a potential climate hazard. The purpose of this review is to show the chemistry and mechanism of gas hydrate formation, the problems they pose, especially to flow assurance, their system implications, their environmental and economic perspectives with respect to their prospects as storage and transport alternative to the liquefied natural gas technology. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Gertmar L., Liljestrand L., Lendenmann H.
Title: Wind energy powers-that-be successor generation in globalization
Affiliations: Department of SECRC/PT, ABB Corporate Research, S-72178 Västerås, Sweden; Lund University, LTH/IEA, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Gertmar, L., Department of SECRC/PT, ABB Corporate Research, S-72178 Västerås, Sweden, Lund University, LTH/IEA, S-221 00 Lund, Sweden; Liljestrand, L., Department of SECRC/PT, ABB Corporate Research, S-72178 Västerås, Sweden; Lendenmann, H., Department of SECRC/PT, ABB Corporate Research, S-72178 Västerås, Sweden
Abstract: After a historic introduction, today's wind power technology is reviewed on a systems level, with some details, and with some brave suggestions for wind technology 2030 when power electronics (PE) will be some 2000 GW. Eternal themes like "electricity storage"are avoided. Aspects of drive-trains in towers and collection grids in parks are concisely described in the paper's core, including: 1) a power circuit scheme eliminating mechanical stress in geared drive-trains at grid faults and low-voltage ride-through (LVRT); 2) a brushless drive-train with partly rated PE;.3) a clarification of transients in cable collection grids including causes, prevention, and mitigation; and 4) details of interactions between PE and cables at faults. IEEE members are challenged to meet emerging demands, and to host future renewable energy (RE) conversion with education, standards, R&D, and wind system coordination, defined well above automation. © 2007 IEEE.

Title: Closing the fuel carbon cycle
Authors with affiliations: Powicki, C.R.; Wilson, T.
Abstract: The complex economic, environmental, institutional, and social challenges associated with the closing of fuel carbon loop on a massive scale and in a timely manner are discussed. It is believed that integrated carbon capture and control systems will be used that will be made of a number of individual technology components that are currently in different stages of development. Numerous issues such as regulation, liability, risk perception, and public acceptance need to be resolved before carbon dioxide capture and storage can be applied on the massive scale required to affect atmospheric concentrations and potential climate change. Reducing the costs of these systems and their impact on energy conversion efficiency is critical because applying the present technologies is projected to increase the cost of electricity. Companies planning for future CCS retrofitting could reap long-term benefits, incorporating these systems in plant design and asset management plans.

Title: IP Week: Dinner: Energy for the future generations
Affiliations: Royal Dutch Shell
Authors with affiliations: Van Der Veer, J., Royal Dutch Shell
Abstract: Addressing the IP Week Dinner, Jeroen van der Veer, Chief Executive, Royal Dutch Shell, reflected on the connection between food prices and biofuels. With partners Choren and Iogen, the company is developing ways to produce second generation biofuels from residues like straw and wood chips. Solar and wind energy together provide ∼ 0.15% of the world's total primary energy consumption. Biofuels add 450,000 boe/day, or ∼ 0.2%. A major part of the remainder is made up of nuclear energy. If the UK would fit 20 million roofs each with 4 sq m of standard silicon-based solar panels, this would generate less full time equivalent power than a typical power station fired by gas or coal, or no more than 1% of UK electricity capacity. As for wind energy, the London Array offshore wind farm that Shell is a partner in, will have up to 341 wind turbines, generating the equivalent of about 1% of the UK's electricity demand. A more useful approach might be to invest in a combination of clean coal techniques, such as coal gasification and coal-to-liquids. Also included is the capturing and underground storage of CO2. The best way to mitigate CO2 emissions is not to emit them. Gains may be made at the well, in car engines, in manufacturing industries, etc. The possibilities to save energy are legion and not to restricted to the energy industry.

Authors: Dimakou C.P., Kiokias S.N., Tsaprouni I.V., Oreopoulou V.
Title: Effect of processing and storage parameters on the oxidative deterioration of oil-in-water emulsions
Affiliations: Laboratory of Food Chemistry and Technology, School of Chemical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Iroon Politechniou, 9, 15780, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Dimakou, C.P., Laboratory of Food Chemistry and Technology, School of Chemical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Iroon Politechniou, 9, 15780, Athens, Greece; Kiokias, S.N., Laboratory of Food Chemistry and Technology, School of Chemical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Iroon Politechniou, 9, 15780, Athens, Greece; Tsaprouni, I.V., Laboratory of Food Chemistry and Technology, School of Chemical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Iroon Politechniou, 9, 15780, Athens, Greece; Oreopoulou, V., Laboratory of Food Chemistry and Technology, School of Chemical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Iroon Politechniou, 9, 15780, Athens, Greece
Abstract: The effect of storage temperature, pH, and homogenization pressure on the oxidative deterioration of Tween 20 and sodium caseinate sunflower oil-in-water emulsions was studied by monitoring conjugated dienes (CD), lipid hydroperoxides (LH), and thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARs). CD increased linearly with storage time, and the rate constant was temperature dependent according to the Arrhenius equation with an activation energy equal to 37.5 kJ mol -1. The increase in LH and TBARs with temperature (5-60°C) was in good agreement with CD variation. Tween-stabilized emulsions oxidized faster as pH increased from 3 to 7, whereas a different behavior was observed in emulsions stabilized with sodium caseinate or a mixture of both emulsifiers. A change of homogenization pressure (30-900 bars), reflecting variation of emulsion average droplet size, had no effect on the oxidative stability of the emulsions. © Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 2007.
Author Keywords: Emulsion oxidation; Homogenization pressure; pH; Processing parameters; Temperature
Index Keywords: Helianthus

Title: Oman pharma wins European approval
Affiliations: Interpharmalink AG, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Lüderwald, I., Interpharmalink AG, Switzerland; Müller, M., Interpharmalink AG, Switzerland
Abstract: The business environment in the Gulf region offers a wide spectrum of unparalleled strategic advantages for drug manufacturing ranging from highly experienced specialists and excellent-infrastructure to low labour, energy and tax costs. In this context, an Omani investor has built a-pharmaceutical contract manufacturing facility in the Sultanate of Oman that has received EU regulatory approval. It is anticipated this will promote strengthened industrial relationships between Europe and the Gulf region, with European pharmaceutical companies now having the opportunity to benefit from this first and unique approved manufacturing site in the area for their local products or the supply into Europe.

Title: Tank construction on a two-week cycle
Authors with affiliations: Banyay, L.
Abstract: The construction of three full-containment LNG storage tanks in Cameron representing the first new LNG receipt terminals in North America in more than 20 years, is discussed. These tanks will store the LNG received via tanker before entering the US energy market in gaseous form. The project will have the capacity to regasify up to 1 and half billion cubic feet of natural gas per day. The wall across section batteries at one-third of the final wall height runs vertically to the top with constant thickness. Each tank was started one month apart with the mat foundations and the wall scheduled at 36 weeks per tank. One additional tank will be built to increase production capacity in the years ahead.

Authors: Rafique M.S., Khaleeq-Ur-Rahman M., Aziz-Ul-Rehman, Siraj K., Khan M.F.
Title: Laser-produced copper ion energy spectrum employing Thomson scattering technique
Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore, 54890, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Rafique, M.S., Department of Physics, University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore, 54890, Pakistan; Khaleeq-Ur-Rahman, M., Department of Physics, University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore, 54890, Pakistan; Aziz-Ul-Rehman, Department of Physics, University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore, 54890, Pakistan; Siraj, K., Department of Physics, University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore, 54890, Pakistan; Khan, M.F., Department of Physics, University of Engineering and Technology, Lahore, 54890, Pakistan
Abstract: Investigations were performed on laser-assisted ion emission when a copper target was irradiated with a Nd:YAG laser (1.064 μm 10 mJ and 1.1 MW). Charge states present in the ion core emitted from plasma were determined employing Faraday cup arrangement using a four-channel 500 MHz Digital Storage Oscilloscope YOKOGAWA DL 1740. The Thomson parabola scattering (TPS) technique was used to measure the energy of ions emitted from plasma. Singly charged positive ions were found to be in excessive amount. For the energy analysis, the ion beam was collimated using a pinhole arrangement. The collimated beam was then made to pass through a uniform magnetic field of 0.4 T. A solid-state nuclear track detector PM-355 was used to register the ion tracks. The energy of ions, found to be in the range of 9-50 keV. The ion energy spectra d 2 N/d2N/dEdΩ show a decreasing trend with increasing ion energy. The empirical relation dN/dE ∞ E -n fits well with the experimental data at higher values of energy, i.e., greater than 20 keV. © Nauka/Interperiodica 2007.
Index Keywords: Copper; Laser applications; Light scattering; Magnetic storage; Optical collimators; Targets; Energy analysis; Energy spectrum; Ion energy; Thomson parabola scattering (TPS); Ion beams

Title: Whatever happened to TMI-2, and other nuclear waste issues
Abstract: The American Nuclear Society (ANS) Winter Meeting sponsored by ANS Decommissioning, Decontainment, and Reutilizing (DD&R) Division, held at Albuquerque, N.M., focused on Three Mile Island-2 (TMI-2) plant in Pennsylvania and other nuclear waste issues. The winter meet reported that the TMI-2 plant is expected to maintain postdefueling monitored storage (PDMS) status till 2014 and the decommissioning of the plant is planned between 2012 and 2014. The challenges such as alphas from damaged fuel, high radiation containment areas, and high level of strontium-90, are overcome in the TMI-2 decommissioning. The Global Nuclear Energy Partnership (GNEP) program of ANS focuses on clean and green nuclear fuels and creating a sustainable energy source. The ANS meet found that the Natonal Council on Radiation Protection and Measurements' (NCRP) report focuses on nuclear waste issues such as dose-based and risk-based approach for protection of public health.

Title: Hydrogen storage and distribution systems
Source title: Mitigation and Adaptation Strategies for Global Change
Affiliations: Department of Environment, Energy and Mobility, Abt. 138 Hydrogen and Energy, EMPA Materials Sciences and Technology, Überlandstrasse 129, Dübendorf 8600, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Züttel, A., Department of Environment, Energy and Mobility, Abt. 138 Hydrogen and Energy, EMPA Materials Sciences and Technology, Überlandstrasse 129, Dübendorf 8600, Switzerland
Abstract: Hydrogen storage and transportation or distribution is closely linked together. Hydrogen can be distributed continuously in pipelines or batch wise by ships, trucks, railway or airplanes. All batch transportation requires a storage system but also pipelines can be used as pressure storage system. Hydrogen exhibits the highest heating value per weight of all chemical fuels. Furthermore, hydrogen is regenerative and environment friendly. There are two reasons why hydrogen is not the major fuel of toady's energy consumption: First of all, hydrogen is just an energy carrier. And, although it is the most abundant element in the universe, it has to be produced, since on earth it only occurs in the form of water. This implies that we have to pay for this energy, which results in a difficult economic task, because since the industrialization we are used to consuming energy for free. The second difficulty with hydrogen as an energy carrier is the low critical temperature of 33 K, i.e. hydrogen is a gas at room temperature. For mobile and in many cases also for stationary applications the volumetric and gravimetric density of hydrogen in a storage system is crucial. Hydrogen can be stored by six different methods and phenomena: high pressure gas cylinders (up to 800 bar), liquid hydrogen in cryogenic tanks (at 21 K), adsorbed hydrogen on materials with a large specific surface area (at T < 100 K), absorbed on interstitial sites in a host metal (at ambient pressure and temperature), chemically bond in covalent and ionic compounds (at ambient pressure), oxidation of reactive metals e.g. Li, Na, Mg, Al, Zn with water. These metals easily react with water to the corresponding hydroxide and liberate the hydrogen from the water. Finally, the metal hydroxides can be thermally reduced to the metals in a solar furnace. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, B.V.
Author Keywords: Hydrogen; Metal hydride; Storage; Synthetic fuel
Index Keywords: distribution system; fuel consumption; gas pipeline; gas storage; gravimetry; hydrogen; industrialization; transportation system

Title: {A figure is presented}Single-Gene Autosomal Recessive Disorders and Prader-Willi Syndrome: An Update for Food and Nutrition Professionals{A figure is presented}
Source title: Journal of the American Dietetic Association
Authors with affiliations: Isaacs, J.S.; Zand, D.J.
Abstract: This review is an update for food and nutrition professionals about single-gene autosomal recessive disorders and Prader-Willi syndrome. These disorders highlight the application of new genetic tools for screening newborns for conditions managed by medical nutrition therapy. Early detection and dietary treatment have been crucial since the 1960s for patients diagnosed with phenylketonuria. The same concept of reducing the dietary substrate that accumulates in disease is applied today for some conditions difficult to diagnose a decade ago. More than 6,000 human single-gene disorders have been identified to date, including more than 100 protein-based metabolic disorders. Tandem mass spectrometry has facilitated newborn screening for more disorders at low cost and high speed. Presently, screening newborns for 29 disorders is recommended in the United States and many states are doubling or tripling the number of tests offered in their screening programs. Complex dietary therapies have evolved for rare disorders, such as fatty acid oxidation, urea cycle, organic acid metabolism, glycogen storage, and energy production. Diagnosis-specific therapy may challenge routine dietary recommendations, such as encouraging fatty and sugary foods or avoiding fruits and milk, and treatment options have spawned a market in special formulas and substitute foods; recommended references and Web sites are provided to assist food and nutrition professionals in navigating this territory. Single-gene autosomal recessive disorders have increased the need for, and created opportunities for, food and nutrition professionals, especially those who enjoy biochemistry. © 2007 American Dietetic Association.
Index Keywords: genetic screening; genetics; human; inborn error of metabolism; mass spectrometry; methodology; newborn; newborn screening; nutritional disorder; Prader Willi syndrome; review; Genetic Screening; Humans; Infant, Newborn; Mass Spectrometry; Metabolism, Inborn Errors; Neonatal Screening; Nutrition Disorders; Prader-Willi Syndrome

Authors: Pinchasov Y., Porat R., Zur B., Dubinsky Z.
Title: Photoacoustics: A novel tool for the determination of photosynthetic energy storage efficiency in phytoplankton
Affiliations: Mina and Everard Goodman Faculty of Life Sciences, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan 52900, Israel; Central Laboratory, Mekorot National Water Company, Nazareth-Illit 17105, Israel; Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Pinchasov, Y., Mina and Everard Goodman Faculty of Life Sciences, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan 52900, Israel; Porat, R., Central Laboratory, Mekorot National Water Company, Nazareth-Illit 17105, Israel; Zur, B., Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Technion, Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa, Israel; Dubinsky, Z., Mina and Everard Goodman Faculty of Life Sciences, Bar-Ilan University, Ramat-Gan 52900, Israel
Abstract: Photosynthetic energy storage efficiency controls the development and decline of phytoplankton biomass. All abiotic environmental factors such as light intensity; temperature, nutrient availability and pollutants will exert detectable changes in the photosynthetic energy storage efficiency of phytoplankton, and subsequently affect total biomass and composition of phytoplankton assemblages. Since this efficiency is a sensitive amplifier of ambient conditions, it thereby is an excellent reporter of water quality parameter. We demonstrate the applicability of the novel photoacoustic method in easily and directly estimating the energy storage efficiency of phytoplankton in a drinking water reservoir of different nutrient status. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media B.V.
Author Keywords: Nutrients; Photoacoustics; Photosynthesis; Phytoplankton
Index Keywords: Biomass; Environmental impact; Nutrition; Photoacoustic effect; Plants (botany); Thermal effects; Water quality; Light intensity; Nutrient availability; Photosynthetic energy storage efficiency; Phytoplanktons; Photosynthesis; biomass; carbon fixation; community composition; drinking water; environmental factor; nutrient availability; photosynthesis; phytoplankton; reservoir

Title: Evaluation of energy efficient design strategies for different climatic zones: Comparison of thermal performance of buildings in temperate-humid and hot-dry climate
Affiliations: Faculty of Architecture, Istanbul Technical University, Taskisla, Taksim, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Yilmaz, Z., Faculty of Architecture, Istanbul Technical University, Taskisla, Taksim, Turkey
Abstract: Since the Kyoto protocol signed in December 1997 the majority of governments around the world have committed themselves to reducing the emission of the greenhouse gases. Thus, efficient use of energy and sustainability has become a key issue for the most energy policies. Sustainability and energy saving terms take place in building construction industry too since buildings are one of the most significant energy consumers. It is known that heating energy demand of a building has a great rate in building total energy consumption. In addition to that, the most of the heating energy has been lost from building envelope. TS 825, Heating Energy Conservation Standard for Buildings in Turkey, aims the reducing of heat loss in buildings through the envelope. But within buildings, one of the fastest growing sources of new energy demand is cooling and especially in hot-humid and hot-dry climatic parts of Turkey cooling season is much longer than the heating season. Moreover in hot-dry climate heat storage capacity of the envelope becomes more important issue than heat insulation for energy efficiency of the building. Since the Turkish standard is considering only heating energy conservation by using degree-day concept, Istanbul and Mardin are considered in the same zone, however those are in temperate-humid and hot-dry climatic zones, respectively. In this study energy efficient design strategies for these climatic zones have been explained and thermal performance of two buildings, which are constructed according to the TS 825 in Mardin and Istanbul cities were evaluated to show the importance of thermal mass in hot-dry climates. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Climate change; Construction industry; Energy efficiency; Energy policy; Energy utilization; Greenhouse effect; Strategic planning; Sustainable development; Heating energy demand; Hot-dry climate heat storage capacity; Hot-dry climates; Kyoto protocol; Structural design

Title: Economic feasibility of thermal energy storage systems
Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, King Abdulaziz University, P. O. Box 80204, Jeddah, 21589, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Habeebullah, B.A., Faculty of Engineering, King Abdulaziz University, P. O. Box 80204, Jeddah, 21589, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: This paper investigates the economic feasibility of both building an ice thermal storage and structure a time of rate tariff for the unique air conditioning (A/C) plant of the Grand Holy Mosque of Makkah, Saudi Arabia. The features of the building are unique where the air-conditioned 39,300 m2 zone is open to the atmosphere and the worshippers fully occupy the building five times a day, in addition hundreds of thousands of worshippers attend the blessed weekend's prayer at noontime, which escalates the peak electricity load. For economic analysis, the objective function is the daily electricity bill that includes the operation cost and the capital investment of the ice storage system. The operation cost is function of the energy imported for operating the plant in which the tariff structure, number of operating hours and the ambient temperature are parameters. The capital recovery factor is calculated for 10% interest rate and payback period of 10 years. Full and partial load storage scenarios are considered. The results showed that with the current fixed electricity rate (0.07 $/kWh), there is no gain in introducing ice storage systems for both storage schemes. Combining energy storage and an incentive time structured rate showed reasonable daily bill savings. For base tariff of 0.07 $/kWh during daytime operation and 0.016 $/kWh for off-peak period, savings were achieved for full load storage scenario. Different tariff structure is discussed and the break-even nighttime rate was determined (varies between 0.008 and 0.03 $/kWh). Partial load storage scenario showed to be unattractive where the savings for the base structured tariff was insignificant. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Cooling load; Economic analysis; Ice storage; Religious building
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Electric loads; Energy conservation; Energy efficiency; Energy storage; Environmental engineering; Cooling loads; Ice storage; Operation costs; Tariff structure; Religious buildings

Authors: Şencan A., Kizilkan O., Bezir N.C., Kalogirou S.A.
Title: Different methods for modeling absorption heat transformer powered by solar pond
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Education, Technical Education Faculty, Süleyman Demirel University, 32260 Isparta, Turkey; Department of Physics, Science-Literature Faculty, Süleyman Demirel University, 32260 Isparta, Turkey; Department of Mechanical Engineering, Higher Technical Institute, P.O. Box 20423, Nicosia, 2152, Cyprus
Authors with affiliations: Şencan, A., Department of Mechanical Education, Technical Education Faculty, Süleyman Demirel University, 32260 Isparta, Turkey; Kizilkan, O., Department of Mechanical Education, Technical Education Faculty, Süleyman Demirel University, 32260 Isparta, Turkey; Bezir, N.C., Department of Physics, Science-Literature Faculty, Süleyman Demirel University, 32260 Isparta, Turkey; Kalogirou, S.A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Higher Technical Institute, P.O. Box 20423, Nicosia, 2152, Cyprus
Abstract: Solar ponds are a type of solar collector used for storing solar energy at temperature below 90°C. Absorption heat transformers (AHTs) are devices used to increase the temperature of moderately warm fluid to a more useful temperature level. In this study, a theoretical modelling of an absorption heat transformer for the temperature range obtained from an experimental solar pond with dimensions 3.5 × 3.5 × 2 m is presented. The working fluid pair in the absorption heat transformer is aqueous ternary hydroxide fluid consisting of sodium, potassium and caesium hydroxides in the proportions 40:36:24 (NaOH:KOH:CsOH). Different methods such as linear regression (LR), pace regression (PR), sequential minimal optimization (SMO), M5 model tree, M5′ rules, decision table and back propagation neural network (BPNN) are used for modelling the absorption heat transformer. The best results were obtained by the back propagation neural network model. A new formulation based on the BPNN is presented to determine the flow ratio (FR) and the coefficient of performance (COP) of the absorption heat transformer. The BPNN procedure is more accurate and requires significantly less computation time than the other methods. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Absorption heat transformers; Back propagation neural network; Decision table; M5 model tree; M5′ rules; Pace regression; SMO; Solar ponds
Index Keywords: Absorption; Backpropagation; Decision tables; Energy storage; Neural networks; Solar ponds; Absorption heat transformers (AHT); Back propagation neural networks; Model trees; Pace regression (PR); Sequential minimal optimization (SMO); Energy conversion

Authors: Huang M.-C., Chen B.-R., Hsiao M.-J., Chen S.-L.
Title: Application of thermal battery in the ice storage air-conditioning system as a subcooler
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Nan-Kai Institute of Technology, No.568 Chung Cheng Road, Tsao Tun, Nan Tou, 54243, Taiwan; Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University, No.1, Sec. 4 Roosevelt Road, Taipei, 10617, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Huang, M.-C., Department of Electrical Engineering, Nan-Kai Institute of Technology, No.568 Chung Cheng Road, Tsao Tun, Nan Tou, 54243, Taiwan; Chen, B.-R., Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University, No.1, Sec. 4 Roosevelt Road, Taipei, 10617, Taiwan; Hsiao, M.-J., Department of Electrical Engineering, Nan-Kai Institute of Technology, No.568 Chung Cheng Road, Tsao Tun, Nan Tou, 54243, Taiwan; Chen, S.-L., Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University, No.1, Sec. 4 Roosevelt Road, Taipei, 10617, Taiwan
Abstract: This article experimentally investigates the thermal performance of a thermal battery used in the ice storage air-conditioning system as a subcooler. The thermal battery utilizes the superior heat transfer characteristics of two-phase closed thermosyphon and eliminates the drawbacks found in convectional energy storage systems. Experimental investigations are first conducted to study the thermal behavior of thermal battery under different charge temperatures (-5 °C to -9 °C) in which water is used as the energy storage material. This study also examines the thermal performance of the subcooled ice storage air conditioner under different cooling loads. Experimental data of temperature variation of water, ice fraction, refrigerant mass flow rate and coefficient of performance (COP) are obtained. The results show that supercooling phenomenon appears in the water and it can be ended when the charge temperature is lower than -6 °C. The system gives 28% more cooling capacity and 8% higher COP by the contribution of the thermal battery used as a subcooler. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd and IIR.
Author Keywords: Air conditioning; Experiment; Ice tank; Subcooling; Thermal storage
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Heat convection; Heat transfer; Ice; Thermal conductivity; Coefficient of performance (COP); Ice storage; Ice tank; Thermal battery; Thermal storage; Electric batteries

Authors: Böyükata M., Özdoǧan C., Güvenç Z.B.
Title: An investigation of hydrogen bonded neutral B4Hn (n = 1-11) and anionic B4 H11(- 1) clusters: Density functional study
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Erciyes University, 66100 Yozgat, Turkey; Department of Computer Engineering, Çankaya University, Balgat, 06530 Ankara, Turkey; Department of Electronic and Communication Engineering, Çankaya University, Balgat, 06530 Ankara, Turkey
Authors with affiliations: Böyükata, M., Department of Physics, Erciyes University, 66100 Yozgat, Turkey; Özdoǧan, C., Department of Computer Engineering, Çankaya University, Balgat, 06530 Ankara, Turkey; Güvenç, Z.B., Department of Electronic and Communication Engineering, Çankaya University, Balgat, 06530 Ankara, Turkey
Abstract: In this study, detailed analysis of the structural stability of hydrogen bonded four-atom boron clusters within the framework of density functional theory (DFT) is presented. Effects of the number of hydrogen atoms on the structural stability of B4, binding energy of the clusters, and also on the boron-hydrogen binding energy are investigated. Attention is also paid to the determination of energetically the most stable geometries of B4Hn (n = 1-11) boron hydrides, and to their isomers. The lower-lying electronic states of the B4Hn structures are investigated. In addition natural electron configurations of the most stable clusters and charge transfer between the atoms in the cluster are also analyzed. Furthermore, the stability of anionic form of B4 H11(- 1) cluster is examined. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Boron; Boron hydrides; Cluster compounds; Density functional calculations; Hydrogen storage

Title: Why boron nitride nanotubes are preferable to carbon nanotubes for hydrogen storage?. An ab initio theoretical study
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Crete, P.O. Box 1470, 71409 Heraklion, Crete, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Mpourmpakis, G., Department of Chemistry, University of Crete, P.O. Box 1470, 71409 Heraklion, Crete, Greece; Froudakis, G.E., Department of Chemistry, University of Crete, P.O. Box 1470, 71409 Heraklion, Crete, Greece
Abstract: Using ab initio calculations we investigated the hydrogen storage in single-walled boron nitride nanotubes. We present the nature of hydrogen interaction in selected sites of a (5,5) and (9,9) BN nanotube. Our results show that BN nanotubes are preferable to carbon nanotubes for hydrogen storage applications due to their heteropolar binding nature of their atoms. In addition, by increasing the nanotube's diameter - decreasing its curvature, more efficient binding energies of hydrogen can be achieved. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Ab initio; BN nanotubes; Carbon nanotubes; Hydrogen storage; Physisorption

Title: General interest: Energy Sec. Bodman outlines US energy goals
Authors with affiliations: Dittrick, P.
Abstract: US Secretary of Energy Samuel W. Bodman and Mississippi Governor Haley Barbour wants to designate Richton, MS, as a new site for the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve. This new site, in conjunction with an expansion at two of the existing SPR sites, will increase the emergency stocks to 1 billion bbl, according to Bodman. Existing SPR sites are in Texas and Louisiana. A sixth storage project is planned to bring the total capacity to 1.5 billion bbl. That site could be on the West Coast. The sixth storage project will be a 20-yr program that will be included in the federal budget in 2008. President George W. Bush's state of the union speech to Congress in January 2007 called for increasing the SPR volume to 1.5 billion bbl.

Title: Market Journal: Gas withdrawal fails to move market
Authors with affiliations: Fletcher, S.
Abstract: Energy commodity prices decreased 2/14-15/2007 as traders in the New York market focused on a smaller-than-expected drawdown of US distillate stocks but shrugged off a near-record withdrawal of natural gas from US underground storage during the coldest week of this winter. The March contract for benchmark US light, sweet crudes lost $1.06 to $58/bbl 2/14/2007, giving back most of its gain from the previous trading session on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as the EIA reported distillate inventories fell 3 million bbl to 133.3 million bbl in the week ended 2/9/2007 vs. a Wall Street consensus for a 4 million bbl draw. However, US crude inventories dropped 600,000 bbl to 323.9 million bbl, against consensus expectation for a 1 million bbl build. Gasoline stocks were down by 2.1 million bbl against expectations for a 2.1 million bbl build. The 2/14/2007 data, especially the unexpected drop in gasoline inventories, were positive for refiners, according to Jacques Rousseau, senior energy analyst at Friedman, Billings, Ramsey Group Inc, Arlington, VA. Total refined product inventories showed their largest week-over-week decline in over 3 mo, as production and import gains were insufficient to meet increased consumption. Based on preliminary estimates, imports of LNG into the US will likely average nearly 1.7 bcf/day through January-February, which is essentially in-line with prior forecast, and compares with just over 1.3 bcf/day, on average, during the first 2 mo of 2006.

Authors: Sopian K., Supranto, Othman M.Y., Daud W.R.W., Yatim B.
Title: Double-pass solar collectors with porous media suitable for higher-temperature solar-assisted drying systems
Affiliations: Dept. of Mechanical and Material Engineering, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia; Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Univ. Pembangunan Nasional, Jogjakarta, Indonesia; Dept. of Physics, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia; Dept. of Chemical Engineering and Process Engineering, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Sopian, K., Dept. of Mechanical and Material Engineering, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia; Supranto, Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Univ. Pembangunan Nasional, Jogjakarta, Indonesia; Othman, M.Y., Dept. of Physics, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia; Daud, W.R.W., Dept. of Chemical Engineering and Process Engineering, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia; Yatim, B., Dept. of Physics, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia
Abstract: A high-performance solar collector suitable for a solar-assisted drying system was designed, fabricated, and tested. Solar-assisted drying systems consist of the solar collector array, auxiliary heater, drying chamber, and the air distribution systems. The solar collector was a double-pass solar collector and has upper and lower channels. The lower channel of the solar collector was filled up with porous media, which also acts as a storage medium. The outlet temperature and the performance of the system increased with the presence of the porous media. The collector width and length are 120 and 240 cm, respectively. The upper channel depth is 3.5 cm and the lower channel depth is 10.5 cm. The solar collector array consists of six solar collectors, arranged as two banks of three collectors in series. The collectors were joined in series using internal manifolding. A temperature of 90°C can be reached at a solar radiation level of 800 W m2, ambient temperature of 30°C, and mass flow rate of 0.06 kgs. The solar-assisted drying system was used for drying of oil palm fronds from moisture content of about 63% to moisture content of about 15%, for a drying time of about 7 h. The overall system efficiency is about 25%. © 2007 ASCE.
Author Keywords: Solar energy; Temperature; Thermal factors
Index Keywords: Air distribution systems; Drying chambers; Thermal factors; Mass transfer; Oils and fats; Porous materials; Solar dryers; Solar energy; Solar radiation; Thermal effects; Solar collectors

Authors: Sopian K., Syahri M., Abdullah S., Othman M.Y., Yatim B.
Title: Unglazed fiberglass reinforced polyester solar water heater with integrated storage system
Affiliations: Dept. of Mechanical and Material Engineering, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia; Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Univ. Pembangunan Nasional, Jogjakarta, Indonesia; Dept. of Physics, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Sopian, K., Dept. of Mechanical and Material Engineering, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia; Syahri, M., Faculty of Chemical Engineering, Univ. Pembangunan Nasional, Jogjakarta, Indonesia; Abdullah, S., Dept. of Mechanical and Material Engineering, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia; Othman, M.Y., Dept. of Physics, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia; Yatim, B., Dept. of Physics, Univ. Kebangsaan Malaysia, 43600, Bangi, Selangor, Malaysia
Abstract: Theoretical and experimental investigations on an unglazed solar hot water heater with integrated storage system were conducted. The system was comprised of a collector and storage tank which was integrated into one unit. All parts of the system have been fabricated from fiberglass reinforced polyester (GFRP). The absorber plate has water tubes of semielliptical shape. The width and length of the absorber plate were 1.4 and 1.8 m, respectively. The absorber plate was fabricated from GFPR using a special resin composition that provides good thermal conductivity and absorptivity. The storage tank has a capacity of 496 L. The storage tank is of sandwich construction with a core material made of polyurethane foam that combines stiffness and lightness of the structure with very good thermal insulation properties. An average tank temperature of 53°C was achieved at an average solar radiation level of 700 W m2 and ambient temperature of 28°C. The thermal efficiencies of the system were evaluated at 48 and 57% for cloudy and clear days, respectively. Transient performance of the system was predicted by solving the mathematical models consisting of energy balance equations of the system that have been converted to finite difference form and solved by a personal computer. The experimental results were in close agreement as has been found with the theoretical predictions. © 2007 ASCE.
Author Keywords: Fiber reinforced polymers; Fiberglass; Solar energy; Storage tanks; Thermal factors

Title: Electrohydrogenation of MgH2 -thin films
