Authors with affiliations: Pleguezuelos, J.M., Dep. Biología Animal y Ecología, Fac. Ciencias, Univ. Granada, E-18071 Granada, Spain; Santos, X., Dep. Biología Animal y Ecología, Fac. Ciencias, Univ. Granada, E-18071 Granada, Spain, Departament Biología Animal (Vertebrats), Fac. Biología, Univ. Barcelona, Avda. Diagonal 645, E-08028 Barcelona, Spain; Brito, J.C., CIBIO, Inst. Ciências Agrárias de Vairão, R. Padre Armando Quintas, Vairão, P-4485-661, Portugal; Parellada, X., Servei Protecció Fauna, Dep. Medi Ambient, Generalitat Catalunya, E-08017 Barcelona, Spain; Llorente, G.A., Departament Biología Animal (Vertebrats), Fac. Biología, Univ. Barcelona, Avda. Diagonal 645, E-08028 Barcelona, Spain; Fahd, S., Dép. Biologie, Fac. Sciencies, Univ. Abdelmalek Essaadi, Tetuan, Morocco
Abstract: Eurosiberian vipers have been considered model organisms, and studies on their reproductive ecology have afforded much of the current knowledge concerning viviparity in snakes. However, such studies are biased towards northern species and there is little information on Mediterranean species and/or populations. The reproductive ecology of Vipera latastei in the Iberian Peninsula was studied by analysing a large sample of specimens from collections, to better understand the conservation status of this Mediterranean viper. Males and females matured at small and similar body sizes (240 and 265 mm snout-vent length, respectively) and reproductive cycles in both sexes were seasonal. Spermatogenesis peaked in August, vitellogenesis developed in spring and the timing of the mating period was puzzling, with populations mating in autumn, spring, or in both seasons. The most striking finding was that adult females reproduced triennially on average. Lataste's viper is currently in continuous decline in the IP, and most of its populations are isolated in Mediterranean mountains. We hypothesize that prey scarcity and the brevity of the activity period in mountain habitats diminishes the ability of vipers to recover over the short term the energy expended in reproduction. The species needs 2 years for the acquisition and storage of energy ("capital breeder"), and a third year for the expenditure of this energy (in vitellogenesis and embryogenesis), a year during which females feed consistently ("income breeder"). Thus, this viper combines both strategies to supply the reproductive energy cost. Current decline in population and distribution, together with a poor capacity to renew populations, renders Lataste's viper vulnerable to environmental stochasticity. © 2006 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.

Abstract: This paper studies a new innovative concrete with phase change materials (PCM) on thermal aspects. The final objective is to develop a product which would achieve important energy savings in buildings. The work here presented is the construction and experimental installation of two real size concrete cubicles to study the effect of the inclusion of a PCM with a melting point of 26 °C. The cubicles were constructed in the locality of Puigverd of Lleida (Spain). The results of this study show the energy storage in the walls by encapsulating PCMs and the comparison with conventional concrete without PCMs leading to an improved thermal inertia as well as lower inner temperatures. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. Title: Rheological determination of the sol-gel transition during the aqueous synthesis of resorcinol-formaldehyde resins
Source title: Colloids and Surfaces A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects
Affiliations: Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, University of Liège, Building B6c, Sart Tilman, 4000 Liège, Belgium

Abstract: The sol-gel transition of organic gels prepared by polycondensation of resorcinol (R) with formaldehyde (F) in presence of sodium carbonate (C) was monitored by small amplitude oscillatory measurements, at a single frequency. The gelation time (tg) was determined from the evolution of the storage (G′) and loss (G″) moduli versus time. The influence of two synthesis variables, the resorcinol/sodium carbonate ratio (R/C) and the synthesis temperature (T), was investigated. The gelation time was found to decrease with increasing synthesis temperature and decreasing R/C ratio. The apparent activation energy of the reactional system leading to the gelation, calculated from the gelation times obtained between 50 and 90 °C, was found to be close to 80 kJ mol-1 and independent of the R/C ratio. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: Creep crack growth on spent fuel zircaloy cladding in interim storage
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, 43 Keelung Road, Section 4, Taipei, 106, Taiwan; Nuclear Fuels and Materials Division, Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, Taoyuan 32546, Taiwan

Abstract: The effect of creep failure mechanisms on the creep crack growth is examined on spent fuel Zircaloy cladding in interim storage. Based on the creep fracture mechanics parameter C* and the strain energy density criteria, the relationship between the creep crack growth rate and the fracture mechanics parameter C* is established theoretically. The effects of initial crack lengths and storage temperature profiles on cladding failure are discussed in detail. The results show that the initial crack length and the storage temperature profile play an important role in the interim dry storage. When the storage temperature remains at a constant temperature of 400 °C, it will be safe for the cladding which stores in the interim dry storage. The results presented in this study provide a reliable cladding integrity evaluation for spent fuel in the interim dry storage. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Title: Performance evaluation method of solar-assisted heat pump water heater
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University, Taipei, 106, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Huang, B.J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University, Taipei, 106, Taiwan; Lee, C.P., Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University, Taipei, 106, Taiwan
Abstract: The present study derives a simple linear correlation for the performance evaluation of different solar-assisted heat pump water heater (ISAHP). The correlation was derived from the principle of energy conservation with some simplifications. The correlation is then verified using the long-term outdoor field test data of four different ISAHP. The problems of seasonal repeatability and method of data scattering were examined. From that, a standard performance test method is proposed. The test method suggests that only the measurement of instantaneous solar incident radiation on horizontal surface, ambient temperature, hot water temperature in the storage tank, total mass of water in the storage tank and total power input to the ISAHP are required. It is suggested to select the value of COP at Tf - Ta,ave = 15 °C as the characteristic COP for performance comparison of ISAHP. It is found from the test results that the same performance correlation holds for ISAHP operating with single or dual energy source. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Chen F., Fernandes T.R.C., Yetano Roche M., da Graça Carvalho M.
Title: Investigation of challenges to the utilization of fuel cell buses in the EU vs transition economies
Affiliations: Research Group on Energy and Sustainable Development, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Instituto Superior Técnico, Technical University of Lisbon, Av. Rovisco Pais, 1049-001, Lisbon, Portugal

Rovisco Pais, 1049-001, Lisbon, Portugal
Abstract: In the urban environment, residents' health is damaged seriously due to fossil-fuel combustion, among the pollutants most are created from transport vehicles. Fuel cell buses fuelled by hydrogen appear to be a promise solution to environment, energy and public health problems that we face today. Studies worldwide point towards the technical feasibility of hydrogen as an energy carrier in the transport and stationary sectors, but several non-technical barriers need to be overcome or removed before hydrogen can be deployed in energy systems. This paper expounds a previous country-specific analysis by contrasting the challenges arising at EU level and those faced by transition economies, using China and Brazil as case-studies to identify the key barriers and potential impact on hydrogen fuel cell buses applications. The evaluation criteria used are described. Lessons on the critical conditions for a successful introduction of fuel cell buses and hydrogen into society and the establishment of a hydrogen infrastructure arise from the above analyses. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Bolund B., Bernhoff H., Leijon M.
Title: Flywheel energy and power storage systems
Affiliations: Department of Engineering Sciences, Uppsala University, The Ångström Laboratory, Box 534, S-75121 Uppsala, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Bolund, B., Department of Engineering Sciences, Uppsala University, The Ångström Laboratory, Box 534, S-75121 Uppsala, Sweden; Bernhoff, H., Department of Engineering Sciences, Uppsala University, The Ångström Laboratory, Box 534, S-75121 Uppsala, Sweden; Leijon, M., Department of Engineering Sciences, Uppsala University, The Ångström Laboratory, Box 534, S-75121 Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: For ages flywheels have been used to achieve smooth operation of machines. The early models where purely mechanical consisting of only a stone wheel attached to an axle. Nowadays flywheels are complex constructions where energy is stored mechanically and transferred to and from the flywheel by an integrated motor/generator. The stone wheel has been replaced by a steel or composite rotor and magnetic bearings have been introduced. Today flywheels are used as supplementary UPS storage at several industries world over. Future applications span a wide range including electric vehicles, intermediate storage for renewable energy generation and direct grid applications from power quality issues to offering an alternative to strengthening transmission. One of the key issues for viable flywheel construction is a high overall efficiency, hence a reduction of the total losses. By increasing the voltage, current losses are decreased and otherwise necessary transformer steps become redundant. So far flywheels over 10 kV have not been constructed, mainly due to isolation problems associated with high voltage, but also because of limitations in the power electronics. Recent progress in semi-conductor technology enables faster switching and lower costs. The predominant part of prior studies have been directed towards optimising mechanical issues whereas the electro technical part now seem to show great potential for improvement. An overview of flywheel technology and previous projects are presented and moreover a 200 kW flywheel using high voltage technology is simulated. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Title: Parton transverse momenta and direct photon production in hadronic collisions at high energies
Source title: Physical Review D - Particles, Fields, Gravitation and Cosmology
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, PL-31-342 Cracow, Poland; University of Rzeszów, PL-35-959 Rzeszów, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Pietrycki, T., Institute of Nuclear Physics, PL-31-342 Cracow, Poland; Szczurek, A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, PL-31-342 Cracow, Poland, University of Rzeszów, PL-35-959 Rzeszów, Poland
Abstract: The invariant cross sections for direct photon production in hadron-hadron collisions are calculated for several initial energies (SPS, ISR, Spp̄S, RHIC, Tevatron, LHC) including initial parton transverse momenta within the formalism of unintegrated parton distributions (UPDF). Different approaches from the literature are compared and discussed. A special emphasis is put on the Kimber-Martin-Ryskin (KMR) distributions and their extension into the soft region. Sum rules for UPDFs are formulated and discussed in detail. We find a violation of naive number sum rules for the KMR UPDFs. An interesting interplay of perturbative (large kt2) and nonperturbative (small kt2) regions of UPDFs in the production of both soft and hard photons is identified. The kt-factorization approach with the KMR UPDFs is inconsistent with the collinear approach at large transverse momenta of photons. Kwieciński UPDFs provide very good description of all world data, especially at super proton synchrotron (SPS) and intersecting storage rings (ISR) energies. Off-shell effects are discussed and quantified. Predictions for the CERN LHC are given. Very forward/backward regions in rapidity at LHC energy are discussed and a possibility to test unintegrated gluon distributions (UGDF) is presented. © 2007 The American Physical Society.

Title: Status of WASA at COSY
Source title: International Journal of Modern Physics A
Affiliations: Svedberg Laboratory, Uppsala University, Box 533, 751 21 Uppsala, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Fransson, K., Svedberg Laboratory, Uppsala University, Box 533, 751 21 Uppsala, Sweden
Abstract: The WASA detector built and operated at the storage ring CELSIUS in Uppsala, was during 2005 moved to the COoler SYnchrotron COSY in Jülich where it is now being reassembled. The main physics concerns decays of η and η′ mesons and isospin violation in deuteron-deuteron interactions. Several modifications and upgrades are planned to adapt the WASA detector to the COSY environment and beam energy. The first commissioning run is scheduled to start August 2006. Here we report on the status of the installation work and upgrades planned for the WASA detector at COSY. © World Scientific Publishing Company.

Authors: Guan P.-C., Chen Y.-F., Yu I.A.
Title: Role of degenerate Zeeman states in the storage and retrieval of light pulses
Source title: Physical Review A - Atomic, Molecular, and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Department of Physics, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, 300, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Guan, P.-C., Department of Physics, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, 300, Taiwan; Chen, Y.-F., Department of Physics, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, 300, Taiwan; Yu, I.A., Department of Physics, National Tsing Hua University, Hsinchu, 300, Taiwan
Abstract: We have studied the role of degenerate Zeeman states in the storage and retrieval of light pulses in the three-level Λ -type system of electromagnetically induced transparency. A probe pulse with the σ+ polarization is stored in the medium and subsequently released with the σ- polarization. However, the manipulation of the retrieved polarization causes an energy loss. Our study shows that the incompatibility between the stored ground-state coherence and the ratio of the probe and coupling Clebsch-Gordan coefficients is responsible for the energy loss. Such energy loss can be avoided as long as all population accumulates in a single Zeeman state. We provide the useful knowledge for the light-storage technique and demonstrate that the degenerate Zeeman states should be considered in the relevant applications. © 2007 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Gutman R., Yosha D., Choshniak I., Kronfeld-Schor N.
Title: Two strategies for coping with food shortage in desert golden spiny mice
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, 69978, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Gutman, R., Department of Zoology, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, 69978, Israel; Yosha, D., Department of Zoology, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, 69978, Israel; Choshniak, I., Department of Zoology, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, 69978, Israel; Kronfeld-Schor, N., Department of Zoology, Tel Aviv University, Tel Aviv, 69978, Israel
Abstract: Desert rodents face periods of food shortage and use different strategies for coping with it, including changes in activity level. Golden spiny mice (Acomys russatus) inhabit rock crevasses and do not dig burrows nor store food. When kept under 50% food restriction most, but not all, golden spiny mice defend their body mass by physiological means. We tested the hypothesis that these rodents use two different behavioral strategies, i.e., increasing activity level and searching for food or decreasing activity level and conserving energy to cope with food shortage. Twelve golden spiny mice were fed ad libitum for 14 days, followed by 40 days of 50% food restriction, and 14 days of refeeding. Body mass, food consumption and general activity were monitored. Seven mice significantly reduced activity level, concentrating their activity around feeding time, lowering energy expenditure and thus keeping their body mass constant ("resistant"), while five ("non-resistant") significantly increased activity level (possibly searching for food) and thus energy expenditure, thereby losing mass rapidly (more than 25% of body mass). The non-resistant golden spiny mice were active throughout many hours of the day, with high variability both between and among individuals. The use of two strategies to cope with food shortage as found in the golden spiny mice may be of evolutionary advantage, since it allows a more flexible reaction to food restriction at the population level. © 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Rutile-type dense ceramics fabricated by pressureless sintering of Ti1-xRuxO2 powders prepared by sol-gel
Source title: Journal of the European Ceramic Society
Affiliations: Instituto de Cerámica y Vidrio, CSIC, C/Kelsen no. 5, 28049 Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Colomer, M.T., Instituto de Cerámica y Vidrio, CSIC, C/Kelsen no. 5, 28049 Madrid, Spain; Velasco, M.J., Instituto de Cerámica y Vidrio, CSIC, C/Kelsen no. 5, 28049 Madrid, Spain
Abstract: Materials in the TiO2-RuO2 system, in different shapes, as thin films, coatings, fine powders, xerogels and aerogels are of great interest for many applications, such as energy storage and production systems, solar cells, chemical sensors, electronics, gas separation processes, and industrial electrochemistry. However, a serious drawback in the processing of materials based on RuO2 is the well-established chemical reactivity above ∼700 °C where RuO2 becomes volatile and oxidizes to RuO3/RuO4 gases (in air) or reduces to Ru metal (in a vacuum). For this reason, it is not obvious to attain dense materials in the systems containing Ru. In this study, a novel method has been used to obtain rutile-type Ti1-xRuxO2 (x = 0.05, 0.08 and 0.10) as dense ceramics without the use of the hot-pressing for the sintering step. The relative densities of the materials prepared were higher than 99.0 ρth %). This method combines the sol-gel synthesis, a pressureless fast-firing method (heating and cooling rate of 20 °C min-1) at 1350 °C for 10 min and the use of a buffer during the sintering that provides a RuO3 + RuO4 rich atmosphere. © 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Montenegro M.A., Nunes I.L., Mercadante A.Z., Borsarelli C.D.
Title: Photoprotection of vitamins in skimmed milk by an aqueous soluble lycopene-gum arabic microcapsule
Source title: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
Affiliations: Instituto de Ciencias Químicas, Faculdad de Agronomía Y Agroindustrias, Universidad Nacional de Santiago del Estero, Av. Belgrano (S) 1912, 4200 Santiago del Estero, Argentina; Department of Food Science, Faculty of Food Engineering, State University of Campinas, UNICAMP, P.O. Box 6121, Campinas, São Paulo 13083-862, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Montenegro, M.A., Instituto de Ciencias Químicas, Faculdad de Agronomía Y Agroindustrias, Universidad Nacional de Santiago del Estero, Av. Belgrano (S) 1912, 4200 Santiago del Estero, Argentina; Nunes, I.L., Department of Food Science, Faculty of Food Engineering, State University of Campinas, UNICAMP, P.O. Box 6121, Campinas, São Paulo 13083-862, Brazil; Mercadante, A.Z., Department of Food Science, Faculty of Food Engineering, State University of Campinas, UNICAMP, P.O. Box 6121, Campinas, São Paulo 13083-862, Brazil; Borsarelli, C.D., Instituto de Ciencias Químicas, Faculdad de Agronomía Y Agroindustrias, Universidad Nacional de Santiago del Estero, Av. Belgrano (S) 1912, 4200 Santiago del Estero, Argentina
Abstract: Riboflavin (Rf)-mediated photosensitized degradation of vitamins A and D3 in skimmed milk under illumination with a white fluorescence lamp was studied by using the HPLC technique. The photosensitized degradation of both vitamins followed first-order kinetics, and the temperature effect on the observed photodegradation rate constant allowed the determination of the activation energy Ea as being 4 and 16 kcal/mol for vitamins A and D3, respectively. The addition of lycopene microencapsulated by spray-drying with a gum arabic-sucrose (8:2) mixture (MIC) produced a reduction of ca. 45% in the photosensitized degradation rate of both vitamins. Front-face fluorescence experiments showed the same photoprotection factor in the degradation of Rf itself, indicating that the photodegradation mechanism involved Rf-mediated reactive species, such as the excited triplet state of Rf, 3Rf*, and/or singlet molecular oxygen, 1O 2. The interaction of both 3Rf* and 1O2 with MIC was evaluated in aqueous solutions by using laser-induced time-resolved absorption or emission spectroscopy, and the contribution of an inner-filter effect in the presence of MIC in skimmed milk was evaluated by diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. The main operating mechanism of photoprotection is due to the deactivation of 3Rf* by the proteic component of gum arabic; thus, gum arabic based microcapsules could be used to improve the photostability of milk during its storage and/or processing under light. © 2007 American Chemical Society.

Title: Effect of short-term starvation on hepatopancreas and plasma energy reserves of the Pacific white shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei)
Source title: Journal of Experimental Marine Biology and Ecology
Affiliations: Centro de Investigación en Alimentación y Desarrollo (CIAD), A.C., Carretera a la Victoria Km. 0.6, Hermosillo, Sonora, C.P. 83000, Mexico; Centro de Investigaciones Biológicas del Noroeste (CIBNOR), P.O. Box 128, La Paz, B.C.S. C.P. 23000, Mexico; Centro de Investigaciones Biológicas del Noroeste (CIBNOR), Unidad Hermosillo, Hermosillo, Sonora C.P. 83260, Mexico

Box 128, La Paz, B.C.S. C.P. 23000, Mexico; Hernández-López, J., Centro de Investigaciones Biológicas del Noroeste (CIBNOR), Unidad Hermosillo, Hermosillo, Sonora C.P. 83260, Mexico; Muhlia-Almazán, A., Centro de Investigación en Alimentación y Desarrollo (CIAD), A.C., Carretera a la Victoria Km. 0.6, Hermosillo, Sonora, C.P. 83000, Mexico; Yepiz-Plascencia, G., Centro de Investigación en Alimentación y Desarrollo (CIAD), A.C., Carretera a la Victoria Km. 0.6, Hermosillo, Sonora, C.P. 83000, Mexico
Abstract: Crustaceans are forced to fast during molting. Several physiological, metabolic and behavioral changes have been associated with starvation. Although some of these changes have been well studied, knowledge of the dynamics of fuel reserves during the molting process is limited. To understand the effects of short-term hunger stress on energy reserves, intermolt shrimp Litopenaeus vannamei were starved up to five days. This period corresponds to the normal time that juvenile shrimp starve during molting, since they can not eat. Glucose, glycogen, total soluble protein, total lipids, sterols, and acylglycerides were measured in plasma and hepatopancreas. The same metabolic substrates were measured in organisms that were fed after 96 h of starvation. It is widely accepted that protein is the main energy reserve used by shrimp to deal with starvation. However, under short-term starvation a rapid decrease of plasma and hepatopancreas glucose and an important decrease in hepatopancreatic glycogen were detected. Additionally, acylglycerides content in hepatopancreas decreased significantly at later times, while protein in plasma and hepatopancreas remained fairly constant during the experiment. This study may help understand some aspects of the nutrition physiology of the Pacific white shrimp related to its biology. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: EC proposes legislation to enforce utility unbundling
Authors with affiliations: Izundu, U.
Abstract: On January 10, the European Commission has proposed enforcing full ownership unbundling of gas and electricity infrastructure via new legislation as one of its measures to help facilitate an internal energy market in Europe. The comprehensive energy policy package was unveiled in Brussels. The EC is set to carry out an impact assessment of the proposal prior to exploring a legislative route. Achieving diversity as promoted in the package will necessitate developing projects to bring gas from new regions, establishing gas hubs in central Europe and the Baltic states, improving the use of strategic storage possibilities and encouraging the building of liquefied natural gas terminals.
Index Keywords: Energy policy; Laws and legislation; Marketing; Petroleum industry; Societies and institutions; electricity supply; energy market; energy policy; European Commission; gas supply; legislation; liquefied natural gas; Eurasia; Europe

Title: OGJ newsletter: General interest - Quick takes: Gas exports to Georgia start
Abstract: On 1/11/2007, Azerbaijan's Azarigaz began exporting natural gas along the Haciqabul-Qazax-Tbilisi trunk line to Georgia, which is seeking to reduce its dependence on increasingly expensive Russian supplies. The State Oil Co of the Azerbaijani Republic will initially supply 3 million cu m/day of gas on 1/11-21/2007 at a cost of $120/1000 cu m. By the end of January 2007, gas from Azerbaijans Shah Daniz field will be supplied to Georgia via the Baku-Tbilisi-Erzurum pipeline. Georgia is expected to require 1.8 billion cu m of gas in 2007 and had an agreement with OAO Gazprom to supply 1.46 billion cu m in 2007. Meanwhile, Georgia is planning to repair its main gas lines and to build a gas storage facility in the southern Ninotsminda district initially capable of storing ≤ 500 million cu m of gas to boost its energy security.

Authors: Lin B.-R., Chiang H.-K., Chen C.-C., Lin C.-S., Chiang A.
Title: Analysis and implementation of soft switching converter with series-connected transformers
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, National Yunlin University of Science and Technology, Yunlin 640, Taiwan; Sunpower Technology Corp., 16F-1, No. 150, Jian Yi Road, Chung-Ho City, Taipei Hsien, 235, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lin, B.-R., Department of Electrical Engineering, National Yunlin University of Science and Technology, Yunlin 640, Taiwan; Chiang, H.-K., Department of Electrical Engineering, National Yunlin University of Science and Technology, Yunlin 640, Taiwan; Chen, C.-C., Department of Electrical Engineering, National Yunlin University of Science and Technology, Yunlin 640, Taiwan; Lin, C.-S., Sunpower Technology Corp., 16F-1, No. 150, Jian Yi Road, Chung-Ho City, Taipei Hsien, 235, Taiwan; Chiang, A., Sunpower Technology Corp., 16F-1, No. 150, Jian Yi Road, Chung-Ho City, Taipei Hsien, 235, Taiwan
Abstract: The system analysis and design consideration of a zero voltage switching (ZVS) converter with series-connected transformers are presested. Based on the operational behaviour, each transformer in the adopted converter can be operated as an inductor or a transformer. Therefore no output filter inductor is needed in the adopted converter. To reduce the voltage stress of the switching device in the conventional forward converter, an active snubber based on a clamp switch and a clamp capacitor is used to recycle the energy stored in the transformer leakage. During the transition interval, the resonance based on the junction capacitance of switches and transformer leakage inductance can achieve ZVS operation of switches. The centre-tapped rectifier is used at the secondary side to achieve full-wave rectification. The operating principles, steady-state analysis and design equations of the proposed converter are provided. Finally, experimental results for a 100W (5V/20A) prototype circuit are provided to verify the converter performance. © The Institution of Engineering and Technology 2007.
Index Keywords: Electric inductors; Electric rectifiers; Electric transformers; Energy storage; Magnetic filters; Switching circuits; Clamp switch; Junction capacitance; Series-connected transformers; Zero voltage switching (ZVS); Electric converters

Authors: Yun C.L., Glund S., Garcia-Roves P.M., Zierath J.R.
Title: Calcineurin regulates skeletal muscle metabolism via coordinated changes in gene expression
Affiliations: Department of Molecular Medicine and Surgery, Section of Integrative Physiology, Karolinska Institutet, von Eulers väg 4, Stockholm S-171 77, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Yun, C.L., Department of Molecular Medicine and Surgery, Section of Integrative Physiology, Karolinska Institutet, von Eulers väg 4, Stockholm S-171 77, Sweden; Glund, S., Department of Molecular Medicine and Surgery, Section of Integrative Physiology, Karolinska Institutet, von Eulers väg 4, Stockholm S-171 77, Sweden; Garcia-Roves, P.M., Department of Molecular Medicine and Surgery, Section of Integrative Physiology, Karolinska Institutet, von Eulers väg 4, Stockholm S-171 77, Sweden; Zierath, J.R., Department of Molecular Medicine and Surgery, Section of Integrative Physiology, Karolinska Institutet, von Eulers väg 4, Stockholm S-171 77, Sweden
Abstract: The metabolic property of skeletal muscle adapts in response to an increased physiological demand by altering substrate utilization and gene expression. The calcium-regulated serine/threonine protein phosphatase calcineurin has been implicated in the transduction of motor neuron signals to alter gene expression programs in skeletal muscle. We utilized transgenic mice that overexpress an activated form of calcineurin in skeletal muscle (MCK-CnA*) to investigate the impact of calcineurin activation on metabolic properties of skeletal muscle. Activation of calcineurin increased glucose incorporation into glycogen and lipid oxidation in skeletal muscle. Activated calcineurin suppressed skeletal muscle glucose oxidation and increased lactate release. The enhancement in lipid oxidation was supported by increased expression of genes for lipid metabolism and mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation. In a reciprocal fashion, several genes of glycolysis were down-regulated, whereas pyruvate dehydrogenase kinase 4 was markedly induced. This expression pattern was associated with decreased glucose utilization and enhanced glycogen storage. The peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) and PPARγ coactivator 1α (PGC1α) are transcription regulators for the expression of metabolic and mitochondrial genes. Consistent with changes in the gene-regulatory program, calcineurin promoted the expression of PPARα, PPARδ, and PPARγ coactivator 1α in skeletal muscle. These results provide evidence that calcineurin-mediated skeletal muscle reprogramming induces the expression of several transcription regulators that coordinate changes in the expression of genes for lipid and glucose metabolism, which in turn alters energy substrate utilization in skeletal muscle. © 2007 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.

Authors: Huang Z.G., Guo Z.P., Calka A., Wexler D., Liu H.K.
Title: Effects of carbon black, graphite and carbon nanotube additives on hydrogen storage properties of magnesium
Affiliations: Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials, University of Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia; Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Z.G., Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials, University of Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia; Guo, Z.P., Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials, University of Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia; Calka, A., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia; Wexler, D., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia; Liu, H.K., Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials, University of Wollongong, NSW 2522, Australia
Abstract: The effects of different carbon additives: carbon black, graphite and multi-walled carbon nanotubes, on the hydrogen storage properties of magnesium were investigated and compared. Samples of Mg containing 5 wt.% additive were prepared by milling in hydrogen gas using a magnetically controlled ball mill. Structural and phase evolution were investigated using X-ray diffractometry (XRD) and morphology and microchemistry by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). Raman spectroscopy was used to investigate changes in the nature of carbon-carbon bonding, differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) to investigate desorption characteristics, and thermogravimetry (TG) to estimate the hydrogen storage capacity of both milled and rehydrogenated samples. There was no significant difference in the hydrogen storage capacity between the as-prepared (6.4 wt.%) and rehydrogenated (6.2 wt.%) composites, however, the rehydrogenated composite containing graphite displayed a remarkable decrease in the desorption temperature, a result which wants further investigation. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Title: OGJ newsletter: McMoRan's main pass energy hub project approved
Abstract: McMoRan Exploration Co has received approval from the US Maritime Administration for its Main Pass Energy Hub (MPEH) project on Main Pass Block 299 in 210 ft of water off Louisiana in the Gulf of Mexico. Marad concluded that construction and operation of the MPEH deepwater port would be consistent with national objectives such as energy sufficiency and environmental quality. The project will fill a vital role in meeting national energy requirements for many years and that the port's offshore deepwater location will help reduce congestion and enhance safety in receiving LNG cargoes to the US. As approved, the MPEH facility, will be able to regasify LNG at a peak rate of 1.6 bcf/day, store 28 bcf of gas in salt caverns, and deliver 3.1 bcf/day of gas, including gas from storage, to the US.

Title: Special report: US energy market to expand in 2007 as prices ease
Authors with affiliations: Radler, M.
Abstract: Demand for electric power generation in the United States will drive much of the energy needed in 2007. Forecasts show increases in consumption across all forms of energy. Transportation fuel consumption will push US oil demand in 2007. US production of crude and condensate will move up nearly 2% this year. However, energy prices will be lower this year. US energy demand this year will grow 1.1%. Consumption of all forms of energy will total 101.95 quadrillion btu (quads). While this year's growth rates for all types of energy will be modest, the largest percentage of growth will be for renewable energies which include wind, solar and hydroelectric power generation. However, oil will remain the largest of all energy sources in the US. US oil production will increase to average 5.25 million b/d this year. Volumes of crude and oil products in storage will finish 2007 loewr than in 2006. The amount of crude in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve also will climb, reaching 700 million bbl. Processing at refineries will remain strong in 2007 where refining capacity is expected to increase marginally to 17.5 million b/d. Total US imports of crude and products will be unchanged this year. Demand for oil products will increase 1.1% and total demand for oil products will average 20.96 million b/d. Motor gasoline demand will grow 1% this year as pump prices of gasoline have moderated from their summer 2006 highs. Consumption of liquefied petroleum gases to be unchanged this year from 2005.
Index Keywords: Costs; Crude petroleum; Energy utilization; Forecasting; Marketing; Renewable energy resources; Statistics; electricity generation; energy market; energy use; fuel consumption; oil production; renewable resource; North America; United States

Authors: Carnero Ruiz C., Díaz-López L., Aguiar J.
Title: Self-assembly of tetradecyltrimethylammonium bromide in glycerol aqueous mixtures: A thermodynamic and structural study
Source title: Journal of Colloid and Interface Science
Affiliations: Grupo de Fluidos Estructurados y Sistemas Anfifílicos, Departamento de Física Aplicada II, Escuela Universitaria Politécnica, Campus de El Ejido s/n, 29071 Málaga, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Carnero Ruiz, C., Grupo de Fluidos Estructurados y Sistemas Anfifílicos, Departamento de Física Aplicada II, Escuela Universitaria Politécnica, Campus de El Ejido s/n, 29071 Málaga, Spain; Díaz-López, L., Grupo de Fluidos Estructurados y Sistemas Anfifílicos, Departamento de Física Aplicada II, Escuela Universitaria Politécnica, Campus de El Ejido s/n, 29071 Málaga, Spain; Aguiar, J., Grupo de Fluidos Estructurados y Sistemas Anfifílicos, Departamento de Física Aplicada II, Escuela Universitaria Politécnica, Campus de El Ejido s/n, 29071 Málaga, Spain
Abstract: In this paper, we have studied the effect of glycerol on the micelle formation of tetradecyltrimethylammonium bromide. Changes in both the critical micelle concentration and the degree of counterion binding of the surfactant upon the addition of glycerol across a temperature range (20-40 °C) were examined by using the conductance method. The equilibrium model of micelle formation was applied to obtain the thermodynamic parameters of micellization. An enthalpy-entropy compensation effect was observed in all the solvent systems, but whereas the micellization of the surfactant in the medium with 20% glycerol occurs under the same structural conditions as in pure water, in glycerol rich mixtures the results suggest that the lower aggregation in these media is due to the minor cohesive energy of the solvent system in relation to water. It was also observed that the micellar aggregation number, as obtained by the static quenching method, decreases with the glycerol content. This fact was attributed to an increase in the surface area per headgroup of the surfactant as a consequence of an enhanced solvation, probably induced by the incorporation of some glycerol molecules in the micellar solvation layer. Although the pyrene 1:3 ratio index does not indicate significant changes in the micropolarity at the micelle-bulk interface, the data of fluorescence anisotropy of coumarin 6 and fluorescein are compatible with the formation of a more compact solvation layer. © 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: What ecosystems really are-Physicochemical or biological entities?
Affiliations: Department of Ecology, School of Biology, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, 54124 Thessaloniki, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Schizas, D., Department of Ecology, School of Biology, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, 54124 Thessaloniki, Greece; Stamou, G., Department of Ecology, School of Biology, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, 54124 Thessaloniki, Greece
Abstract: Classical systems ecology in the style of Howard Odum wasn't genuinely holistic. Odum reduced ecological phenomena to storages, fluxes and transformations of energy and by doing so he undermined the autonomy of ecological science. To surmount this situation, Patten and coworkers offer an alternative framework, namely environ analysis. Resulting in novel ontological perspectives, environ analysis attempts to represent phenomena that are characteristically biological in nature, rather than purely physical or chemical. However, Patten and coworkers do not assign autonomy to ecosystem processes related to these phenomena and lead themselves to the "reductionist trap". In an effort to escape this trap they throw off the traditional ecosystem models and proceed to methodological reforms. This way, they finally achieve to partly outmatch the reductionism associated traditionally with Systems Ecology, although the holding to a framework which overrates prediction probably jeopardizes the whole enterprise. © 2006 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Environ analysis; Holism; Network theory; Reductionism; Systems Ecology
Index Keywords: Circuit theory; Ecology; Energy transfer; Environmental impact; Mathematical models; Ecological science; Ecosystem models; Systems Ecology; Ecosystems; ecological approach; ecosystem modeling

Title: Capturing carbon
Authors with affiliations: Sampson, B.
Abstract: The impact of green house gases and the solutions for carbon capture and storage for the positive impacts on the climate is presented. The European emissions trading scheme is placing economic controls on the production of CO2 that requires revolutionary technology. The International Energy Association's Greenhouse Gas R&D Program, in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire is a central node in the international research network for carbon capture and storage technology. There are three approaches to the capture carbon at the back end of the industrial process: post-combustion, pre-combustion, and oxyfuel combustion. Post-combustion system uses a chemical scrubbing system to remove CO2 from the flue gas and an special solvent is used to dissolve the CO2 that is boiled to release the gas. Pre-combustion process separates the CO2 before the combustion and the latest approach is cleaning coal emissions by the process of oxyfuel burning.
Index Keywords: Carbon dioxide; Combustion; Flue gases; Greenhouse effect; Industrial emissions; Industrial wastes; Research and development management; Carbon capture; Coal emissions; Oxyfuels; Global warming

Title: Ferroelectric thin-films: The emancipation of ferroelectricity
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Céramique, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Lausanne 1015, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Muralt, P., Laboratoire de Céramique, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, Lausanne 1015, Switzerland
Abstract: The high-resolution microscopy measurements of ultra-thin ferroelectric films resolve the unit-cell structure of the crystals and is used in mass storage of data. A ferroelectric material with critical temperature of 460°C breaks the inverse symmetry of the crystal and displaces the ions to form electrical polarization. The strain produced by displacement of ions deforms the cubic unit-cells into a tetragonal cells by stress-polarization coupling in Gibbs Free Energy. A compressive strain that leads to a vertical strain, is developed in the films when polarization at the interfaces approaches zero. The description of materials in terms of Gibbs free-energy is adjusted to find the elastic energy potential and the fixed in-plane strains at the interface. The mass storage is provided by the increase in tetragonality at the surfaces and the interfaces and the atomic displacements of the ferroelectric films, due to epitaxial strain effect.
Index Keywords: Ferroelectricity; Free energy; Interfaces (materials); Microscopic examination; Cubic unit-cells; Elastic energy potential; Electrical polarization; Epitaxial strain effect; Inverse symmetry; Ferroelectric thin films

Authors: Su F., Zhao X.S., Wang Y., Lee J.Y.
Title: Bridging mesoporous carbon particles with carbon nanotubes
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, National University of Singapore, 4 Engineering Drive 4, Singapore, 117576, Singapore; Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Initiative, National University of Singapore, Singapore, 117576, Singapore; Singapore-MIT Alliance, National University of Singapore, 4 Engineering Drive 3, Singapore, 117576, Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Su, F., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, National University of Singapore, 4 Engineering Drive 4, Singapore, 117576, Singapore; Zhao, X.S., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, National University of Singapore, 4 Engineering Drive 4, Singapore, 117576, Singapore, Nanoscience and Nanotechnology Initiative, National University of Singapore, Singapore, 117576, Singapore; Wang, Y., Singapore-MIT Alliance, National University of Singapore, 4 Engineering Drive 3, Singapore, 117576, Singapore; Lee, J.Y., Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, National University of Singapore, 4 Engineering Drive 4, Singapore, 117576, Singapore, Singapore-MIT Alliance, National University of Singapore, 4 Engineering Drive 3, Singapore, 117576, Singapore
Abstract: The enhancement of the electrical conductivity (EC) of a porous carbon is highly desirable in many applications, especially in those associated with storage and conversion of electrochemical energy. In this work, we demonstrated an approach to largely increasing the EC of ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) by bridging the OMC particles with carbon nanotubes (CNTs). Infiltration of the pores of ordered mesoporous SBA-15 silica with a carbon precursor yielded a carbon/mesoporous silica composite, which was further used as a support for Ni catalyst. Subsequently, catalytic growth of CNTs on the Ni-supported composite surface was carried out using the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method with benzene as the carbon precursor. Removal of the silica framework and the metal catalyst left behind OMC particles bridged with CNTs. The EC of the OMC was increased from 138 S/m (before bridging) to 645 S/m (after bridging). Because of the significant enhancement of EC and the availability of mesopores, the cyclability of the hybrid carbon materials as a negative electrode used in rechargeable lithium-ion batteries was significantly improved. © 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Carbon nanotubes; Chemical vapor deposition; Mesoporous carbon; Rechargeable lithium ion batteries; Template
Index Keywords: Carbon nanotubes; Catalyst activity; Chemical vapor deposition; Composite materials; Silica; Electrochemical energy; Mesoporous carbon; Rechargeable lithium ion batteries; Mesoporous materials; Carbon nanotubes; Catalyst activity; Chemical vapor deposition; Composite materials; Mesoporous materials; Silica

Title: ECS Transactions - 3rd Symposium on Atomic Layer Deposition Applications
Abstract: The proceedings contain 29 papers. The topics discussed include: ALD capping layers for accelerator superconducting radio frequency cavities; deposition of TiN and TaN by remote plasma ALD for diffusion barrier applications; a silicon nitride MIM capacitor for analog/mixed-signal integrated circuit using manufacturable atomic layer deposition equipment; oxidant effect on resistance switching characteristics of HfO2 film grown atomic layer deposition; copper nano film formation using electrochemical ALD; an ab initio evaluation of cyclopendadienyl precursors for the atomic layer deposition of Hafnia and Zirconia; nanomechanical properties of high-K dielectrics grown by atomic layer deposition; and evaluation of novel Sr precursor for atomic layer deposition of SrO thin film.
Index Keywords: Atomic physics; Atoms; Blood vessel prostheses; Copper; Cubic boron nitride; Electric currents; Electrochemical properties; Electronics industry; Energy storage; Hafnium compounds; Health; Integrated circuits; Microelectronics; MIM devices; Nitrides; Physical vapor deposition; Plasma deposition; Plasma diagnostics; Pulsed laser deposition; Radio equipment; Silicon; Silicon nitride; Strontium; Tantalum compounds; Thick films; Thin films; Tin; Tinning; Titanium compounds; Titanium nitride; Zirconia; (100) silicon; (O-sec.-butyldithiocarbonatio-S ,S') copper; ab initio; Atomic layers; Capping layer (GC layer); Hf O2 films; High k dielectrics; Metal high insulator metal (MIM) capacitor; Nano films; Nano mechanical properties; On-resistance (Rons); Remote plasma ALD; Superconducting radio frequency (SRF) cavities; Atomic layer deposition

Title: ECS Transactions - Symposium on Silicon Nitride, Silicon Dioxide Thin Insulating Films, and Emerging Dielectrics
Abstract: The proceedings contain 49 papers. The topics discussed include: future advances in the electrical characterisation of silicon-insulator interface traps using charge pumping; transfer of positive fixed charge between Si and SiO2 in a Si/SiO2 interface with hydrogen migration; optimizing the interface of spin-on oxide and the active area of transistor in sub70nm DRAM structures for better electrical performance; interface engineering by PVD-based in-situ fabrication method for advanced metal/high-k gate stacks; rare-earth metal oxides and their silicates/aluminates as future gate dielectric films; resistance switching characteristics of metal oxides for nonvolatile memory applications; and dielectric and electrode thin films for stack-cell structured DRAM capacitors with sub 50-nm design rules.
Index Keywords: Blood vessel prostheses; Data storage equipment; Dielectric devices; Dielectric films; Dielectric materials; Dynamic random access storage; Electrolytic capacitors; Energy storage; Gate dielectrics; Gates (transistor); Health; Hydrogen; Insulating materials; Insulation; Metallizing; Nitrides; Oxide films; Plastic films; Rare earth elements; Silica; Silicon nitride; Thick films; (100) silicon; active areas; characterisation; Charge pump (CP); Design rules; DRAM capacitors; Electrical performances; Fixed charges; gate dielectric films; Gate stacks; hydrogen migration; In-situ fabrication; Interface engineering; interface trapping; Metal oxides; Non volatile memory (NVM) applications; Rare earth metal (REM); Resistance switching; silicon dioxides; SiSi O2 interfaces; Spin on; Thin insulating films; Silicon

Title: ECS Transactions - 47th State-of-the-Art Program on Compound Semiconductors (SOTAPOCS 47) and the 8th Symposium on Wide Bandgap Semiconductor Materials and Devices
Abstract: The proceedings contain 33 papers. The topics discussed include: end point detection of GaAs backside via etching capacitor on via; enhanced light extraction from gallium nitride optoelectronics on Si substrates; high performance ZnO thin film transistors fabricated on both glass and flexible substrates; frequency response and devices performance of the indium zinc oxide thin film transistors; properties of the state-of-the-art bulk and homoepitaxial films on III-V nitride semiconductors; conjugate polymer induced enhancement of THz radiation in semiconductors; overcoming contact hurdles for investigating lower dimensional structures in undoped heterostructures; performance evaluation of III-nitride avalanche photodiodes grown on SiC and GaN substrates; monolayer formation on GaN surface via self-assembly; and growth of InN by plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy on InN/GaN and p-GaN templates.
Index Keywords: Avalanches (snowslides); Blood vessel prostheses; Coatings; Crystal growth; Crystals; Cubic boron nitride; Electric conductivity; Electric currents; Energy gap; Energy storage; Epitaxial growth; Extraction; Film growth; Frequency response; Gallium; Gallium alloys; Gallium compounds; Gallium nitride; Mixtures; Molecular beam epitaxy; Molecular beams; Molecular dynamics; Multitasking; Nitrides; Oxide films; Oxides; Photonics; Pigments; Polymer films; Pulsed laser deposition; Self assembly; Semiconducting gallium; Semiconducting zinc compounds; Semiconductor devices; Semiconductor growth; Silicon; Silicon carbide; Snow; Solids; Solvent extraction; Substrates; Tellurium compounds; Thick films; Thin film devices; Thin film transistors; Thin films; Transistors; Zinc; Zinc oxide; Zinc sulfide; (1 1 0) surface; (PL) properties; (R ,S)-conjugate; Compound semiconductor (CS); Continuous wave terahertz (THz) radiation; Dimensional structures; Endpoint detection (EPD); Flexible substrates; GaN substrates; GaN templates; heterostructures; High performance; Homoepitaxial films; III nitrides; Indium zinc oxide (IZO); Light extractions; monolayer formation; Nitride semiconductors; Performance evaluation (PE); Plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy (PA-MBE); self-assembly; Si(2 1 1) substrates; Wide band gap semiconductor materials; ZnO thin films; Semiconductor materials

Title: Analysis: Global energy demand to rise 50% by 2030
Abstract: Speaking at the launch of IEA's World Energy Outlook report, executive director Nobuo Tanaka warned that inevitable growth in the energy demand would create a indisputable threat to energy security and speed up climate change. The main drivers behind the increase will be the rapid economic growth in China and India. Various analysts are already anticipating that China and India's energy demands will top North America within the next two decades due to the countries' huge population and rapid growth. The World energy Outlook 2007 report forecasts that a majority of the increased demand for energy would be met by coal. As a result, CO2 emissions are set to jump by 57% from 27 Gton in 2005 to 42 Gton in 2030. The report suggests that emissions savings come from improved efficiency in industry, buildings and transport, switching to nuclear power and renewables, and the widespread deployment of carbon capture and storage.

Title: Projects: Gulf Interstate Engineering wins Enbridge contracts
Abstract: Gulf Interstate Engineering Co has won a contract from subsidiaries of Enbridge Energy Partners LP and Enbridge Inc to provide detailed engineering, design, and procurement services for the US portion of the Alberta Clipper and Southern Lights Projects in North Dakota, Minnesota, and northern Wisconsin. This is in addition to the preliminary engineering services that Gulf is already providing on these projects. The Alberta Clipper Project includes 326-mi of 36-in. dia crude oil pipeline from the US-Canadian border to Superior, WI, and three 1000-hp pump stations. The Southern Lights Project consists of 136 mi of 20-in. dia crude oil pipeline and 190 mi of 20-in. dia diluent pipeline. The Southern Lights Project includes five 6500-hp pump stations, the reversal of flow at one existing pump station, conversion of two existing pump stations and six 200,000 bbl and storage tanks. The work will start immediately and continue through August 2008.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Vector Pipeline, a joint venture between...
Abstract: Vector Pipeline, a joint venture between Enbridge and DTE Energy, plans to expand the capacity of its mainline gas-transmission pipeline by about 100 million cu ft/day to 1.3 bcf/day by late 2009. The 348 mi pipeline runs between Joliet, IL, and a storage complex at Dawn, Ontario, Canada.

Title: International: Gazprom, PetroVietnam sign cooperation agreement
Abstract: Gazprom and PetroVietnam have signed an agreement of cooperation in the oil, gas, and pipeline industries. The agreement stipulates cooperation in exploration, production, transportation, utilization, and marketing of natural gas, oil and other energy; engineering, construction, operation, and maintenance of oil and gas pipelines, storage facilities as well as distribution pipeline networks; inspection and monitoring of oil and gas pipelines as well as other gas and petrochemical infrastructure; and processing of oil, gas and other hydrocarbon processing. Gazprom's participation may help Vietnam exploit its gas reserves as economic growth boosts energy demand. Vietnam has not developed the distribution network to deliver gas from its offshore fields to industrial and residential consumers. The companies will collaborate on promising projects in third countries including the exploration and development of gas and oil fields. Meanwhile, Gazprom and Eni signed a strategic partnership agreement, which gives Russia access to Italy's gas market. Starting in 2007, Gazprom can ship natural gas directly to the Italian market. The volume of shipments is set to grow to 3 billion cu m by 2010. The agreement extends current gas delivery contracts until 2035.

Title: UK: The world onshore pipelines report 2008-2012
Abstract: The world onshore pipelines report 2008-2012 by Douglas-Westwood examines the current and future prospects, technologies, and markets for the onshore hydrocarbons and energy pipelines business. The report considers the prospects for this huge global market and values the future markets through to 2012, and it includes both a comprehensive view of the historic market from 2003 to 2007, and a forecast for the period from 2008 to 2012. The report starts with identifying existing pipeline projects, and examines the market drivers and prospects. Expenditure is broken down into the main spend areas of land and RoW, linepipe and fittings, pipeline construction, pump station and equipment, and other (including delivery systems, communications, vehicles, etc.). The report describes pipeline design and how routes are selected, safety considerations, sizing, flow and pressure control, and storage. Construction techniques and associated issues are explained from stringing, welding and trenching to backfilling, cleaning, sizing, quality control and testing. Operations and maintenance content includes a review of control, integrity, corrosion protection and repairs.

Title: Projects: CIG-Xcel venture to develop/lease gas pipeline and compression facilities
Abstract: Colorado Interstate Gas (CIG), a subsidiary of El Paso, and Xcel Energy jointly announced that WYCO Development LLC plans to develop and lease new natural gas transportation and storage facilities in Colorado. The companies are equal partners in the joint venture to develop the proposed High Plains Pipeline Project. The project includes 164 mi of natural gas transmission pipeline and storage facilities having working capacity of ≈ 7 bcf. The facilities will be leased and operated by CIG. CIG held a binding open season for the project earlier in 2007 and plans to make the necessary regulatory filings later in 2007.

Title: Newsreel: Spectra Energy, New Jersey resources plan storage facility
Abstract: Spectra Energy and New Jersey Resources have formed a partnership to jointly develop and operate a natural gas storage facility with the capacity to store in excess of 10 bcf of working natural gas for markets in Pennsylvania and the northeast US. Steckman Ridge LP, the new venture owned equally by subsidiaries of Spectra Energy and New Jersey Resources, reached an agreement with Pennsylvania General Energy Co LLC to acquire its depleted natural gas field located in Bedford County, PA. Steckman Ridge will convert the field into a multi-cycle storage facility that will provide growing energy markets in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic with supply security and flexibility, especially during winter.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Duke Energy Gas Transmission (DEGT) plans...
Abstract: Duke Energy Gas Transmission (DEGT) plans to expand its Gulf Coast gas-storage facilities by > 35 bcf during the next 6 yr. The gas will be stored in salt caverns in Acadia Parish, LA, and Liberty County, TX, and in a proposed operation in Copiah County, MS. These sites, which will all be completed by 2012, will have a total working capacity of about 70 bcf.

Title: Refining and marketing: UK: Contaminated gasoline sourced from Harvest Energy
Abstract: Harvest Energy admitted that there were unusually high levels of silicon in gasoline it had supplied to several retailers, including the Tesco supermarket chain. The contaminated fuel, supplied in late February 2007, had caused many cars to break down because the impurity affected the engine's oxygen sensor and catalytic converter. The company said the gasoline was stored in four tanks, used exclusively by the firm, at the Vopak London storage terminal, at West Thurrock on the River Thames. The tanks were isolated and stocks at over 100 filling stations in the southeast of the country were tested. The firm did not say where the gasoline had originated, nor why it had a high silicon content. The fuel supplied had continued to meet the European and UK specification for unleaded gasoline (BS EN 228), because the specification does not include a test for silicon, which is not an element that would normally be expected to be present. It is now testing for silicon routinely, and has called for a silicon test to be included in BS EN 228. The company shares the use of the West Thurrock terminal with Greenergy. Greenergy said tests had shown that its gasoline was free of silicon and it had asked Harvest to clarify the situation urgently. Vopak said it was not responsible for the quality of products delivered into its facilities.

Title: Top of the news: Valero L.P., Valero GP Holdings take on NuStar name
Abstract: As a result of the separation from Valero Energy Corp, Valero LP and Valero GP Holdings LLC have officially changed their names to NuStar Energy LP and NuStar GP Holdings LLC, respectively. NuStar Energy LP has 9113 mi of pipeline, 87 terminal facilities, and four crude oil storage facilities. The partnership's combined system has ∼ 80 million bbl of storage capacity, and includes crude oil and refined product pipelines, refined product terminals, petroleum and a specialty liquids storage and terminaling business, as well as crude oil storage tank facilities.

Title: Ireland: To invest $1.6bn in energy projects
Abstract: Ireland will invest $1.6 billion to develop strategic energy infrastructure. Supply security, competitive energy prices, and environmental sustainability are all key priorities under the government's current plans, which include improving its gas interconnection with Scotland, developing a strategic oil storage project to maximize oil stocks, and constructing a gas storage facility to help ease supply disruptions. From 2005-2010, energy demand in Ireland is projected to increase by 1.6%/yr, gas demand by 6.5%/yr, and electricity by 3.1%/yr. Ireland will commit $350 million to sustainable energy sources, and $193.4 million to energy research.

Title: Newsreel: GE makes first investment in natural gas storage
Abstract: GE Energy Financial Services is making its first investment in natural gas storage, acquiring a preferred equity interest in an underground salt dome storage project in Louisiana for $65 million from Haddington Energy Partners III LP. The investment, which will help cover the project's capital expenditures, enables GE Energy Financial Services to expand in midstream energy where it co-owns pipelines, retail distribution, and gas processing assets. The project's location, 1.5 mi southwest of Port Barre, provides access to natural gas from offshore in the Gulf of Mexico, onshore in Texas and Louisiana, as well as from the Barnett Shale. Bobcat will interconnect with five major interstate pipelines, i.e., Florida Gas Transmission Co, Texas Eastern Transmission Corp, Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corp, ANR Pipeline Co, and Gulf South Pipeline Co. The project is initially planned to provide up to 13.5 bcf of working gas storage capacity (Bcfw) in two new 6.75 Bcfw underground salt caverns. Construction began in December 2006 with service from Cavern 1 scheduled to begin during the third quarter of 2008 and Cavern 2 scheduled to enter operation in the third quarter of 2009. The project can be expanded to five caverns, bringing total capacity to ≈ 34 Bcfw. Construction costs for the first two caverns are estimated at $200 million.

Title: News in brief: Latin America: Peru: Maple Energy, which owns a gas...
Abstract: Maple Energy, which owns a gas and NGL producer in Mexico's eastern jungle, will soon start planting sugarcane on the northern coast for a project to produce 30 million USG/yr of ethanol. The estimated project cost of $160 million includes construction of a processing plant, the development of the cane fields and construction of storage tanks at the northern port of Paita from where the ethanol would be exported.

Title: Onshore exploration and development update
Abstract: Nova Scotia's energy potential portfolio is very promising in areas of conventional, coal-bed methane, and shale gas exploration. Underground gas storage and LNG regasification initiatives are also progressing. Two LNG projects are currently being developed in the Strait area of Nova Scotia. Maple LNG's Nova Scotia project will initially include three LNG storage tanks of 160,000 cu m capacity, providing a send-out capacity of 9 bcm/yr. The development will be phased, starting at 9 bcm/yr and expanding to 18 bcm/yr. The Goldboro site will be able to receive LNG carriers up to 250,000 cu m. Keltic Petrochemicals Inc received conditional approval for a petrochemical/LNG project on the North Shore of Stormont Bay in Goldboro, Guysborough County, Nova Scotia. Nova Scotia is also exploring green renewable energy, e.g., wind, tidal and wave energy, as part of its energy portfolio.

Title: Colombia: Energy company wins bid for pipeline operator
Abstract: Colombia's Empresa de Energia de Bogota (EEB) won control of Ecogas with a $1.42-billion bid in one of the nation's biggest privatizations. EEB's bid for Ecogas' 3700-km network of pipelines - the country's largest - beat a $1.26 billion bid from a consortium including Prisma Energy. As part of a system upgrade, EEB wants to increase the capacity of Ecogas' pipeline that transports gas from the Cusiana field along the eastern border with Venezuela. Cusiana is operated by BP in association with Ecopetrol and Total. Meanwhile; a dollar;537-million multi-products petrol and diesel pipeline linking Mozambique's Matola oil refinery to Nelspruit in South Africa is expected to be complete by 2009. The 400-km long project from Matola to Nelspruit, NE of Johannesburg, could be extended in a second phase to South Africa's emerging industrial city of Witbank, halfway between Johannesburg and Nelspruit. The pipeline will have the capacity to transport 5 m ton/yr of gasoline and diesel, and the project also includes rehabilitation of the refinery storage tanks in Matola.

Title: News: Greece: Investments in low-sulphur fuel production in Thessaloniki
Abstract: Hellenic Petroleum SA will invest €130 million to upgrade the Thessaloniki Refinery. The project builds on pre-investments in isomerization and desulfurization plants. The improvement of the refinery involves vital modifications and additions to the distillation and desulfurization plants and the storage and distribution units, and to replace the existing old-technology naphtha plain into a new one using the latest technology to purify fuel. The project will achieve a significant improvement in energy yield while at the same time helping to ease the greenhouse effect and achieving a 55% reduction in SO2 emissions and a 45% drop in suspended particles. Completion is due by the end of 2009.

Title: News in brief: United States: Spectra Energy plans to boost capacity...
Abstract: Spectra Energy is planning to boost capacity at its Market Hub-Egan gas-storage facility in Acadia Parish, LA, by a third to 32 bcf. The company intends to add a salt-dome cavern that can hold 8 bcf beginning in phases that start in 2009. Separately, Spectra and New Jersey Resources have formed a partnership, Steckman Ridge, to convert a depleted gasfield in Bedford County, PA, into a $250 million storage facility with a capacity in excess of 10 bcf of working gas. The facility would start operations in first-half 2009.

Title: Analysis: BP, Rio Tinto launch clean carbon with Kwinana project
Abstract: BP and Rio Tinto have formed a joint venture company that will develop carbon capture and storage power projects around the world. The companies have already announced a first new project for the joint venture company, Hydrogen Energy, with a $1.5 billion project to build a coal-fired power plant with carbon capture and storage at Kwinana, Western Australia. Within a few days of its creation, the joint venture launched a feasibility study into the Kwinana plant. According to Hydrogen Energy, the plant would have a capacity of 500 Mw, equivalent to 15% of the demand of south-west Australia, and capture around 4 million ton/yr of CO2. The CO2 would be stored deep underground, in offshore geological structures in the Perth Basin. However, Rio Tinto warns that because of the extra cost of capturing and storing CO2, the project will only be commercially viable if the Australian government puts in place "appropriate policy support and a regulatory environment which recognizes and encourages the low-carbon benefits it can deliver". Hydrogen Energy expects to make a final investment decision in 2011. If it decides to go ahead, the plant could be built by 2014.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Xcel Energy and El Paso...
Abstract: Xcel Energy and Colorado Interstate Gas are partnering on a $290 million project to complete the High Plains Pipeline Project, which includes 64 mi of new pipelines and a storage facility capable of holding about 7 bcf of gas. The pipeline system would run from the Cheyenne Hub area to Xcel's system in the Denver area and would be able to transport about 0.87 bcf/day.

Title: Analysis: UK energy: "Maybe" for nuclear, "Yes" to CCS
Abstract: The UK faces two big energy-related challenges, i.e., climate change and energy security. UK government sets out solution framework in energy white paper. The Planning White Paper 2007 sets out radical changes to the planning system, which will take decisions on key national infrastructure in a way that is timely, efficient, and predictable, and which will improve the accountability of the system, the transparency of decisions, and the ability of the public and communities to participate effectively in them. A discussion covers cleaner coal and gas via carbon capture and storage (CCS) with electricity generation; nuclear generation; clean energy supplies of electricity and heat; and mixed reviews received by the paper from environmentalists and proponents of nuclear and CCS alike.

Title: International: SUEZ plans LNG terminal in Northern Chile
Abstract: Suez Energy International will partner with Codelco to build GNL Mejillones SA, an LNG regasification terminal in Mejillones, in the northern Chilean region of Antofagasta. Investments will total $500 million. In a first phase (2009-2012), the project includes construction of a jetty and an onshore LNG regasification terminal with a sendout capacity of 5.5 million cu m of gas, sufficient to produce 1100 Mw of electricity. An LNG vessel with a storage capacity of ≈ 135,000 cu m will be permanently moored and serve as a floating storage. In a second phase, an onshore storage tank of 160,000 cu m will be built.

Title: Projects: Rockies express to begin construction on REX-West
Abstract: The FERC has approved construction of the Rockies Express-West project, 713 mi of 42-in. dia pipeline that will extend from the Cheyenne Hub in Weld County, CO, to an interconnection with Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line located in Audrain County, MO. The pipeline will also interconnect with the pipeline systems of Kinder Morgan Interstate Gas Transmission, Northern Natural Gas Co, Natural Gas Pipeline Co of America and ANR. Actual construction on Rockies Express-West is expected to start in May 2007 with an in-service target date of 1/1/2008. Rockies Express Pipeline LLC is a $4.4 billion joint venture of Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, Sempra Pipelines and Storage, a unit of Sempra Energy, and ConocoPhillips. When completed, the 1678-mi pipeline will have a ∼ 1.8 bcf/day capacity. The first 328-mi segment of the Rockies Express project, which runs from the Meeker Hub in Rio Blanco County, CO, to the Wamsutter Hub in Sweetwater County, WY, to the Cheyenne Hub, is in service and has a current capacity of 500,000 Dth/day. The final segment of the project is Rockies Express-East, which will consist of 637 mi of pipeline from eastern Missouri to the Clarington Hub in eastern Ohio. Subject to receipt of regulatory approvals, Rockies Express-East is expected to start interim service as early as 1/1/2009, and to be fully operational by June 2009.

Title: News in brief: North America: United States: Jordan Cove Energy Project plans...
Abstract: Jordan Cove Energy Project plans to construct an LNG import terminal, Jordan Cove LNG, in Coos Bay, OR. The facility will have an LNG storage capacity of 6.4 bcf and a send-out capacity of 1 bcf/day. Pacific Connector Gas Pipeline plans to construct the Pacific Connector, a 230 mi interstate gas-transmission system designed to transport up to 1 bcf/day from the proposed Jordan Cove terminal to markets in the region.

Title: Projects: Falcon Gas Storage to build North Texas Pipeline
Abstract: Falcon Gas Storage Co Inc plans to build a 63-mi, 24-in. dia gas pipeline primarily to serve its expanded 16 bcf working capacity Worsham-Steed Gas Storage Facility in the western portion of the prolific Barnett Shale gas play in North Texas. Capacity in the new pipeline will be 450,000 M cu ft/day, with commercial operation scheduled to begin on 9/1/2007. The route of the proposed line will extend southward from the Worsham-Steed storage facility through Jack, Parker, and Hood Counties where it will interconnect with the two existing major 36-in. dia gas transmission pipelines that serve North Texas - the North Texas Pipeline, jointly owned by Enterprise Products Partners and Energy Transfer Partners, and the Atmos Energy Line "X" Pipeline. In addition to an existing interconnection with Energy Transfer's Old Ocean pipeline at Worsham-Steed, the new pipeline also will connect with Devon's Acacia pipeline, Atmos' Line "WA".

Title: Markets: Europe: Eni urges action to avert "looming threat" of gas shortage
Abstract: According to Eni's chief executive, Paulo Scaroni, demand growth and the need to replace ageing power stations in Europe could lead to natural gas demand in 2020 being 40% higher than today. The net result would be that Europe would need to import double the amount of gas that it does now - in other words, imports would need to increase from 300 billion cu m/yr to 0.6 trillion cu m/yr. Europe's staggering dependence on imports means action is needed to mitigate the risk of a shortage. To satisfy Europe's incremental electricity demand using nuclear power, around 70 new plants or around 115 Gw of nuclear capacity will be needed by 2020. To satisfy incremental demand using wind and solar power would require 15,000 new turbines and 50,000 football fields of solar panels to be installed each year. However, alternative energy sources will not even be able to cover just Europe's incremental electricity demand from here to 2020. Much of this growth will inevitably be satisfied by gas. The second set of proposals involved reducing the importance of gas in Europe's energy mix by resurrecting nuclear power, boosting research into renewables, and developing efficient and effective carbon capture and storage technologies. The third proposal is focused on energy efficiency. Scaroni insisted that even if all three sets of proposals were pursued, the reality would still be Europe's continuing reliance on a small number of gas suppliers, particularly Russia.

Title: Kiev comes in from the cold
Abstract: Ukraine averted a gas-supply crisis after agreeing a mechanism with Gazprom for paying $2 billion that the Russian firm says it is owed for gas shipments. Gazprom warned its European customers that it would start reducing gas supplies to Ukraine unless Ukraine settled unpaid gas debts of $1.3 billion. Ukraine's energy minister, Yury Boiko, promptly agreed on a scheme for repayment, consisting of some $0.9 billion in cash and around $1.2 billion worth of gas, to be returned to Russia from Ukraine's storage facilities. Gazprom's threat to stop supplies to Ukraine raised concerns about shortfalls to Europe, i.e., any interruption could affect supplies if Ukraine were to resort to stealing gas from the transit pipelines that feed Europe, as has happened in the past. Thus, the swift resolution was welcomed in Europe, as well as in Russia and Ukraine.

Title: News: Batteries for water buses
Abstract: Saft, a world leader in high technology batteries, is provid?ing efficient, silent and environmentally friendly power for two new all-electric water buses that have just started operation on the Saint-Denis canal in Paris. This innovative service connects the Corentin Cariou Metro station to the dock at Millenaire Park, a canal jour?ney of around 7 min, it also serves the Park "Fortes de Paris" in the Seine St Denis district. The high energy storage capacity and light weight of the Saft rechargeable nickel-cadmium batteries enables the water buses to remain in constant operation for a 6-hr shift (around 30 return trips) between charges, as they carry up to 75 passengers at speeds between six and 12 kph over a 1.1 km route. Its total weight of 2150 kg is estimated to be some 30% less than the equivalent lead-acid battery system, and without this weight saving a successful design for a boat able to carry 75 passengers would not have been viable.

Title: Contracts: Jacobs on two a day
Abstract: On 6/12/2007, Jacobs made two separate deals with two separate firms. The first was an engineering design services contract with Lyondell Chemical Technology, a subsidiary of Lyondell Chemical Co. It includes the provision of design services to prepare the technical details of the licensor's project design package for the world's largest propylene oxide/styrene monomer project in China's Ningbo. Lyondell aims to produce 274,000 ton/yr of propylene oxide and 620,000 ton/yr of styrene monomer. The second deal is a partnership contract with Essent Projects, the Netherlands-based energy company, that will run for 3 yr. Jacobs will supply front-end design and engineering, procurement, and construction management services for Essent's power and natural gas projects. Jacobs' first two tasks concern a new underground gas storage facility and new interconnections to accommodate expansion of a power station in The Netherlands.

Title: Canada: TransCanada to acquire ANR
Abstract: TransCanada Corp plans to significantly expand its continental natural gas pipeline and storage operations by acquiring ANR Pipeline Co and ANR Storage Co, and an additional 3.55% interest in Great Lakes Gas Transmission Ltd from El Paso Corp. With the acquisition of ANR, TransCanada's wholly-owned natural gas pipeline network will extend more than 59,000 km and offer customers unparalleled connections from traditional and emerging supply basins to growing North American markets. By acquiring more than 230 bcf of gas storage capacity, TransCanada will have interests in ≈ 360 bcf of storage, making it one of North America's largest gas storage operators. In a separate transaction, TransCanada subsidiary TC PipeLines will acquire 46.45% of Great Lakes from El Paso for $962 million. On closing of these acquisitions, TransCanada's portfolio of energy infrastructure assets will include: ≈ 59,000 km of wholly-owned natural gas pipelines, which include the Alberta System, the Canadian Mainline, the BC System, Foothills, Gas Transmission Northwest, North Baja, Tamazunchale, and ANR.

Title: Projects: Spectra energy to invest $1.5 billion in northeast gas market
Abstract: Spectra Energy plans to invest about $1.5 billion in cost-effective expansions that will bring incremental natural gas supplies to the growing New England, New York, and New Jersey markets.
