As new supplies enter the region this November 2007 and new infrastructure is placed into service, those markets will have unparalleled access to significant sources of eastern US seaboard LNG and western U.S. natural gas. A significant advancement in increasing supply access is the company's proposed East-to-West Project, an expansion of its Algonquin pipeline that will bring > 1 bcf/day of eastern LNG-based supplies into Northeast markets through the reversal of flow on the system. The project, which will utilize existing infrastructure combined with new pipeline and compression, is expected to be in service by 11/1/2009. Spectra is constructing additional pipeline and storage expansions as part of its continuous Northeast strategy to provide right-sized and well-timed projects to the market. Projects under construction include the Texas Eastern Incremental Market Expansion (TIME) II Project; Algonquin Northeast Gateway Project, Algonquin Cape Cod Extension, Algonquin Ramapo Expansion, and Maritimes & Northeast Pipeline Phase IV Expansion Project where Spectra serves as the lead partner. The project is expected to be in service in late 2009. The company also plans to explore the need for incremental pipeline capacity from Oakford to the Northeast markets.

Title: ECS Transactions - Electrochemistry of Novel Electrode Materials for Energy Conversion and Storage
Abstract: The proceedings contain 41 papers. The topics discussed include: characterization of core-shell type cathode material in Li-ion cells; electrochemical and thermal studies of LiFePO4 cathode in lithium-ion cells; cathodic electrodeposition of mixed rhenium-molybdenum oxides; electrochemical performance of various electrodes for lithium-ion batteries deposited by the condensation-solidification method; chemical vapor deposition of nanocarbon-supported platinum and palladium catalysts for oxygen reduction; some observations on the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at platinum catalysts based on post year 2000 reports; direct mechanism of OH radicals formation in PEM fuel cells; preparation of pt/electro-conductive polymer loaded carbon composite for improvement of electrode durability for fuel cells; oxygen reduction on PtFe/C electrocatalysts prepared in microemulsions; and electrochemical behaviour of platinum nanoparticles supported on polypyrrole (PPy)/C composite.

Title: ECS Transactions - Nanomaterials for Energy Conversion and Storage at the 212th ECS Meeting
Abstract: The proceedings contain 13 papers. The topics discussed include: synthesis of NiO nanowires for use in lithium batteries; nanocomposite solid electrolytes based on lithium perchlorate; synthesis and electrochemical properties of a novel molybdenum oxyfluoride perovskite; platinum coated fuel cell electrodes by atomic layer deposition; synthesis of Pd-Sn nanoparticles by using ultrasonic irradiation and their elecrocatalytic activity for oxygen reduction; novel non-precious metal electroccatalysts for oxygen reduction based on nanostructured cobalt chalcogenide; stabilization and characterization of Pt nanoparticles on HOPG; electroless deposition of metals and alloys for microelectronics, nanoelectronics, piezoengineering and composites fabrication; and study of underlying electrochemical mechanisms in nanoscale amorphous carbon-iodine electrodes.

Authors: Gonzalez A.J., Sanchez-Juarez A., Fernandez A., Mathew X., Sebastian P.J.
Title: Converting Solar Radiation to Electric Power in Mexico
Affiliations: Departamento de Materiales Solares, Centro de Investigación en Energía, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Temixco, Morelos, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Gonzalez, A.J., Departamento de Materiales Solares, Centro de Investigación en Energía, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Temixco, Morelos, Mexico; Sanchez-Juarez, A., Departamento de Materiales Solares, Centro de Investigación en Energía, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Temixco, Morelos, Mexico; Fernandez, A., Departamento de Materiales Solares, Centro de Investigación en Energía, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Temixco, Morelos, Mexico; Mathew, X., Departamento de Materiales Solares, Centro de Investigación en Energía, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Temixco, Morelos, Mexico; Sebastian, P.J., Departamento de Materiales Solares, Centro de Investigación en Energía, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México, Temixco, Morelos, Mexico
Abstract: The generation of electric power for supplying the populations of large cities is effected at an elevated cost, given that this cost does not include solely the price of generating the electric power itself, i.e., production, storage, labor, maintenance of installations, distribution, etc., but, in addition, bears the associated costs of damage to the environment due to the production of residual pollutants, and the consequent damage to the health of humans, and to the flora and fauna. © 2007, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
Author Keywords: Crystalline Silicon Solar Cell; Monocrystalline Silicon; Silicon Solar Cell; Solar Cell; Thin Film Solar Cell
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Electric power generation; Solar power plants; Associated costs; Electric power; Generation of electric power; Large cities; Me-xico; Electric power distribution

Title: Hydrogen: The Ecological Fuel for Mexican Future
Affiliations: Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Fernández-Valverde, S.M., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico
Abstract: Mexico, as many other countries, needs the substitution of fossil fuels to avoid the environmental and health problems produced by their burning. Hydrogen is an important alternative energy source for the growing energy demand and the answer to the present need of a clean, efficient, and environmentally-friendly fuel. While the proved hydrocarbon reserves in Mexico will last for just some more decades, hydrogen, in counterpart, is the most abundant element in the universe and the third one in the earth’s surface. Burning hydrogen in a combustion engine produces water and a small amount of nitrogen oxides, which can be eliminated in proton exchange membrane fuel cells or in alkaline fuel cells. Fuel cells working with hydrogen are electrochemical devices where the recombination of hydrogen with oxygen produces electricity, heat and water in a silent manner. In the seventies, most countries started in hydrogen research and development due to the petroleum crisis; being Germany, Canada and Japan the most advanced countries in the area. USA announced in 2003 a $1.2 billion Hydrogen Fuel Initiative to develop technology for commercially viable hydrogen-powered fuel cells. Iceland, one of the countries with large contaminant emissions, is working to become the first hydrogen based economy. In the other hand, two hydrogen isotopes, deuterium and tritium, could produce energy for the future through thermonuclear reactions. Mexico needs to include in its energetic program research and development in hydrogen for its use as an energy carrier of the renewable and still non renewable energy sources. Mexico should also explore the possibility of becoming a member of the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor ITER project, like other countries (e.g. India), to develop a clean energy future. © 2007, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
Author Keywords: Direct Methanol Fuel Cell; Fuel Cell; Hydrogen Production; Hydrogen Storage; Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell
Index Keywords: Alkaline fuel cells; Experimental reactors; Fossil fuels; Gas fuel purification; Nitrogen oxides; Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC); Renewable energy resources; Tokamak devices; Alternative energy source; Contaminant emissions; Environmentally friendly fuels; Hydrocarbon reserves; Hydrogen-based economy; International thermonuclear experimental reactor; Non-renewable energy sources; Research and development; Hydrogen economy

Authors: Balcázar-García M., Flores-Ruiz J.H., Peña P., López A.
Title: Natural Safety Storage of Radioactive Waste
Affiliations: Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Balcázar-García, M., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico; Flores-Ruiz, J.H., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico; Peña, P., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico; López, A., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico
Abstract: The public acceptance of an increase program of nuclear energy requires an openly and straight forward discussion, in an understandable way of the main issues against nuclear energy as: nuclear accidents, proliferation of nuclear weapons and safety storage of nuclear waste. Regarding this last issue, there are doubts concerning stability of geological sites to storage nuclear waste as well as possible leakage and migration of radioactive waste from containers, which potentially could contaminate underground aquifers. Technical explanations about safety designs of those nuclear waste storages do not convince general public because of the thousand of year half-life of the radioactive generating material from uranium fuel. Nature has contributed to present us a wonderful example concerning immobility of nuclear waste, not in a period of thousand of years, but thousands of million of years. This paper describes the discovery of several Nuclear Reactors (NRs) that operated two thousand of million years ago, in the Republic of Gabon, Africa. The discovery of at least 17 NRs in Oklo uranium mine in Gabon was possible from the analysis of the nuclear waste that remaining undisturbed in that mine for nearly two thousand of million years. The reactors were very small of about ten centimeters in diameter and had a power of around 100 kilowatts and were intermittently operating during 150,000 years. Xenon gases generated from the reactors were kept in the crystalline matrix of aluminium phosphate glasses. Recent analysis of the whole production and trapping process of xenon gasses permitted to know that reactors were intermittently operating in cycles of about 30 minutes and additionally aluminium phosphate glasses showed the capability of trapping xenon gasses in its crystalline matrix for nearly two thousand of millions years. This paper presents the “design”, functioning and safety storage of nucl waste of NRs that were performed by interdisciplinary work by nature in Oklo, long before man appeared on earth. © 2007, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
Author Keywords: Crystalline Matrix; Nuclear Waste; Phosphate Glass; Radioactive Waste; Safety Storage
Index Keywords: Aluminum compounds; Aquifers; Glass; Groundwater pollution; Hydrogeology; Nanocrystalline materials; Nuclear energy; Nuclear reactor accidents; Nuclear reactors; Nuclear weapons; Radioactive wastes; Radioactivity; Radioisotopes; Uranium; Xenon; Aluminium phosphates; Crystalline matrices; General publics; Interdisciplinary work; Nuclear accidents; Nuclear waste storage; Public acceptance; Uranium fuels; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Chávez R.-H., Guadarrama J.J., Klapp J.
Title: CO2 Capture for Atmosphere Pollution Reduction
Affiliations: Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico; Instituto Tecnológico de Toluca, Av. Tecnológico S/N, Metepec, 52140, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Chávez, R.-H., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico; Guadarrama, J.J., Instituto Tecnológico de Toluca, Av. Tecnológico S/N, Metepec, 52140, Mexico; Klapp, J., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico
Abstract: Carbon dioxide is considered to be the major source of greenhouse gases responsible for global warming; man-made CO2 contributes approximately 63.5 % to all greenhouse gases. Efforts towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions have increased in the past few years, offering promising alternatives in power generation and better fuel efficiency. However, the incorporation of these new technologies to our daily lives represents a big challenge to be solved in the mid- to long-term, leaving separation and CO2 sequestration to be an immediate priority for researchers. CO2 capture and storage can support the transition of our fossil fuel based energy supply towards a sustainable energy system, based upon nuclear and renewable sources. Our present energy infrastructure will largely remain the same during this transition period. For example, electric power plants will be equipped with CO2 capture units, but will produce the same electricity, transported and distributed over the same grid. The first step in the CO2 capture and storage chain is to capture carbon in a high concentration. This can be done before or after combustion of the fuel. Capture is best carried out at large sources of emissions, such as power stations, refineries and other industrial complexes. There are several ways to capture CO2, some of the main methods are absorbents using solvents or solid sorbents, which have been used in industry for several years and seems to be the most feasible solution at this time; membranes have also become an interesting alternative and although extensive research is in progress, new materials for membranes have yet to be discovered. Other methods like pressure- and temperature-swing adsorption using various solid sorbents, cryogenic distillation and new emerging technologies show promising results in the bench testing scale. This report presents a comparison between these different methods. © 2007, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
Author Keywords: Energy Penalty; Hydrate Formation; Integrate Gasification Combine Cycle; Pressure Swing Adsorption; Solid Sorbent
Index Keywords: Adsorbents; Carbon dioxide; Distillation; Electric power systems; Fossil fuel power plants; Fossil fuels; Fuel storage; Gas emissions; Global warming; Greenhouse gases; Industrial emissions; Membranes; Atmosphere pollution; Cryogenic distillations; Emerging technologies; Energy infrastructures; Industrial complex; Pressure and temperature; Renewable sources; Sustainable energy systems; Electric power plants

Authors: Castellón C., Medrano M., Roca J., Nogués M., Castell A., Cabeza L.F.
Title: Use of microencapsulated phase change materials in building applications
Source title: Thermal Performance of the Exterior Envelopes of Whole Buildings
Affiliations: University of Lleida, Spain; Applied Energy Research Group, University of Lleida, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Castellón, C., University of Lleida, Spain; Medrano, M., Applied Energy Research Group, University of Lleida, Spain; Roca, J., University of Lleida, Spain; Nogués, M., University of Lleida, Spain; Castell, A., University of Lleida, Spain; Cabeza, L.F., Applied Energy Research Group, University of Lleida, Spain
Abstract: Phase Change Materials (PCMs) have been considered for thermal storage in buildings since before 1980. In the literature, development and testing were conducted for prototypes of PCM wallboard and PCM concrete systems to enhance the thermal energy storage (TES) capacity of standard gypsum wallboard and concrete blocks, with particular interest in peak load shifting and solar energy utilization. The idea studied here was to integrate a PCM in construction materials and test them in real buildings to check improvements in thermal performance. The first experiment was the inclusion of a microencapsulated PCM in concrete and the construction of a small house-sized cubicle with this new PCM-concrete. A second cubicle with the exact same characteristics and orientation, but built with standard concrete, was located next to the first one as the reference case. The thermal behavior of such cubicles was tested during the years 2005 and 2006. In autumn 2006 a Trombe wall was added in both cubicles and its influence was investigated. The results were very good, since temperature differences up to 4ºC were observed between both cubicles and peak temperatures in the PCM cubicle were shifted to later hours © 2007, American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers, Inc.

Title: ASHRAE Transactions - Papers presented at the 2007 Winter Meeting of the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers
Abstract: The proceedings contain 66 papers. The topics discussed include: the use of numerical acoustics to solve classic acoustics problems at an HVAC original equipment manufacturer; using numerical acoustics to predict the attenuation of HVAC plenums (RP-1218); using numerical methods to analyze multicomponent HVAC systems (RP-1218); net zero energy building case study: science house; tale of two low-energy designs: comparison of mechanically and naturally ventilated office buildings in temperate climates; measured energy performance of a US-China demonstration energy-efficient office building; applications of customized absorption heat pumps with heating capacities above 500 kW; designing sustainable on-site CHP systems; low-temperature heat storage for solar heating and cooling applications; performance of a rack of liquid-cooled servers; and comparison between underfloor supply and overhead supply ventilation designs for data center high-density clusters.
Index Keywords: Acoustic variables control; Heating; Office buildings; Solar heating; Ventilation; Energy efficient office building; Energy performance; Overhead supply ventilation; Air conditioning

Title: Luminescent Materials
Affiliations: School of Chemical and Physical Sciences SCPS, Victoria University, Kelburn Parade/PO Box 600, Wellington, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Edgar, A., School of Chemical and Physical Sciences SCPS, Victoria University, Kelburn Parade/PO Box 600, Wellington, New Zealand
Abstract: This chapter surveys the field of solid-state luminescent materials, beginning with a discussion of the different ways in which luminescence luminescence can be excited. The internal energy-level structures of luminescent ions and centres, particularly rare-earth ions, are then discussed before the effects of the vibrating host lattice are included. Having set the theoretical framework in place, the chapter then proceeds to discuss the specific excitation process for photo-stimulated luminescence and thermally stimulated luminescence before concluding by surveying stimulated luminescencephosphortelevision screensX-ray storage current applications, including plasma television screens, long-term persistent phosphors, X-ray storage phosphors, scintillators, and phosphors for white LEDs. © 2006, Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Compute Radiography; Glow Curve; Light Emit Diode; Optically Stimulate Luminescence; Thermally Stimulate Luminescence

Title: Front end accessory drive vibration control solutions for engines with cylinder deactivation
Affiliations: Schaeffler Group USA Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Thompson, S., Schaeffler Group USA Inc.; Brechko, A., Schaeffler Group USA Inc.
Abstract: Recent internal combustion engine developments for passenger car and truck applications are incorporating cylinder deactivation in order to reduce fuel consumption. This strategy prevents combustion in half of the engine cylinders when power requirements are relatively low. The resulting irregularities from the reduced firing frequency adversely affect the front end accessory drive and require damping and/or tuning devices to lessen their severity. The scope of this paper is to investigate and recommend the best solution for vibration control, based on the increase of torsional energy in the drive. A "Design-of-Analysis" was created to methodically analyze different FEADs, with cylinder deactivation. Several tools were used to control the increased vibration including tensioner devices, multi-rib belt constructions, and alternator pulley devices. The possible solutions will be predicted through the simulation tool SIMDRIVE 3D™, developed by Contecs, and then correlated with test data measured on the actual FEAD system. Copyright © 2007 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Combustion; Digital storage; Vibration control; Vibrations (mechanical); Control solutions; Cylinder deactivation (CDA); Firing frequency; Front end accessory drives; Power requirement; Tensioners; Torsional energies; Tuning devices; Engine cylinders

Title: PMMA/montmorillonite nanocomposites by bulk polymerization: Mechanical and thermal properties
Source title: ICCM International Conferences on Composite Materials
Affiliations: Department of Cosmetic Applications and Management, Tung Fang Institute of Technology, Tungfang Road, Hunei, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Institute of Chemical Engineering, Chinese Culture University, Yang-Ming-Shan, Taipei, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Sun, Y.-Y., Department of Cosmetic Applications and Management, Tung Fang Institute of Technology, Tungfang Road, Hunei, Kaohsiung, Taiwan; Chen, C.-H., Institute of Chemical Engineering, Chinese Culture University, Yang-Ming-Shan, Taipei, Taiwan
Abstract: This paper researched the mechanical and thermal properties of poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA)/montmorillonite (MMT) and PMMA/organic modified montmorillonite (OMMT) nanocomposites. PMMA/MMT and PMMA/OMMT nanocomposites have been synthesized by bulk polymerization. The particles of MMT and OMMT were dispersed using forced agitation and the composites were polymerized using free radical polymerization. The comparison of the addition MMT and OMMT also have been investigated in this experiment. The X-ray analysis showed that exfoliation occurred for the OMMT in the polymer matrix. The effects on the properties of experiment results have been found by static mechanical tests based on flexural strength and modulus, tensile strength and modulus, and impact strength. The dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) based on dynamic storage modulus (E'). The thermal analysis based on differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA).
Author Keywords: Mechanical properties; Montmorillonite; Nanocomposites; PMMA; Thermal properties
Index Keywords: Acrylic monomers; Clay minerals; Differential scanning calorimetry; Dynamics; Energy dispersive X ray analysis; Esters; Free radical polymerization; Free radicals; Glass ceramics; Impact strength; Mechanical properties; Nanocomposites; Tensile strength; Thermoanalysis; Thermodynamic properties; X ray diffraction analysis; Bulk polymerization; Dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA); Mechanical and thermal properties; Modified montmorillonite; ON dynamics; PMMA; Poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA); Static mechanical test; Thermogravimetric analysis

Authors: Guo G., Shane M., Laing P., Jensen T.E.
Title: Development of a new oxygen storage model for SIMTWC
Affiliations: Ford Motor Company
Authors with affiliations: Guo, G., Ford Motor Company; Shane, M., Ford Motor Company; Laing, P., Ford Motor Company; Jensen, T.E., Ford Motor Company
Abstract: The high conversion efficiency required by the modern three-way catalyst (TWC) is dependent on oxygen storage material functionality and capacity. To successfully model a TWC, it is critical that the oxygen storage function in the catalyst be adequately represented. The original oxygen storage model (a simple "bucket" model) included in one of Ford's TWC models, SIMTWC, was developed for vehicle programs meeting LEV emission standards. Application of SIMTWC to test data from vehicles targeting more stringent emission standards, such as ULEV and PZEV, revealed limitations in the accuracy of the original bucket model. To address these limitations, an improved kinetic model of oxygen storage is being developed. This new model is more kinetically-detailed than the old model. Kinetic parameters, i.e., reaction constants and activation energies, are generated from laboratory flow reactor data with low frequency air-fuel ratio changes and validated using laboratory test data with high frequency air-fuel ratio fluctuations. Post-catalyst air-fuel ratio predictions are very close to actual measured values and demonstrate the model capability to handle air-fuel ratio switches typical of real vehicle control strategies. Copyright © 2007 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Activation energy; Catalysts; Control system synthesis; Fuels; Kinetic parameters; Oxygen; Storage (materials); Vehicles; Emission standard; High conversion efficiency; High frequency HF; Kinetic modeling; Laboratory test; Measured values; Oxygen storage materials; Three way catalysts; Digital storage

Title: Expanded polyolefin bead foam property and processing innovations for automotive interior applications
Affiliations: JSP International
Authors with affiliations: Sopher, S.R., JSP International
Abstract: The demand for improved material properties and performance, as well as the demand for weight and cost reduction has presented challenges for the automotive industry as a whole. From the plastic and polymer materials side, the challenge has been incorporating newer polyolefin material technology into existing applications, all while reducing cost and improving performance. This paper will explore novel approaches to meeting the industry need of both cost and weight reduction for plastic interior components, all while meeting the stringent performance and environmental needs of each OEM. Recent advancements in the field of polyolefin resins have enabled new classes of thermoplastic bead foam products to be created which provide enhanced physical properties. These new materials are capable of improved performance due to the advancements that have been made to their base polymers. With the advent of this new technology, Expanded Polyolefin Bead Foams are now being used in newer and more challenging applications ranging from not only energy management and energy absorption, but comfort, structural components, acoustic, storage, and support applications. Along with the advancements in material technology, advances have been made in the way Expanded Polyolefin Bead Foams are being processed. Advancement in the processing of these materials has led to improvements in the areas of; insert molding, multiple density parts, fastener integration, and lamination. All of these newer processing techniques will be discussed in the paper. Copyright © 2007 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Automotive industry; Polymers; Automotive interiors; Environmental needs; Improving performance; Material technologies; Polymer materials; Polyolefin resins; Processing technique; Structural component; Cost reduction

Title: A hybrid power driving system with an energy storage flywheel for vehicles
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Huang, Y.M., Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University, Taiwan; Wang, K.-J., Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University, Taiwan
Abstract: This study generates a conceptual vehicle hybrid power driving system that consists of an internal combustion engine, a motor, two continuously variable transmissions, a generator, a pulse width modulation electric controller, a planetary gear, and an energy storage flywheel. The flywheel drives a generator that generates electric power for the motor to drive the vehicle. The controller with the fuzzy theory is used to determine the torque distribution of the engine and the motor. Using the Japanese 10-15 mode, the driving shaft torque, the engine torque, the motor torque, the torque distribution percentages of the engine and the motor and the flywheel angular velocity versus time were studied with the flywheel moment of inertia to be e 0.6 kg·m2 and 1.2 kg·m2 and the reduction speed ratio to be 0.231. The flywheel moment of inertia to be 1.2 kg·m2 is selected for the system to have more stable operation. Copyright © 2007 SAE International.
Index Keywords: Angular distribution; Electric drives; Electric power system control; Energy storage; Flywheels; Hybrid vehicles; Internal combustion engines; Powertrains; Torque; Vehicle transmissions; Voltage control; Wheels; Continuously variable transmission; Electric power; Energy storage flywheel; Engine torque; Moment of inertia; Planetary Gears; Stable operation; Torque distribution; Electric machine control

Title: Genes regulating adipose-tissue development and function
Affiliations: Medical Genetics, Department of Medical Biochemistry, Göteborg University, Göteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Enerbäck, S., Medical Genetics, Department of Medical Biochemistry, Göteborg University, Göteborg, Sweden
Abstract: In times of excess caloric intake, adipose tissue serves as an energy buffer. Superfluous calories are stored as triglycerides (TGs), ready to satisfy future needs. To perform this seemingly simple task, the adipose tissue needs to be well connected. It needs to know the general energy status of the organism, including present demand, storage capacity, size of present energy store, etc. At yet another level of integration, energy, in the form of free fatty acids (FFA), can be redistributed, for example, from adipose tissue to meet the demands of other cell types (e.g., myocytes). An elaborate system of endocrine and paracrine functions as well as neuronal signaling makes sure that the adipose tissue is well integrated into the general energy network described in greater detail elsewhere in this book. The importance of adipose tissue in this context is illustrated by the dramatic metabolic consequences that are induced by lack of it. Lipodystrophy both in man and mouse leads to, among other things, steatosis, hepatomegaly, and insulin resistance. In mice, transplanting adipose tissue back to lipodystrophic mice has been used as a way to treat this condition (1). This approach leads to a more or less complete reversal of the metabolic disturbances. Thus, supplying ample TG storage capacity to mice that lack it can cure many obesitylinked symptoms such as fatty liver and insulin resistance. © 2008 by Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Proceedings of Science
Abstract: The proceedings contain 61 papers. The topics discussed include: providing HPC resources for Philips research and partners; to what extent can we rely on the results of scientific computations?; automatic calculations for multi-leg processes; computing challenges in oil and gas field simulation; theoretical foundations for computational physics: numerical, symbolic, and algebraic computing grand challenges: an NSF View; the Ganga job management system; a high availability solution for GRID services; grid infrastructure analysis with a simple flow model; the ALICE grid. the beat of a different drum; INFN tier-1 experiences with Castor-2 in CMS computing challenges; experience with fabric storage area network and HSM software at the Tier1 INFN CNAF; PROOF: the parallel ROOT facility. scheduling and load-balancing; the object model to construct the mixed open inventor/ROOT 3D scenes; HEP CG: the high energy physics community grid project inside D-grid; online monitoring for the CDF Run II experiment and the remote operation facilities; D0 global monitoring and outlook for LHC/CMS remote monitoring; database architecture for the calibration of Atlas monitored drift tube chambers; a neural network approach to high energy cosmic rays mass identification at the Pierre Auger observatory; efficient algorithms of multidimensional γ-ray spectra compression using address randomizing transforms; and online electron/jet neural high-level trigger over independent calorimetry information.

Title: Cegasa leads Spanish project on PEM, SOFCs
Abstract: The battery manufacturer Cegasa will direct an ambitious research project aimed at developing PEM and solid oxide fuel cells with improved efficiency over existing technologies. Cegasa will lead a consortium made up of 15 companies and the same number of technology centers, that will be working over the next 4 yr with two main goals: to reduce the environmental impact of electricity-generating technologies, and to develop new products that will generate economic activities in line with this future energy system. This project is committed to the development of two technologies: PEM and solid oxide fuel cells. The research is divided into two main lines of investigation. The first, principal one is aimed at the technological development of the components of the fuel cell itself. The second line of research will focus on the development of technologies necessary to have at hand all the auxiliary components (from fuel storage to electronic control) needed to achieve optimum integrated operation in current and future applications.

Title: DOE releases updated hydrogen posture plan
Abstract: The newly released 2006 Hydrogen Posture Plan outlines a coordinated plan for activities under the Hydrogen Fuel Initiative in the US, at both the DOE and DOT. The goal of the program is to develop hydrogen production, delivery, storage, and fuel cell technologies that enable automobile and energy companies to opt for commercial availability of fuel cell vehicles and hydrogen fuel infrastructure by 2020. The program is focused on R&D activities needed to overcome the barriers to making hydrogen and fuel cell technologies competitive with alternative technologies. The policy assumptions implicit in the 2006 Hydrogen Posture Plan are: learning demonstrations will be used to measure progress; identify issues during real world operation that will provide feedback to the R&D program; validate the performance, durability and cost of the technologies; address systems engineering issues; enable DOE to provide information to Congress and the public on the status of the technology; and educate the public, especially safety and code officials and first responders.

Title: Hydrogen energy demo for Scotland
Abstract: An energy-efficient hydrogen office and demonstration center in Scotland is planned, which will integrate proven renewable energy technologies solar, wind, and geothermal heat pumps with hydrogen and fuel cell energy storage technologies. The development in Methil, Fife will cost £2.8 million and is expected to be complete later of 2007. The project, financed Scottish Enterprise, Alsherra Investments and the European Regional Development Fund from the East of Scotland Program, will work towards meeting the Scottish Executives targets of generating 18% of Scotland's electricity by renewables by 2010, rising to 40% by 2020. The project is anticipated to result in considerable economic benefits for Scotland's economy over the next 25 yr, potentially creating around 1350 new jobs and up to £81 million in gross value added through new businesses starting up to further develop, manufacture, assemble, install and maintain office facilities powered by hydrogen and renewable energy.

Title: UK consortium reports hydrogen storage advance using lithium
Abstract: A breakthrough in hydrogen storage technology could remove a key barrier to the widespread uptake of cars that produce no CO2 emissions. A consortium of UK scientists has developed a lithium compound, which may make it practical to store enough hydrogen onboard fuel cell powered cars to enable them to drive > 300 mi (480 km) before refueling. The breakthrough has been achieved by a team from the Universities of Birmingham and Oxford and the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory in Oxfordshire under the auspices of the UK Sustainable Hydrogen Energy Consortium (UKSHEC). The 4-yr, $11.8 million UKSHEC program is funded by the Sustainable Power Generation and Supply initiative, which is managed and led by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council. The research has focused on an approach, which could enable hydrogen to be stored at a much higher density and within acceptable weight limits. The option involves the well established chemisorption process. The team has now produced a lithium hydride (Li4BN3H10) that could offer the right blend of properties, although development work is needed to further investigate the powder's potential.

Title: Biogas HotModule power for computer center
Abstract: In Germany, a HotModule fuel cell system from CFC Solutions will soon be ensuring reliable operation of the servers in a T-Systems computer center operated by Deutsche Telekom. The power plant will be run on biogas produced from "energy crops" grown in the countryside around Munich. CFC Solutions received the order for installation of the HotModule from Munich-based PASM Power and Air Condition Solution Management GmbH, a subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom. The 250 kw fuel cell system and absorption refrigeration system represent a package solution to supply electricity and cooling capacity for a server suite, which is a self-contained part of the computer center in Munich's Euroindustriepark area. It is based on the trigeneration principle, which combines generation of electrical energy and thermal energy in a single process. The resulting energy efficiency is approximately twice as high as can be achieved using electrically powered air-conditioning systems, as here the thermal energy is utilized to cool the servers. The new HotModule will be officially put into service in the early summer. CFC Solutions calls its innovative approach the Permanent Premium Power principle (P3). Instead of drawing power from the grid and keeping standby generators in reserve, the HotModule takes the opposite approach. The system provides a permanent supply of electrical and thermal energy, even in the event of grid failure. This eliminates the need for a backup system with large diesel engines, storage tanks, and battery rooms.

Title: H2 ECOnomy unveils renewable combination
Abstract: H2 ECOnomy has unveiled a renewable energy system featuring a fuel cell. The system, thought to be the first such system in Eastern Europe and the Middle East, was developed as part of the US government's Global Initiatives for Proliferation Prevention program. The system includes a photovoltaic module consisting of 30 PV panels capable of generating ≤ 4 kw, a PEM electrolyzer with hydrogen storage tanks, a conventional uninterruptible power supply, and a 1 kw PEM fuel cell backup power system developed and prototyped by H2 ECOnomy.

Title: Funding approved for Scottish clean energy schemes
Abstract: More than £1 million in funding has been approved for six projects in Scotland that will develop new technology for the energy industry, with additional applications still being processed. The Scottish Renewable Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Support Scheme program was launched last December 2006, with total support of £1.5 million available. Successful bidders for a share of the scheme include the company St. Andrews Fuel Cells, which secured £160,000 to undertake further research on its solid oxide fuel cell for use with biogas. Western Isles Council H2 SEED received £250,000 for a project that will install an electrolyzer in the Creed Waste Management facility to produce hydrogen from biogas. A sum of £250,000 will also finance a TUV NEL project, which will install a fuel cell and electrolyzer at the Myers Hill wind turbine test site, near East Kilbride, to demonstrate how hydrogen can be used to strengthen an area of constrained grid. The electrolyzer will also provide hydrogen for a fuel cell bus at Whitelee wind farm visitor center. Berwickshire Housing Association will use £223,000 in funding to install a micro renewable powered hydrogen fuel cell in a house in Ayton, Berwickshire, to provide a constant supply of clean energy. There are also plans to establish an energy-efficient hydrogen office and demonstration center at an energy park in Scotland, which will cost £2.8 million. The project will integrate well proven renewable energy technologies solar, wind, and geothermal source heat pumps with hydrogen and fuel cell energy storage technologies.

Title: Proton Power starts work on Czech bus, Swiss street cleaner
Abstract: Proton Power Systems has begun work on a contract for a city bus project in the Czech Republic. Developed in collaboration with Skoda Electric Pilsen, the new electric bus will operate in the Prague region in 2009. PPS has also commenced work on a utility vehicle project in Switzerland in collaboration with Swiss Bucher Municipal. PPS's German subsidiary Proton Motor Fuel Cell GmbH will develop a PEM fuel cell system for the Czech bus using technology based on its dedicated bus fuel cell application. Proton Motor has developed a standard fuel cell module, fueled by hydrogen, integrated with an energy storage system to create a hybrid system capable of providing power during peak demand situations. The market focus is on industrial applications where back-to-base refueling occurs, onsite, at the end of each shift or work period.

Title: AeroVironment's unmanned aircraft achieves record flight
Abstract: AeroVironment worked with Protonex Technology to develop the fuel cell/battery hybrid energy storage system, which included hydrogen generation technology licensed from Millennium Cell in New Jersey. The Puma's standard propulsion system comes equipped with rechargeable batteries with a listed flight time of 2.5 hr. The nearly 5 hr duration of the Puma flight using fuel cell/battery hybrid power surpassed the longest previous Puma flight achieved by AeroVironment using any technology. With a wingspan of 8.5 ft and a weight of 12.5 lb, the Puma is a lightweight, hand-launched unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) that provides aerial observation at line-of-sight ranges up to 6 mi. Each of AeroVironment's small UAS can be transported and set up with minimal logistical footprint, and launched and operated by one person. Each is powered by a replaceable and rechargeable battery pack. Using standard propulsion systems, the Wasp, Raven, and Puma UAS can fly for up to 30, 90, and 150 min, respectively, while wirelessly transmitting live video and other information generated by electro-optical or infrared sensor payloads, enabling their operators to view and capture images on a handheld ground control unit.

Title: Astris Energi sells assets, ECD Ovonics restructures
Abstract: Alkaline fuel cell developer Astris Energi has signed a binding letter of intent with Green Shelters Innovations Ltd (GSI) to sell substantially all of its assets for $5.8 million. The transaction includes the sale of substantially all of the companys assets, including its fuel cell and test load technology. Meanwhile, Energy Conversion Devices (ECD Ovonics) is restructuring its business activities, and substantially reducing its R&D efforts in fuel cell technology. ECD Ovonics is implementing an organizational restructuring plan to consolidate and realign its business activities and reduce annual costs by $23 million when fully implemented by the end of fiscal 2008. The firms new Ovonic Materials business segment is being formed from the consolidation of the Ovonic Battery segment with the remainder of the ECD business segment, including hydrogen storage (Ovonic Hydrogen Systems) and fuel cells (Ovonic Fuel Cell Co).

Title: California hydrogen energy demo under way
Abstract: Southern California Edison (SCE) and Chevron Technology Ventures have dedicated a comprehensive hydrogen energy station evaluation and demonstration program at the utility's headquarters in Rosemead, CA. The 5-yr demonstration, co-funded by the DOE, will provide valuable understanding of hydrogen's potential for future transportation needs. SCE operates a fleet of around 300 electric vehicles. SCE's hydrogen and fuel cell EV evaluation and demonstration program is part of the firm's continued commitment to R&D in electric transportation, and a component of a larger strategy for reducing US greenhouse gas emissions. Specific program components include an on-site alkaline electrolyzer that produces up to 40 kg/day of hydrogen and storage of 60 kg; a power analyzing system that gathers detailed system-wide energy impact data on the entire hydrogen production process; safety systems; and a fleet of up to nine zero-emission Hyundai cars, powered by UTC Power fuel cells that will be evaluated as part of the station's operational demonstration. This is one of five Chevron Hydrogen stations commissioned and implemented in California, Florida, and Michigan.

Title: Germany establishes Europe's largest micro fuel cell program
Abstract: The German government will fund nine projects worth €18 million. The German federal ministry for education and research (BMBF) recognizes that micro fuel cells have an excellent opportunity to dominate the consumer electronics market and take over from established technologies. They could also help Germany to take the technological lead in this sector. The nine projects are focused on industrially applicable products, in particular looking at the overall system, including storage, energy conversion and controllers, and balance-of-plant. Three of the BMBF's existing framework programs (Microsystems, Material Innovations for Industry and Business, and Research for Tomorrow's Production) have been combined to create the new initiative. Some 35 projects were submitted, but only nine were selected for funding (including one on zinc/air fuel cells), in order that the most promising projects would receive significant funding, worth approximately €2 million each. These nine projects, which will be Europe's largest micro fuel cell program, are presented.

Title: BASF acquires PEMEAS
Abstract: BASF Future Business GmbH has agreed to acquire PEMEAS Fuel Cell Technologies for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition was expected to be completed by the end of January 2007. BASF is developing new technologies and materials for energy storage and energy conversion, as well as for alternative energy capture. The chemicals firm sees PEMEAS as an excellent strategic fit, and will speed up ongoing activities in energy management. The company is pursuing two strategies. Its Celtec division is focusing on developing and commercializing membrane-electrode assemblies for high-temperature PEM fuel cells, while the E-TEK division develops and manufactures catalysts, gas diffusion layers and electrodes for low- and high-temperature PEM fuel cells as well as for direct methanol fuel cells.

Title: Erratum: Dissipative Systems Analysis and Control (Psychological Science, (2007)
Abstract: (the first figure indicates the page number) • Notation section: λ(A): an eigenvalue of A ∈ IR n×n. • Notation section: σ(A): the set of eigenvalues of A ∈ IR n×n (i.e. the spectrum of A). • 17, 18, 28: line 2 after (2.22), and also in (2.24), (2.29), (2.30), line 3 in the equation above (2.75): change u T (t) to u t(τ), and u T (jω) to u t (jω). • 17: line 8, the integration is done over τ ∈ [0, t] • 59, lemma 2.55: rational • 81, Lemma 3.11: μmin (A) denotes the minimum eigenvalue of the symmetrized matrix 12 (A + AT). • 81: σmin (B) > 0 is equivalent to Ker(B) = (0), and to m n and B of full rank m. • 81, last line: it is H(jω − μ), not T (jω − μ) • 89 line 6: it is H(jω), not T (jω) • 88, line -3: it is H(jω), not T (jω) • 101: in the framed set of implications/equivalences, the last implication has to be reversed and in the last line this is P = P T ≥ 0 (hence the last condition is really sufficient for PRness as indicated in the paragraph in between the two framed sets. • 119: in (3.134) it is ∂Vf ∂x (x)[Ax + Bu] +w(x, u) ≥ 0 • 121, line 5 after remark 3.38: Thus H(−jω, jω) is the condition…. • 123, left hand side of (3.148): P is G • 124, line 2: P is G • 125: line 5 after Theorem 3.44: numerically • Section 3.9 (Lur’e problem and absolute stability): it’s also worth reading the survey by R. Closely related results concerning Lur’e set-valued systems are in Brogliato and Goeleven, ”Existence, uniqueness of solutions and stability of nonsmooth multivalued Lur’e dynamical systems”, Journal of Convex Analysis, vol.20, no 3, 2013, and ”Well-posedness, stability and invariance results for a class of multivalued Lur’e dynamical systems”, Nonlinear Analysis: Theory, Methods and Applications, vol.74, pp.195-212, 2011. • 167, in Remark 3.96 this is [0, ∞) (see Theorem 3.91) • 175, preservation of dissipativity after time-discretization has recently been tackled in S. Greenhalg, V. Acary, B. Brogliato, ”Preservation of the dissipativity properties of a class of nonsmooth dynamical systems with the (θ, γ)-algorithm”, Numerische Mathematik. See several references that concern this issue in this article. The issue that is tackled concerns the preservation of the strorage function, the supply rate, and the dissipation function, and therefore yields much more stringent conditions than the mere preservation of dissipativity (with possible different supply rate, dissipation function after discretization). • 170, about the Popov’s line. Hill and P. Moylan: ”Stability results for nonlinear feedback systems”, Automatica, vol.13, pp.377-382, 1977, and ”General instability results for interconnected systems”, SIAM J. Control and Optimization, vol.21, no 2, pp.256-279, 1983. The errata for these papers include the following. James et al, SIAM J. Control Optimization, vol.43, no 5, pp.1535-1582, 2005. • 366: generally speaking BV functions do not satisfy that for any t, there exists a σ such the function is continuous on [t, t+σ). This is because at t a BV function may possess an accumulation of jumps on the left, and an accumulation of jumps on the right. Authors: Balcázar-García M., Flores-Ruiz J.H., Peña P., López A.
Title: Natural safety storage of radioactive waste
Source title: Environmental Science and Engineering (Subseries: Environmental Science)
Affiliations: Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Balcázar-García, M., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico; Flores-Ruiz, J.H., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico; Peña, P., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico; López, A., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México DF, 11801, Mexico
Abstract: The public acceptance of an increase program of nuclear energy requires an openly and straight forward discussion, in an understandable way of the main issues against nuclear energy as: nuclear accidents, proliferation of nuclear weapons and safety storage of nuclear waste. Regarding this last issue, there are doubts concerning stability of geological sites to storage nuclear waste as well as possible leakage and migration of radioactive waste from containers, which potentially could contaminate underground aquifers. Technical explanations about safety designs of those nuclear waste storages do not convince general public because of the thousand of year half-life of the radioactive generating material from uranium fuel. Nature has contributed to present us a wonderful example concerning immobility of nuclear waste, not in a period of thousand of years, but thousands of million of years. This paper describes the discovery of several Nuclear Reactors (NRs) that operated two thousand of million years ago, in the Republic of Gabon, Africa. The discovery of at least 17 NRs in Oklo uranium mine in Gabon was possible from the analysis of the nuclear waste that remaining undisturbed in that mine for nearly two thousand of million years. The reactors were very small of about ten centimeters in diameter and had a power of around 100 kilowatts and were intermittently operating during 150,000 years. Xenon gases generated from the reactors were kept in the crystalline matrix of aluminium phosphate glasses. Recent analysis of the whole pro- duction and trapping process of xenon gasses permitted to know that reactors were intermittently operating in cycles of about 30 minutes and additionally aluminium phosphate glasses showed the capability of trapping xenon gasses in its crystalline matrix for nearly two thousand of millions years. This paper presents the “design”, functioning and safety storage of nuclear waste of NRs that were performed by interdisciplinary work by nature in Oklo, long before man appeared on earth. © 2007, Springer Berlin Heidelberg. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Aluminum; Aquifers; Crystalline materials; Glass; Groundwater pollution; Hydrogeology; Nuclear energy; Nuclear reactor accidents; Nuclear reactors; Nuclear weapons; Radioactive wastes; Radioactivity; Radioisotopes; Storage (materials); Uranium; Aluminium phosphates; Crystalline matrices; General publics; Interdisciplinary work; Nuclear accidents; Nuclear waste storage; Public acceptance; Uranium fuels; Radioactive waste storage

Authors: Chávez R.-H., Guadarrama J.J., Klapp J.
Title: Co2 capture for atmosphere pollution reduction
Source title: Environmental Science and Engineering (Subseries: Environmental Science)
Affiliations: Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México, DF, 11801, Mexico; Instituto Tecnológico de Toluca, Av. Tecnológico S/N, Metepec, 52140, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Chávez, R.-H., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México, DF, 11801, Mexico; Guadarrama, J.J., Instituto Tecnológico de Toluca, Av. Tecnológico S/N, Metepec, 52140, Mexico; Klapp, J., Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Nucleares, Apartado Postal 18-1027, México, DF, 11801, Mexico
Abstract: Carbon dioxide is considered to be the major source of greenhouse gases responsible for global warming; man-made CO2 contributes approximately 63.5 % to all greenhouse gases. Efforts towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions have increased in the past few years, offering promising alternatives in power generation and better fuel efficiency. However, the incorporation of these new technologies to our daily lives represents a big challenge to be solved in the mid- to long-term, leaving separation and CO2 sequestration to be an immediate priority for researchers. CO2 capture and storage can support the transition of our fossil fuel based energy supply towards a sustainable energy system, based upon nuclear and renewable sources. Our present energy infrastructure will largely remain the same during this transition period. For example, electric power plants will be equipped with CO2 capture units, but will produce the same electricity, transported and distributed over the same grid. The first step in the CO2 capture and storage chain is to capture carbon in a high concentration. This can be done before or after combustion of the fuel. Capture is best carried out at large sources of emissions, such as power stations, refineries and other industrial complexes. There are several ways to capture CO2, some of the main methods are absorbents using solvents or solid sorbents, which have been used in industry for several years and seems to be the most feasible solution at this time; membranes have also become an interesting alternative and although extensive research is in progress, new materials for membranes have yet to be discovered. Other methods like pressure- and temperature-swing adsorption using various solid sorbents, cryogenic distillation and new emerging technologies show promising results in the bench testing scale. This report presents a comparison between these different methods. © 2007, Springer Berlin Heidelberg. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Distillation; Electric power plants; Electric power systems; Fossil fuel power plants; Fossil fuels; Fuel storage; Fuels; Gas emissions; Global warming; Greenhouse gases; Industrial emissions; Membranes; Atmosphere pollution; Cryogenic distillations; Emerging technologies; Energy infrastructures; Industrial complex; Pressure and temperature; Renewable sources; Sustainable energy systems; Carbon dioxide

Title: ElectroChem wins SBIR contract from Nasa
Abstract: NASA has awarded ElectroChem a Phase II Small Business Innovation Research contract to continue development of its PEMFC power plants. The contract follows the successful first phase, during which a unique integrated-flow-field (IFF) design was incorporated into the firms hydrogen/oxygen PEMFC power plant. The IFF exhibits superior passive water management, which has led to gravity independence, higher voltage efficiencies and safe operation at high pressures, which promotes higher efficiency. ElectroChem's Phase II project will produce a 250 w IFF stack that will be integrated directly into Nasas advanced energy storage power plant. The enhanced voltage efficiencies and lower excess oxygen requirements offered by the IFF allow a lightweight PEMFC power plant to be built that is ideal for space applications. The IFF design represents a substantial breakthrough in fuel cell technology that eventually will be able to be used in a wide range of Nasas systems and applications, including lunar rovers, shuttles, and space stations.

Title: ISO standard to transport hydrogen storage devices
Abstract: ISO has recently published a new technical specification defining safety requirements for the transport of long-lasting fuel cells, which is expected to announce a new era for hand-held consumer devices such as laptops and cell phones. A new system for transporting hydrogen will facilitate the commercial progress of the industry as well as help build consumer confidence in the use of hydrogen as a clean and safe energy source. The technical specification, ISO/TS 16111: 2006, Transportable gas storage devices - Hydrogen absorbed in reversible metal hydride, will help pave the way for larger, widespread applications of hydrogen by facilitating the safe design and use of transportable hydrogen gas storage canisters. It describes the service conditions, design criteria, type tests and routine tests for these canisters. ISO/TS 16111 is critical to the success of several international regulatory programs related to the transport of metal hydride storage systems, including the International Civil Aviation Organization Dangerous Goods Panel and the UN Subcommittee of Experts on the Transport of Dangerous Goods. ISO/TS 16111 will be referenced in both these regulatory programs.

Authors: Wu C.-H., Kuo T.-W., Chang L.P.
Title: An Efficient B-Tree Layer Implementation for Flash-Memory Storage Systems
Source title: ACM Transactions on Embedded Computing Systems
Affiliations: National Taiwan University, Graduate Institute of Networking and Multimedia, Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering, Taipei, Taiwan; National Chiao-Tung University, Department of Computer and Information Science, Hsin Chu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Wu, C.-H., National Taiwan University, Graduate Institute of Networking and Multimedia, Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering, Taipei, Taiwan; Kuo, T.-W., National Taiwan University, Graduate Institute of Networking and Multimedia, Department of Computer Science and Information Engineering, Taipei, Taiwan; Chang, L.P., National Chiao-Tung University, Department of Computer and Information Science, Hsin Chu, Taiwan
Abstract: With the significant growth of the markets for consumer electronics and various embedded systems, flash memory is now an economic solution for storage systems design. Because index structures require intensively fine-grained updates/modifications, block-oriented access over flash memory could introduce a significant number of redundant writes. This might not only severely degrade the overall performance, but also damage the reliability of flash memory. In this paper, we propose a very different approach, which can efficiently handle fine-grained updates/modifications caused by B-tree index access over flash memory. The implementation is done directly over the flash translation layer (FTL); hence, no modifications to existing application systems are needed. We demonstrate that when index structures are adopted over flash memory, the proposed methodology can significantly improve the system performance and, at the same time, reduce both the overhead of flash-memory management and the energy dissipation. The average response time of record insertions and deletions was also significantly reduced. © 2007, ACM. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Algorithm; B-tree; database systems; Design; embedded systems; Flash memory; Performance; storage systems

Authors: Van Mourik S., Ploegaert J.P.M., Zwart H., Keesman K.J.
Title: Mathematical performance analysis of a temperature controlled bulk storage room
Affiliations: Department of Applied Mathematics, University of Twente, Netherlands; Systems and Control Group, Wageningen University, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Mourik, S., Department of Applied Mathematics, University of Twente, Netherlands; Ploegaert, J.P.M., Systems and Control Group, Wageningen University, Netherlands; Zwart, H., Department of Applied Mathematics, University of Twente, Netherlands; Keesman, K.J., Systems and Control Group, Wageningen University, Netherlands
Abstract: Usually, control design takes place after the plant has been designed. However, the performance of the plant connected to the controller might be improved by simultaneous design of the plant and the controller. In this paper, expressions are deduced that describe the dynamics of a controlled plant (a bulk storage room) and its design criteria. These expressions contain all the physical system parameters, and give insight on how the system performance (in terms of energy usage and temperature uniformity) depends on the design parameters (these are the bulk height and the ventilator- and heat exchanger capacity). This insight gives guidelines for optimal storage room design. The physical relations that could not be found in the literature were identified experimentally. © Copyright 2007 IFAC.
Author Keywords: Control; Identification; Modelling; Process optimization
Index Keywords: Control engineering; Controllers; Identification (control systems); Models; Optimization; Control design; Design criteria; Design parameters; Heat-exchanger capacity; Mathematical Performance; Physical systems; Simultaneous designs; Temperature uniformity; Process control

Authors: Draghiciu N., Albu D., Gordan C., Reiz R.
Title: Power factor correction converter with auxiliary switch
Source title: Proceedings Book - 11th International Conference on Microwave and High Frequency Heating, AMPERE 2007
Affiliations: University of Oradea, Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, 1, Universitatii Street, Oradea, Romania
Authors with affiliations: Draghiciu, N., University of Oradea, Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, 1, Universitatii Street, Oradea, Romania; Albu, D., University of Oradea, Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, 1, Universitatii Street, Oradea, Romania; Gordan, C., University of Oradea, Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, 1, Universitatii Street, Oradea, Romania; Reiz, R., University of Oradea, Faculty of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology, 1, Universitatii Street, Oradea, Romania
Abstract: For lower-power, cost-sensitive applications, the single-stage power factor correction approach may be more attractive. The proposed technique improves the input power factor, reduces the stress on the energy-storage capacitor, and improves the overall efficiency. In this paper, an improved single-stage power factor correction technique which employs an auxiliary switch is presented. © 2007 UNIVERSITY OF ORADEA.
Index Keywords: Power converters; Auxiliary switch; Cost-sensitive applications; Energy storage capacitor; Input power factor; Overall efficiency; Power factor correction converters; Single stage power factor correction; Electric power factor correction

Title: Renewable Energy Conversion, Transmission, and Storage
Source title: Renewable Energy Conversion, Transmission, and Storage
Affiliations: Institute of Studies in Mathematics and Physics, Roskilde University, Novator Advanced Technology Consulting, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Sorensen, B., Institute of Studies in Mathematics and Physics, Roskilde University, Novator Advanced Technology Consulting, Denmark
Abstract: Scientist and engineers working in the field renewable energy must overcome the challenges of conversion, transmission and storage before it can replace more traditional power sources such as oil and gas. In this book, Bent Sorenson provides strategies for the efficient conversion, transmission and storage of all forms of renewable energy. The book provides the reader with a complete background on how renewable energy is transformed into power and the best methods for transmitting and storing the energy produced. Specific to this book is a discussion of conversion processes and storage methods for: geothermal energy, biological and liquid fuels, wave energy, and photovoltaic. In addition the book will cover renewable energy conversions for powering small electrics, as well as battery applications for portable power, and energy bands in semiconductors. *Energy conversion methods for all types of renewable energy *Energy conversion and storage for small *Electronics portable power *Battery applications for portable power *Energy bands and semiconductors. © 2007 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Szynkowska M.I., Lełniewska E., Pawlaczyk A., Rogowski J., Paryjczak T.
Title: Application of the TOF-SIMS and SEM-EDS methods to assess the influ- ÅïÑÅ of dusting from a phosphate waste déposai place based on hair analysis
Affiliations: Technical University of Lodz, Department of Chemistry, Institute of General and Ecological Chemistry, 90-924 Lodz, łeromskiego 116, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Szynkowska, M.I., Technical University of Lodz, Department of Chemistry, Institute of General and Ecological Chemistry, 90-924 Lodz, łeromskiego 116, Poland; Lełniewska, E., Technical University of Lodz, Department of Chemistry, Institute of General and Ecological Chemistry, 90-924 Lodz, łeromskiego 116, Poland; Pawlaczyk, A., Technical University of Lodz, Department of Chemistry, Institute of General and Ecological Chemistry, 90-924 Lodz, łeromskiego 116, Poland; Rogowski, J., Technical University of Lodz, Department of Chemistry, Institute of General and Ecological Chemistry, 90-924 Lodz, łeromskiego 116, Poland; Paryjczak, T., Technical University of Lodz, Department of Chemistry, Institute of General and Ecological Chemistry, 90-924 Lodz, łeromskiego 116, Poland
Abstract: In this work, scanning electron microscopy with energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (SEM-EDS) and the time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS) were used to study the particles present on the hair surface of the inhabitants of Wislinka (people environmentally exposed due to the closeness of a dump) in order to obtain the information about the possible influence of dusting from a phosphate waste déposai place. Additionally, the morphology and the composition of fresh phosphogypsum were analyzed. Waste phosphogypsum is formed in the process of a wet phosphoric acid production and there is still a problem with its storage. A thorough understanding of the composition and chemistry of phosphogypsum seems to be necessary to evaluate its environmental impact comprehensively. The results obtained from these two techniques turned out to be complementary and revealed the information expected. © 2007, Versita. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: hair; phosphogypsum; SEM-EDS; surface analysis; TOF-SIMS

Authors: Lerer M., Duic N., Alves L.M., Carvalho M.G.
Title: H2RES, energy planning tool for increasing the penetration of renewable energy sources in island energy supply
Source title: 2004 New and Renewable Energy Technologies for Sustainable Development
Affiliations: Instituto Superior Tecnico, Av. Rovisco Pais, Lisbon, 1049-001, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Lerer, M., Instituto Superior Tecnico, Av. Rovisco Pais, Lisbon, 1049-001, Portugal; Duic, N., Instituto Superior Tecnico, Av. Rovisco Pais, Lisbon, 1049-001, Portugal; Alves, L.M., Instituto Superior Tecnico, Av. Rovisco Pais, Lisbon, 1049-001, Portugal; Carvalho, M.G., Instituto Superior Tecnico, Av. Rovisco Pais, Lisbon, 1049-001, Portugal
Abstract: The islands’ high energy costs make them excellent test beds for introduction of new technologies. Some islands are trying to become so called renewable islands, to satisfy their energy demand mainly or entirely from indigenous and renewable sources, thus increasing the security of supply, and employment opportunities, without necessarily increasing the costs. Advanced energy planning must consider different intermittent and constant resources, to satisfy the demand for energy, water and fuel for transport, taking into account security of supply on different time scales and necessary supply storage. Such studies cannot be done with traditional methods (LDC and Weibul curves) therefore time series analysis methodology is a requirement. The most promising energy storing technologies are reversible hydro (where geography allows) and storing hydrogen, making possible in the first case integration of the water system, and in the second case integration of the future hydrogen based power and transport systems. This paper describes the new developments in H2RES model, and its application on the example of an isolated island in Madeira archipelago, Porto Santo. HzRES is based on time series analysis that includes wind, precipitation and solar as renewable resources and presents reversible hydro, batteries and hydrogen as energy storages. It also allows for deferrable and hydrogen loads. Considering the present situation and the expected energy needs in Porto Santo by 2010, 7 possible cases of evolution of renewable energies in the island are presented, considering the power and road transport systems. The renewable sources available are wind and solar. In some of the cases, storage is introduced: the excess renewable energy can be used to electrolyze water and the produced hydrogen is stored for later use by fuel cells, either for supplying the power system or for transport needs. Renewable sources can be limited to 30% or to 100% of load, on hourly basis. It is seen that it is possible to significantly increase the penetration of renewable energy sources, albeit at a relatively high cost, with hydrogen storage technology. The H21ZES model can serve as a valuable tool for island energy planning. © 2007 by World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Eriksen J., Glockner R., Yartys V.A., Hafsteinsson B.T., Sigfusson T.I.
Title: Experimental investigation and modelling of thermoelectric generators for use in hydrogen based energy systems
Source title: 2004 New and Renewable Energy Technologies for Sustainable Development
Affiliations: Institute for Energy Technologv (IFE), Kjeller, Norway; Varmaraf ehj Reykjavik, Iceland; University of Iceland (HI), Reykjavik, Iceland
Authors with affiliations: Eriksen, J., Institute for Energy Technologv (IFE), Kjeller, Norway; Glockner, R., Institute for Energy Technologv (IFE), Kjeller, Norway; Yartys, V.A., Institute for Energy Technologv (IFE), Kjeller, Norway; Hafsteinsson, B.T., Varmaraf ehj Reykjavik, Iceland; Sigfusson, T.I., University of Iceland (HI), Reykjavik, Iceland
Abstract: The thermoelectric generator (TEG) represents a silent and reliable solid-state means of converting heat flow directly into electrical energy. The objective of the project is to investigate the potential for integration of TEGs in hydrogen based energy systems with focus on the concept development and evaluation of an integrated MH/TEG-unit for hydrogen energy storage purposes. In order to identify the potential for such MH/TEG-units, a TEG-model has been developed that is currently being verified based on laboratory experiments. Over the past several years hydrogen energy system experts at IFE have developed and managed a collection of hydrogen energy models (HYDROGEMS) that is increasingly being used to develop renewable-hydrogen (RE/H2) projects in countries all around the world. By interfacing the developed TEG-model with the HYDROGEMS library we will be able to virtually connect the TEG-technology to various other technologies, such as metal hydrides, electrolysers, fuel cells, photovoltaics, and wind energy conversion systems, in order to n odeling the design and control of such RE/TEG/Hz-systems. Based on the preliminary nodeling results and experimental data some key system parameters and design guidelines are appointed. © 2007 by World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Shie R.F., Ting K., Yu J.S., Liu C.T.
Title: The sliding and overturning analysis of a free-standing cask under earthquake
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, Taiwan; Lunghwa University of Science and Technology, Taiwan; Fuel Cycle and Materials Administration, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Shie, R.F., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, Taiwan; Ting, K., Lunghwa University of Science and Technology, Taiwan; Yu, J.S., Institute of Nuclear Energy Research, Taiwan; Liu, C.T., Fuel Cycle and Materials Administration, Taiwan
Abstract: A freestanding spent fuel interim storage facility is possible to be selected to house the spent fuel for ChinShan nuclear power station in a period of 5 to 50 years. The design specifications of the storage facility should provide adequate safety assurance under the event of a major earthquake. ANSYS/LS-DYNA computer code is employed in this study to simulate the dynamic behavior of the cask under extremely seismic loading, the criterion which is used to judge whether freestanding cask will slide or overturn is thus established. A cylindrical cask is used as an object which subjected to safety shutdown earthquake of support pad of ChinShan nuclear power station. The cylindrical cask will slide but will not overturn is obtained under maximum earthquake loading. © (2007) Trans Tech Publications, Switzerland.
